Doomsday Dread.gmnote: Creatures who fail this save are cursed and become frightened 2 and cannot reduce the value of their frightened condition until they either succeed at a Recall Knowledge against the Ashen Man or one of his agents (such as Xanderghul or an ancient one), until they deal damage to such a creature, or until this curse is counteracted (this is a 20th-level effect for the purposes of counteracting).
Doomsday Dread.description: A failed attempt to sever the planar link has cursed you. You are filled with an overwhelming sense of dread (Frightened 2), and you cannot shake the feeling of a malevolent presence watching you. This fear cannot be reduced by normal means.

Sanctuary's Blessing.name: Sanctuary's Blessing
Sanctuary's Blessing.description: As a worshiper of a friendly deity to Nocticula, you have found comfort in Sorshen's Prayer Room. After spending an hour in prayer or meditation, you have been granted a divine blessing. This boon allows you to cast a 9th-rank cleanse affliction once in the following 24 hours as an innate divine spell.
Sanctuary's Blessing.gmnote: A PC who worships Nocticula or one of the deities the Redeemer Queen has good relations with (such as Calistria, Desna, Findeladlara, Sarenrae, Shelyn, or Tsukiyo) finds comfort here and instinctively understands that if they spend an hour in prayer or meditation, the room can grant them the ability to cast a 9th-rank cleanse affliction once in the following 24 hours as an innate divine spell.

Gimmel's Arcane Insight.description: By retracing Runelord Gimmel's ancient steps, you've discovered the same subtle manipulations of arcane runes he did. You gain a +2 status bonus to all skill checks made to perform the ritual to Conjure the Oliphaunt
Gimmel's Arcane Insight.name: Gimmel's Arcane Insight

Linnorm's Curse Foreknowledge.name: Linnorm's Curse Foreknowledge
Linnorm's Curse Foreknowledge.description: Understanding the history of the linnorm's curse upon Spindlehorn, you are better prepared to resist its spiritual echoes, granting you a +2 circumstance bonus on Will saves to resist it's vestige of an Ancient Curse.

Masterwork Crafting Suite.name: Masterwork Crafting Suite
Masterwork Crafting Suite.description: The well-equipped crafting room in the Blood Moon Palace contains superior tools and a perfectly organized workspace, giving you a +2 item bonus to Crafting checks to Craft and Repair items there.

Sorshen's Library Reference.name: Sorshen's Library Reference
Sorshen's Library Reference.description: After spending an hour cross-referencing the vast collection in Sorshen's library, your knowledge is bolstered. You gain a +3 item bonus to checks to Recall Knowledge using Arcana, Occultism, and specific Thassilonian Lores.

Clockwork Librarians' Assistance.name: Clockwork Librarians' Assistance
Clockwork Librarians' Assistance.description: The reactivated clockwork librarians silently assist your efforts in the archives, retrieving texts and cross-referencing information with perfect efficiency. You gain a +1 status bonus to checks made to Research while in the archives.

Sorshen's Laboratory.name: Sorshen's Laboratory
Sorshen's Laboratory.description: Working amidst the masterfully crafted alchemical equipment in Sorshen's perfume laboratory grants you a +3 item bonus to Crafting checks made to create alchemical items here.

Archive Lockdown.name: Archive Lockdown
Archive Lockdown.description: As long as the archive's lockdown protocols are active, periodic alarms, flickering lights, and other distractions are a constant nuisance, impeding focused research. You take a -1 status penalty to all research checks made within the archives

Favor of the Divine.name: Favor of the Divine
Favor of the Divine.description: A divine favor bolsters your defenses and quickens your actions. You gain a +2 status bonus to AC and saving throws against Xanderghul's attacks and effects, and you are quickened. At the start of each of your turns, you regain 1 Mythic Point.

Jandelay Navigator.name: Jandelay Navigator
Jandelay Navigator.description: Your research into Jandelay's timeless nature grants you a deep understanding of its patchwork layout. You gain a +3 circumstance bonus to checks made to navigate Jandelay.

Eye of Desire (Boon).name: Eye of Desire (Boon)
Eye of Desire (Boon).description: The waters of the Runewell of Lust grant you a surge of vitality and mental fortitude, providing a +3 circumstance bonus against mental effects and 30 temporary Hit Points.

Watcher's Hymn.name: Watcher's Hymn
Watcher's Hymn.description: By performing an eerie hymn in concert with the watchers of Jandelay, you find a strange resonance with the plane's entropy. When you take the 'Call the Final Cessation' action, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to your skill check.

Clockwork Servants' Assistance.name: Clockwork Servants' Assistance
Clockwork Servants' Assistance.description: With the palace's clockwork servants attending to your daily needs like cooking and cleaning, your mind is free to focus entirely on your research. You gain a +1 status bonus to research checks while in the archives.

Adventure Summary.name: Adventure Summary
Adventure Summary.text:
Into the Apocalypse Archive

Mythic Points

Opportunities for the PCs to regain Mythic Points by completing mythic deeds or defeating mythic foes appear in this adventure, but these shouldn’t be the only way for them to regain Mythic Points. Remember that a PC should regain a Mythic Point whenever they follow their calling or achieve a legendary accomplishment. You should keep an eye on opportunities to award PCs these points—in certain encounters in this adventure, suggestions for when to award points for legendary accomplishments are given, but don’t feel limited to these opportunities. Mythic Points fuel a mythic character’s story, and players shouldn’t feel constantly starved for them or afraid to use them out of fear of not being able to earn more! Critical successes on rolls can be a great opportunity to award a Mythic Point for a legendary accomplishment, especially if the timing of that critical success is particularly cinematic or thematic for the PC in question. As long as the PCs don’t feel like they’re being punished for using these points while simultaneously not spending them frivolously, the rate of Mythic Point renewal is about right!

Chapter 1: Crisis in New Thassilon

Desperate for help, old friends reach out to the PCs: Belimarius has recovered a warshard and has seized control of the ruins of Xin- Eurythnia! Enlisting the allies they’ve made throughout their adventures, the PCs act with strength and swiftness, infiltrating the city and retaking Xin-Eurythnia. They confront the horrors of the Doomsday Door that still haunts the city center and stop Belimarius before she can ascend to mythic power.

Chapter 2: Call to Oblivion

There is much work in store to repair and rebuild Xin-Eurythnia, but the pressure is on to break into Jandelay and stop Xanderghul. The PCs use Sorshen’s archives to devise their route into the demiplane of apocalypses, then travel to Spindlehorn and put the ancient spire to use for its original purpose: summoning the Oliphaunt of Jandelay, herald of the apocalypse. Before they can breach Jandelay, the PCs are pulled into the hidden folds between the planes and face off with the Ashen Man one final time.

Chapter 3: Race to the End

The PCs’ planar odyssey takes them through a menagerie of different apocalypses from Golarion and beyond, from ancient Earthfall thousands of years past to distant Andoffa in a faraway galaxy, all captured within Jandelay’s tapestry of ruins. They race against time to reach the Heart of Jandelay and join Sorshen in a final, mythic battle against Xanderghul.

Advancement Track

“Into the Apocalypse Archive” is designed for four characters.

18The PCs begin this adventure at 18th level.

19The PCs should be 19th level when Chapter 2 begins.

20The PCs should be 20th level when Chapter 3 begins.

The PCs should be 20th level by the time they complete this adventure.

Mission 1: The City Gates.name: Mission 1: The City Gates
Mission 1: The City Gates.text:
Mission 1: The City Gates Severe 18

The PCs and their allies make the short journey from the staging cavern to Xin-Eurythnia. While high-level PCs who have access to powerful spells don’t need to limit themselves to entering the city via its southern gates, most of their allies do. More importantly, however, undermining the forces Belimarius has posted at the southern gates allows the PCs to swiftly demoralize and distract the occupying forces. Unlike the last time the PCs were this close to Xin-Eurythnia, there are no civilians to watch over; instead, they are accompanied by a small strike force made up of their most powerful allies. Belimarius knows her plans for Xin-Eurythnia will face resistance; depending on how the PCs dealt with her generals in the last volume, she may even expect the PCs specifically to oppose her. Her soldiers maintain a tight perimeter around the occupied city, patrolling the area from the sky overhead, and the city gates are barricaded and under heavy guard.

As the PCs approach, they find evidence of war and tragedy everywhere they look. The bodies of giants and sinspawn soldiers who died fighting Darklands monsters are intermixed with the remains of every loss the PCs suffered during their flight down the mountain in Lord of the Trinity Star.

Use the map of Xin-Eurythnia’s Gates for this encounter.

Mission 1: The City Gates Severe 18

@UUID[Actor.iwCvPV9CFeIgfTA8]{Rune Giants (3)} @UUID[Actor.fexMj2pgHMWc1ncy]{Runic Warmaws (3)}

Creatures: Xin-Eurythnia’s gates are fortified and guarded by rune giants and sinspawn soldiers. The PCs must defeat these guardians in order to begin their invasion of the city, as word spreads quickly of combat that takes place here. Stealthy PCs can scope the gates out from afar, but if they’re spotted, the guards attack. Wise PCs watch, observing patrol patterns, and then stage their attack at a point where the defenders are spread out along the wall.

Eye of Desire.name: Eye of Desire
Eye of Desire.text:
A2. Eye of Desire Severe 18

A stream of soft, summer sunlight illuminates this intimate grotto both from a wide hole in the roof of the cave and from a tunnel exit. Blue-green hues cascade across the cavern walls, reflected up from a pool of gently surging seawater. Near the center of the grotto, a beautiful throne made of giant, pearlized pink seashell glitters with understated power, and a wooden bath collects the purifying waters of a hot spring near the back of the cave. A sandy beach lies near the hot spring, while a statue of a beautiful woman lies half-toppled over in the water near this shore. Rocks set up almost like stepping stones protrude from the water, giving potential places to stand on just above the water. Thousands of glowing red runes flicker across the cavern’s walls—each one of which strains and shimmers as if something in the area were trying and failing to erase them.

Sorshen’s demiplane, the Eye of Desire, appears as a small sea cavern. Gentle sunlight streams in, spotlighting a pink abalone throne in the center of the blue-green pool. While most of the demiplane is filled with 30-foot-deep and gently sloshing seawater, a sandy beach at one end offers a dry place for supplicants and visitors to stand. Before Belimarius’ arrival to the demiplane, a huge statue depicting the formidable Runelord Sorshen, a relic of her old self carved thousands of years ago, used to stand next to the throne with a watchful eye and a devious, knowing smile. One of Belimarius’s first alterations to the Eye of Desire was to topple this statue over.

The hole in the ceiling above appears to lead up and out of the cave, while the tunnel on the far side of the grotto from the sandy beach appears to open up onto an ocean shoreline. Both of these are nothing more than complex illusions—attempts to exit the cave beyond these areas are impossible, simply because they’re at the edge of this small, finite demiplane. The cave ceiling itself is 20 feet high over the open water, but only 10 feet high over the sandy beach and hot spring.

Within the Eye of Desire, the Runewell of Lust manifests as a wooden bath fed by a natural hot spring. Belimarius’s manipulations of the Eye of Desire by etching runes on the walls with her warshard, combined with Sorshen’s absence from Golarion, have rendered most of the Runewell of Lust’s powers inert, although a small glimmer of Sorshen’s protection can still aid the PCs. The first time a PC ends their turn standing in the three-foot-deep hot spring that is the Runewell of Lust, they gain a +3 circumstance bonus against mental effects and 30 temporary Hit Points for 1 minute (@UUID[Item.bavoHIYN3Rcl749V]{Runewell of Lust's Boon}).

The PCs appear in the demiplane on the beach next to the runewell; allow the players to place their PCs anywhere they wish on the beach, as long as they're all on it and within 10 feet of the hot spring's edge (this placement becomes important once combat begins). As they likely expect, Belimarius is already here, and she has performed a powerful rite of envy to warp the demiplane for her own use. It's only a @Check[athletics|dc:15|traits:move,skill,action:swim|name:Swim] check to Swim in the water here—otherwise, non-flying PCs can hop from rock to rock to reach the abalone throne, although the tops of each rock require a @Check[acrobatics|dc:20|traits:move,skill,action:balance|name:Balance] check to avoid slipping and falling prone (or into the water on a critical failure). None of these checks should particularly challenge the PCs, of course, but that's not the case for the Eye's current occupants!

Creatures: Belimarius broods with a haughty confidence on the abalone throne, her halberd in one hand. Every wall of the sea cave has been defaced by her hand with Thassilonian runes of jealousy and loathing, and the tight, angry scrawl is incandescent with the arcane power it contains. A statue of Queen Sorshen that once stood proudly by the throne has toppled into the water. The statue’s face and shoulders look up into the light instead of maintaining a powerful gaze across her demiplane.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.z7s6pzaKVgGGMxXI]{Raise Beach Water}

A2. Eye of Desire Severe 18

@UUID[Actor.4205je7y2Dr5RRU4]{Belimarius} @UUID[Actor.bI5YYmY7hWNeiTgh]{Knights of Malice (3)}

When the PCs arrive, Runelord Belimarius waits on the seashell throne at the cavern’s center. She is attended by three knights of malice who stand at attention atop nearby rocks. Belimarius is not surprised to see the PCs, and beyond a snide comment (“Here to witness history, are we?”), she has little desire to exchange pleasantries before launching into an attack.

If the PCs don't confront her within 12 hours of completing encounter @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22101crisis.JournalEntryPage.01abundanceove00]{A1}, Belimarius starts this conflict having already cast some preparatory spells. If they arrive more than 24 hours later, however, they’ll face her with her newly gained mythic power.

On the first round of combat, Belimarius Sacrifices the Warshard she carries, then casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx]{Freeze Time}. She uses the first set of 3 actions granted by this spell to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.zfn5RqAdF63neqpP]{Control Water}, raising the water level to the south to flood the sand beach from floor to ceiling around the PCs, then activates her @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.K2rMmiBlzcysNuj6]{Belt of Long Life} to Call Upon the Ancient Life. On the second set of 3 actions, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force}, placing it in a way to divide the PCs and, hopefully, trapping some of them on the beach behind the wall and inside of a fully-flooded area. With the final set of three actions, she either draws her wand of mountain resilience and casts it on herself (then drops the wand on the throne so her hands are free to wield her halberd), or if she’s already cast this spell (as a result of the PCs taking too long to enter the Eye of Desire) casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XXqE1eY3w3z6xJCB]{Invisibility} and uses her third action to fly farther away from the sandy shore to preserve her ranged superiority.

After this, the knights of malice move forward to attack any PCs not trapped by the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force}, engaging them in melee while Belimarius remains at the back of the cavern and attacks with her magic. For example, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.73rToy0v5Ra9NvL6]{Duplicate Foe} as soon as any PC comes within range, uses @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.kUSShxXzY1sPtJA0]{Detonate Magic} on any PC who has an obvious spell effect that’s giving them an advantage (such as haste or flight), or casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Oj1PJBMQD9vuwCv7]{Quandary} on the first PC to dare engage her in melee. When she must use her halberd, she generally only Strikes once with it per round, using the remaining actions to cast spells unless she’s facing foes who have reactions triggered by such actions, in which case she’ll focus on putting distance between them and herself.

If reduced to fewer than 75 Hit Points, Belimarius realizes things could actually go bad for her, and she tries to make it to the Runewell of Lust. Once there, she’ll use three Interact actions to try to flee back to Sorshen’s atrium, and if she makes it there, she casts translocate to travel deeper into Xin-Eurythnia and thence escape. See @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22104beyond]{Beyond the Campaign} for further ramifications if she flees in this way, but in the short term, her flight from the city has the same effects as her death: her army grows increasingly panicked and disorganized as the news of their leader's defeat spreads, and the PCs are free to continue into @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto]{Chapter 2} uncontested.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.VxzgaWpC1AnpIogS]{Belimarius' Robe} @UUID[Actor.dA8XLsJ1MsJOsEl3]{Runewell of Lust}
In addition to the magical gear the PCs can loot from the knights of malice and Runelord Belimarius, an investigation of the deep pockets of her robe turns up one of Belimarius’s many spellbooks. It contains all of the spells she has prepared, along with any other spells the GM may wish to introduce into the campaign—although the PCs might have already promised this treasure to her generals in Sorshen’s atrium.

Tucked into the pages of her spellbook are a few folded parchments on which Belimarius has scribbled several partial maps of the Blood Moon Palace—if the PCs hand the spellbook over to the generals without first investigating these maps, the generals helpfully hand the maps over with a comment, “You might need these,” before going on their way. The maps were made by Belimarius as she first arrived on the scene and chart her route through the complex to Sorshen’s atrium and the anima focus, and scribbled in the margins are several “to do” lists, reminders, and ruminations the PCs can use to learn more about any of Belimarius's plans they remain unclear on. In particular, these notes reveal that Belimarius suspects a place in the lower levels of the palace to contain “Sorshen’s archives”—an area she hopes to investigate for more information about how to conjure the Oliphaunt and enter Jandelay to destroy Sorshen and Xanderghul, leaving herself as the sole heir of Thassilon’s runelord legacy.

The greatest treasure here, though, is access to the Runewell of Lust. As soon as Belimarius is either slain or force to flee the Eye of Desire, the runes she etched on the walls with the warshard fade and the Runewell of Lust is immediately restored.

Rewards: The PCs earn 3 Mythic Points for the legendary accomplishment of defeating Runelord Belimarius.

Crisis in New Thassilon.name: Crisis in New Thassilon
Crisis in New Thassilon.text:
Chapter 1: Crisis in New Thassilon

While the PCs have spent their time since Sorshen’s disappearance evacuating the citizens of Xin-Eurythnia, exploring the Emerald Chambers, opposing the Risen of the Trinity Star, and traveling through the depths of the Dreamlands, Runelord Belimarius has been hard at work solidifying her control over New Thassilon. Ever since her escape from the time-locked prison of Cyrusian at the end of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path, she’s clashed politically against her nation’s neighbors—but with none more ferociously than Queen Sorshen, the “co-ruler” of New Thassilon.

With Sorshen out of the picture, Runelord Belimarius’s armies spread through New Thassilon, from the southern border shared with Varisia to the northern border shared with the Lands of the Linnorm Kings, expanding her domain and destroying her enemies. As her soldiers marched across New Thassilon, they discovered a warshard buried deep in the Red Mountains—a fragment of the armor shed by Gorum when he fell, which contained a single, deadly sliver of godly might.

Belimarius immediately recognized the warshard’s vast and incredible potential and how it could not only aid her conquest of the Saga Lands, but also give her what she’s sought ever since she first became Runelord of Envy—a source of mythic power. It didn’t take her long to research a method by which the warshard’s power could be amplified through a runewell, a Thassilonian artifact certain runelords of old used to focus and heighten their magic. While Belimarius’ own runewell, the Eye of Avarice, was destroyed (which freed her and the city of Xin-Edasseril from the Dimension of Time), she knows Sorshen still possesses the Runewell of Lust and that it was moved from its place beneath Korvosa to her capital in New Thassilon. With Sorshen gone, the strength of her runewell can be Belimarius’s if she only takes it. The Runelord of Envy immediately recalled her generals from Varisia, occupied the evacuated ruins of Xin-Eurythnia, and began searching the city for the Runewell of Lust.

This swift invasion takes place while the PCs are occupied in the Dreamlands in the previous adventure, and when they return to the waking world, allies like Ayavah and Kandirvek (if he survived the previous volumes) are eager to catch the PCs up to speed.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
Getting Started

At the end of the previous adventure, the PCs rescued the self-styled “eighth runelord,” Liralarue, from an oubliette deep in the nightmare realm of Leng. Liralarue wastes no time creating a new dreamscape to dwell in and invites the PCs to visit whenever they dream. This and other types of aid she can grant them are detailed further (@UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06campaignrole02]{Here}).

When the PCs travel out of the Dreamlands (or, if they’ve already returned to the waking world, as soon as they sleep), they receive an urgent message from Ayavah, who delivers it to one of their slumbering minds via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.yM3KTTSAIHhyuP14]{Dream Message}. If any PC grew particularly close to her during the previous volumes, that is the PC who receives the message; failing that, Ayavah contacts the hero with the highest Charisma modifier. Paraphrase the following text, substituting in the PC’s name and making any other changes appropriate to their past interactions with Ayavah. Remember that a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.yM3KTTSAIHhyuP14]{Dream Message} spell can convey a maximum of roughly 150 words, so you have room in the following read-aloud text to add personal touches you feel would help compel the PCs to come quickly to Vekker’s Crossing.

Ayavah’s voice rings melodiously, like the crystal-clear memory of a song the listener has always known but never heard before. She manifests in the dreamscape, floating in the air like a strange spirit. “Blessings of the Redeemer, my friend, and greetings to your companions. I’m afraid we are in terrible crisis and need your aid once more! Runelord Belimarius has invaded the ruins of Xin-Eurythnia. She brings with her a warshard, and as her army occupies the remnants of our city, I fear she seeks a way to weaponize that shard and unlock its deific power. Come quickly to Vekker’s Crossing—I shall meet you there!”

Regardless of where they left Ayavah the last time they spoke to her, she’s currently at Vekker’s Crossing. If the PCs don’t arrive promptly and fail to explain their delay in a reply, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.yM3KTTSAIHhyuP14]{Dream Message} again to spur them onward nightly until they arrive or reply.

Though the PCs are contacted by Ayavah, the logistics of driving Belimarius out of occupied Xin-Eurythnia have been coordinated primarily by another—Galissodia (pretentious female ancient rime dragon), whom the PCs briefly glimpsed in Lord of the Trinity Star. Galissodia was leaving Queen Sorshen’s side when the PCs arrived at the Blood Moon Palace to meet with Sorshen in that adventure. Galissodia has been a close ally of Sorshen’s since the foundation of New Thassilon in 4718, and when she was unable to locate the queen after the disaster, she tracked the Eurythnians to Vekker’s Crossing, where she was eventually intercepted and questioned by other allies before being brought into the fold.

The method by which the PCs travel to Vekker’s Crossing is left to them to determine. For example, if he still lives and is nearby, the omen dragon Kandirvek can certainly fly them there. When the PCs finally meet with Ayavah, however, she reveals to the PCs that Galissodia and a few others have already started to work on plans to retake Xin-Eurythnia and oust Runelord Belimarius’s occupying army, and that they intend to make use of one of the rime dragon’s local outpost lairs. Ayavah’s been there and can use a scroll of teleport to transport the PCs to the region, but she warns them that they might face a mile or so of arduous mountain travel to reach Galissodia’s cave depending on where the spell actually sends them. It’s best to gloss over this bit of inconvenience—the PCs are 18th-level mythic heroes at this point, so a one-mile jaunt through one of Golarion’s most inhospitable mountain ranges should be a simple task!

Retaking Xin-Eurythnia.name: Retaking Xin-Eurythnia
Retaking Xin-Eurythnia.text:
Retaking Xin-Eurythnia

When the PCs arrive, Galissodia, Kandirvek (if he survived), and a handful of Eurythnian soldiers and tacticians are strategizing over a map of Xin-Eurythnia and the surrounding mountains. The cavern around them is stocked with weapons, armor, food, and other supplies for war. Galissodia circles the war table, approaching the PCs to introduce herself.

“Sorshen was greatly impressed by you,” the rime dragon muses softly, her voice gentler than her fearsome physique suggests. “It is my dearest hope that I, too, might come to be so impressed. I am Galissodia, Keeper of Records. Please join us. We have much to discuss and even more to prepare.”

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.YyFv9BpDz8DswCCq]{Galissodia's Cave} @UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.HjGy7cW4zZHDLoo1]{Xin Eurythnia}

The two dragons, Ayavah, and the dozen expert tacticians waste no time bringing the PCs up to speed on their operation. Now that the PCs have arrived, Galissodia is eager for them to assume a mantle of leadership as well. Though she is an ancient and powerful dragon, she is a historian first and foremost; she is not a strategist or a master of war, nor does she have the power of a mythic destiny behind her.

Listed below are the four most important factors the PCs are brought up to speed on.

  • The warshard: Belimarius acquired a fragment of the fallen god Gorum. Galissodia learned of a contingent of rune giants marching east from the Red Mountains, taking great care to escort something precious. Concerned about the incredible danger a giant attack would pose to Vekker’s Crossing, the rime dragon immediately contacted Ayavah with the news. Ayavah explained that she’s used a few scrolls of read omens to augment prayers to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.jL1qiVOZBKXETtVD]{Nocticula} over the past week and was granted visions of Belimarius’ armies uncovering a jagged, dark red fragment of metal in the mountains she identified as a warshard. She also received warnings of the devastation in store for the Saga Lands if Belimarius is not stopped.
  • Belimarius's plans: In Ayavah's visions, Belimarius ascended to new heights of arcane power, seated on a glittering scallop-shell throne. Three delicate pitchers poured water into a magnificent pool surrounding the runelord, signs that Ayavah believes represent a great reservoir of power. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge correctly interprets the vision's imagery as a representation of a runewell , and if they critically succeed, they recognize specific elements, such as the throne and the trio of pitchers, which can be found in the Eye of Desire, a demiplane hidden within Sorshen's Runewell of Lust .
  • The state of Xin-Eurythnia: Between dragons scouting the city from the air and Ayavah’s divinatory spells, the group has some intelligence on the current state of Xin-Eurythnia. Terrible creatures from the Darklands crawled up from below into the abandoned city after the Eurythnians evacuated, and when Belimarius’ army marched through the Kodar Mountains, these monsters were the first obstacles keeping them from uncontested control of the ruined city. The damage to Xin-Eurythnia is extensive and grows worse by the day, and the sinkhole in Temple Plaza that opened during the Unveiling Ceremony remains.
  • Targets of Opportunity: Finally, the group has identified a handful of key locations that Belimarius’s army relies on for their war effort or seems unusually interested in. These are the locations where the PCs can make the largest difference while the rest of the resistance runs distractions and interference to keep the bulk of the occupying forces busy. The PCs can thus mount quick, surgical strikes behind enemy lines.

Resources and Objectives.name: Resources and Objectives
Resources and Objectives.text:
Resources and Objectives

Though the resistance includes dragons, a powerful Nocticulan priestess, several gifted tacticians, and the PCs, this is not enough to lay siege to a city or to directly confront Belimarius’s army of wizards, highly-trained soldiers, giants, and monsters. Galissodia believes, however, that the PCs can assume the role of a small group of elite specialists and make several focused strikes as well as investigate key locations without rousing the wrath of the entire occupying army—especially if the rest of the resistance works to keep the bulk of Belimarius’s forces distracted!

Galissodia has prepared a map of Xin-Eurythnia to point out these locations. The adventure assumes the PCs know the city’s layout and focuses tightly on specific encounters, so the full scope of Xin-Eurythnia’s layout doesn’t play a significant role in this particular adventure.

The locations that the resistance has flagged for investigation and targeted attack are listed below. These encounters can be tackled in any order.

City Gates: While many of the occupying forces can fly or use magic to travel, a sudden strike on the guards stationed at Xin-Eurythnia’s southern gates can throw the occupying army into an increased state of disarray and damage their morale.

Rescue Locals: Not everyone evacuated the city, and many of those who chose to remain behind have been killed by Belimarius’s forces—her army doesn’t seem interested in taking prisoners. A large number of refugees have gone into hiding amid several ruined buildings in the northwest portion of the city’s Artisan District, but that place has become infested with monsters from the Darklands that have slithered from rifts in the ground up to the surface. The PCs must defeat these monsters and ensure the safety of the survivors, who doubtless possess a wealth of intelligence to share!

Temple Plaza: Here, the sinkhole down to the Doomsday Door remains open and has become a focus of the occupying army. One of the army commanders, a rune giant named Yrasthura, is located here. Defeating her and then investigating the sinkhole to make sure more threats don’t await inside it are both important tasks to be tackled.

Mission 2: Rescue Locals.name: Mission 2: Rescue Locals
Mission 2: Rescue Locals.text:
Mission 2: Rescue Locals Moderate 18

The PCs find Xin-Eurythnia in ruins. Though Belimarius might intend to conquer the city, bringing eastern and western New Thassilon under her rule, the rune giants in her army seem unconcerned with leaving the occupied city whole. The damage of the earthquakes and rockslides has gone unrepaired, and entire buildings have been torn apart by creatures who came up through fissures from the Darklands or been crushed underfoot by rune giants unconcerned with Belimarius’s next plans for her new territory.

During this mission, the PCs make their way through these ruins to the region where their allies have learned that survivors now make their last stand. At your discretion, the PCs may face a fight against a few rune giants if they’re particularly obvious or brazen in their approach, but once they arrive at the district, there’s no mistaking it—monsters from the Darklands have taken control of this site. A rockslide from the nearby mountain has buried several buildings, and throughout the detritus of the slide gape several new caverns and rifts from which a deluge of monstrosities emerged.

Mission 2: Rescue Locals Moderate 18

@UUID[Actor.3FAYf1HNqrmoz66T]{Shoggoths (2)}

Creatures: By the time the PCs reach this area, the less powerful gogiteths and giant worms and oversized creepy crawlers have all been slaughtered by the area's current rulers—a pair of shoggoths. The two formless aberrations have each claimed a different part of this space as their new lair. The first has wedged itself into the fissure to the northwest, while the second lurks on the rooftop of the damaged building directly south. Both work together once they spot the PCs, fighting to the death.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.NV7RMz9zM6zXbywr]{Gear Stashes}
Once the shoggoths are slain, dozens of frightened locals emerge from hiding to thank the PCs. They quickly tell the party about several stashes of gear and magic they hid in the area but were then quickly cut off from reaching—supplies that are now the PCs’ for the taking. With a rescued citizen’s directions, 10 minutes of work going from building to building allows the party to recover two major ghost charge bombs, a major glue bomb, 5 major healing potions, 2 panaceas, a greater electricity energy breath potion, a scroll of foresight, a +3 greater striking greater astral quickstrike longsword, a +3 greater resilient standard-grade dawnsilver chain shirt, a wand of disappearance, a scroll of falling stars, a suit of +3 greater resilient greater winged half-plate bearing etchings and imagery sacred to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, and a greater splinter spear. The refugees are content to remain in hiding now that the shoggoths are dead—they can be rescued by the PCs’ other allies in short order while the PCs themselves move on to their next mission.

Gathering Intel.name: Gathering Intel
Gathering Intel.text:
Gathering Intel

No one seems to know exactly where Runelord Belimarius is currently located. Each time the PCs complete one of the three tasks they’ve been assigned, they’ll be able to learn more about Belimarius’s plans and potentially her current location. After finishing a mission, the PCs earn one of the following packets of information, gathered either from reports given by rescued citizens, from eavesdropping on enemy soldiers or interrogating captured foes, or simply as a result of observing Xin-Eurythnia through skill or magic. Rather than put the PCs through a gamut of skill checks, it’s best to reward them with these reports after every time they complete one of the three missions so that play can proceed briskly and quickly.

First Report: Belimarius is sacking Xin-Eurythnia to secure Sorshen’s Runewell of Lust, which she plans to use alongside her warshard to trigger an ascension to mythic power and become the sole ruler of New Thassilon.

Second Report: Once Belimarius has harnessed the warshard’s potential, she plans to solidify her victory by pursuing Sorshen and Xanderghul into Jandelay to destroy her rivals completely. Her plans to access this strange demiplane involve entreating a dangerous, many-tusked planar abomination called the Oliphaunt to create a passageway between the planes so that she can ride the legendary creature into Jandelay.

Final Report: Belimarius recently entered the Blood Moon Palace accompanied by her generals and a contingent of sinspawn knights—she believes the Runewell of Lust is hidden within. According to current intelligence, Belimarius is still somewhere in the palace. Proceed with @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22101crisis.JournalEntryPage.01sorshensatri00]{Sorshen’s Atrium}) once the PCs learn this final piece of information.

Reward: Each time the PCs earn a report, grant them 80 XP.

Mission 3: Temple Plaza.name: Mission 3: Temple Plaza
Mission 3: Temple Plaza.text:
Mission 3: Temple Plaza Severe 18

When the PCs approach Temple Plaza, read or paraphrase the following as the PCs draw near.

Destroyed tents, garbage, and the ruins of nearby buildings cover Temple Plaza, a reminder of the chaos that concluded the Unveiling Ceremony when Sorshen disappeared. Where the square was once a beautiful park flush with trees and flowering bushes, something has drained the vitality from every vestige of nature. Now, the withered, leafless branches of trees that look as though they died centuries past offer barely any shadow or shade.

The deep and terrible pit that swallowed the Circle of Open Hands portal during the Unveiling Ceremony remains at the plaza’s center, save that a sickly green light now shines up from its depths.

Mission 3: Temple Plaza Severe 18

@UUID[Actor.7v4RrpsnkVbOjwZl]{Commander Yrasthura} @UUID[Actor.VaOVN1vhCwcvzlQK]{Knights of Malice (3)} @UUID[Actor.fexMj2pgHMWc1ncy]{Runic Warmaw}

Creatures: The perimeter of the former plaza is patrolled by Yrasthura, an elite rune giant commander who is accompanied by three knights of malice and a runic warmaw. Though Yrasthura is a petty warmonger and delights in violence, she surrenders to the PCs if they reduce her to 50 or fewer Hit Points, as they have proven that their strength surpasses her own. She can offer the PCs valuable intelligence about Belimarius’s whereabouts if they accept her surrender. The knights of malice and runic warmaw fight to the death, and Yrasthura does not care if they live or die; she holds no particular loyalty toward them and uses them to save herself whenever convenient.

If Yrasthura surrenders to the PCs, they may be able to skip over any remaining missions, for she believes they have the strength necessary to defeat Belimarius—a more than satisfactory justification for her to walk away from the Runelord of Envy. Yrasthura shares her orders with the PCs, revealing that she and the other rune giants were told to hold the city while Belimarius and her generals found and conquered Sorshen’s demiplane in the Eye of Desire. She tells the PCs that Belimarius went to the Blood Moon Palace and hasn’t left it in days, leaving her and the other rune giants to conclude the palace must be the location of the Runewell of Lust.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.V1YIBIwNQrno81aU]{Commander's Loot}
Though Commander Yrasthura's sword is too big for the PCs to wield, they can transfer its runes normally. Her ceremonial armor was crafted custom to her body and designed with thin, engraved windows to let the runes that cover her skin shine through. It's worth 15,000 gp to a collector of unique armor or giant cultural items. Though Yrasthura gives her sword to the PCs willingly after surrendering, they must succeed at a @Check[diplomacy|dc:35] check to stop Yrasthura from holding a grudge against them if they force her to part with her armor.

Closing the Doomsday Door.name: Closing the Doomsday Door
Closing the Doomsday Door.text:
Closing the Doomsday Door

When the PCs are ready, they can descend to the bottom of the sinkhole. This encounter is a mythic deed and uses the Victory Points subsystem (Pathfinder GM Core 184) to track the PCs’ progress in decoupling the Doomsday Door. You can use the Mission 3 map to track the PCs’ movements as they descend into the sinkhole, but you won’t need to do so tactically until they face the ancient one, after they close the Doomsday Door.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.pwbU9WxUdbqUvPl9]{Disable Light}

Once the PCs reach the lowest point of the sinkhole at a depth of 100 feet, they are immediately faced with the dangers created by the Doomsday Door. To end this threat and close it fully, they must face the following three Victory Point challenges in the order presented. Each obstacle lists recommended skills and check DCs to earn Victory Points, though consider the PCs’ creative alternatives in resolving checks. Action progresses in rounds. During each round, every PC attempts a check to earn Victory Points. If their accumulated point total equals or exceeds the threshold value at the end of a round, they prevail and move on. If they don’t have enough points, they spend an additional round overcoming the obstacle. Keep track of the number of rounds the players take to close the gate, as the total number of rounds it takes for them to overcome all three dangers determines their results.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.D2Wp0aZk8OYAWecV]{Closing The Doomsday Door}

Annihilation’s Gasp

Threshold 4; Overcome @Check[acrobatics|dc:40] or @Check[athletics|dc:40] (to maneuver down the fissure without hitting the walls), @Check[perception|dc:43] (to identify the dangerous areas of the chasm in advance), or @Check[reflex|dc:48] (to float on the currents and descend the pit in time with the storm)

A foul windstorm brews within the pit, sucking in toward the bottom one moment and pushing out and away the next, as though the Doomsday Door were breathing in and out. Approaching the door requires tremendous strength and balance to avoid being sundered against the chasm’s jagged walls.

Critical Failure Creatures who critically fail are smashed against the fissure walls, taking @Damage[10d6[bludgeoning]] damage.

The Storm Fissure

Threshold 4; Overcome @Check[occultism|dc:40] or @Check[religion|dc:40] to identify the planar energies leaking through the door and neutralize them, @Check[survival|dc:43] to ward yourself against the dangers of a hostile plane, or @Check[fortitude|dc:48] to endure the pain

This door links Golarion to another terrible plane. Though the door is closed, vile energy nonetheless uses it as an anchoring point to access the Universe, leaking through and permeating the world with ruinous potential. Creatures in the door's presence feel this dreadful influence washing over them, blistering skin down to the bone and scorching away their vitality and cohesion.

Critical Failure Creatures who critically fail are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} by the ruinous influence of this other plane. If a PC is already drained 1, their drained condition value increases by 1, to a maximum of drained 4.

Shatter the Ties

Threshold 4; Overcome @Check[arcana|dc:40], @Check[occultism|dc:40], or @Check[thievery|dc:40] to reach between the planes and pull the threads apart, @Check[crafting|dc:43] to quickly craft barricades against the planar leakage, or weapon Strike AC 48 to shatter the silvery cord tethering the two planes together

To save Golarion from the catastrophes waiting behind the Doomsday Door, the link between the two planes must be sundered and sealed. To sever the planar connection, the PCs must overpower or outsmart the spellcaster responsible for its binding, a spellcaster who surely lies on the other side of the door.

Critical Failure @UUID[Item.DXl2VPBApUF8ITYa]{Doomsday Dread}
Creatures who critically fail tap into the link instead of breaking it unless they succeed at a @Check[will|dc:43] saving throw. Creatures who fail this save are cursed and become frightened 2 and cannot reduce the value of their frightened condition until they either succeed at a Recall Knowledge against the Ashen Man or one of his agents (such as Xanderghul or an ancient one), until they deal damage to such a creature, or until this curse is counteracted (this is a 20th-level effect for the purposes of counteracting).

Rewards: Once the PCs overcome all three obstacles and sever the Doomsday Door's connection to Jandelay, each PC restores 3 Mythic Points for completing this mythic deed. They also earn 100 XP and may earn additional XP and information depending on the number of rounds it took them to close the Doomsday Door.

  • 7 or more rounds: Increase the XP reward by 20 XP. The PCs learn that this Doomsday Door leads to Jandelay, an ancient demiplane hidden within the folds of the Maelstrom, and that this link between the two planes was the ingress that allowed a spellcaster on the other side of the door to reach across the Great Beyond and into Xin-Eurythnia to pull Sorshen into Jandelay.
  • 5 to 6 rounds: Increase the XP reward by 40 XP. The PCs gain all the information presented above, but confirm that Runelord Xanderghul is the “spellcaster” in question, that he was the one to create the planar link the PCs just severed, and that he is currently located on Jandelay and locked in a brutal, lasting struggle against Queen Sorshen.
  • 4 or fewer rounds: Increase the XP reward by 60 XP. In addition to the information presented above, the PCs’ brief connection to Jandelay grants them visions of that plane. They learn that Jandelay is a demiplane that holds the remains of ruined worlds, and that its great and terrible herald, a towering beast called the Oliphaunt of Jandelay, appears when a world’s destruction is imminent. Through these visions, they understand that the Oliphaunt was summoned to Golarion long ago at Spindlehorn, and that before it returned to Jandelay, it left something of itself behind at that legendary site.

The Ashen Man's Anger.name: The Ashen Man's Anger
The Ashen Man's Anger.text:
The Ashen Man's Anger Moderate 18

The PCs have little time to rest or celebrate their victory after sealing the Doomsday Door and severing its connection to Jandelay before the Ashen Man realizes his plans have been disrupted once again. Already impatient because Xanderghul has been delayed by his long clash with Sorshen, the Ashen Man becomes freshly incensed when he senses that Jandelay’s influence on Golarion has been shuttered and vents his frustrations by sending one of his servants, an ancient one, to enact the consequences of his displeasure. For the moment, he resists the growing urge to step in and personally attack the party—the time for these more direct measures will come soon!

Creature: A tall, robed creature manifests in the air 60 feet above the sealed Doomsday Door. As this ancient one manifests, the PCs hear the Ashen Man’s voice in their heads:

“And here you stand again, obstructing a doom chosen by fate. Do you still not understand that Golarion has been promised to Jandelay? The seed of apocalypse was sown thousands of years before you, and the time for reaping is nigh.”

The ancient one is a denizen of the Dimension of Time and a servant of the Ashen Man. Equally invested in Golarion’s place in the cycle of time coming to an end, this ancient one believes Golarion has grown too old to cultivate anything other than chaos and destruction.

The Ashen Man's Anger Moderate 18

@UUID[Actor.JgERplzeHFHc7ev4]{Ancient One (The Ashen Man's Anger)}

Once the Ashen Man has finished delivering his short introduction, the ancient one attacks. The creature’s alien perspective on death means it is not afraid of being killed by the PCs and has little interest in negotiating with them. It knows the end of its life can never undo all it has already achieved. This particular ancient one wields an unusual weapon—a timeflaying blade—that it favors in melee combat.

Treasure: When the ancient one is defeated, its robes fall to the ground empty and slowly begin to unravel. Within the bundle of unraveling robes, the PCs can claim the ancient one’s timeflaying blade.

Into the Blood Moon Palace.name: Into the Blood Moon Palace
Into the Blood Moon Palace.text:
Into the Blood Moon Palace

Once the PCs learn that Belimarius was last seen in the Blood Moon Palace, they can chase after her. Sorshen’s Blood Moon Palace has not fared well since the PCs’ last visit. Walls and floors across the upper levels have caved in, and blocked stairs render entire wings inaccessible. Sinspawn knights patrol the palace in greater numbers than in any other part of the city, a clear sign that the PCs are making progress toward Belimarius’s position. By this point, however, word of the PCs’ strength has spread, and the sinspawn here flee at their approach. The dangers the PCs encounter in the palace on their initial search should be simple affairs for them to brush aside—but after less than an hour, they should arrive at the central atrium of the palace, where three of Belimarius’s generals wait.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.cipFpzwDYFjjWIPm]{Blood Moon Palace}

Sorshen’s Atrium.name: Sorshen’s Atrium
Sorshen’s Atrium.text:
Sorshen’s Atrium

A Personal Vendetta

If your players played through the Shades of Blood Adventure Path and killed that adventure’s main villain, Nicza, before bringing the same characters to Revenge of the Runelords, their encounter with Lograsi in the previous volume may have ended on unfavorable terms. If Lograsi discovers that the PCs killed Nicza, he is unwilling to negotiate with them here. In fact, he waits for them at this location for the sole purpose of destroying them and avenging his beloved, and as soon as the PCs make themselves known, he and the other generals attack—proceed with “An Unsuccessful Negotiation.”

Sorshen’s atrium has clearly seen better days. A landslide from the nearby mountainside has blocked off the balcony entrance completely, and rubble and wreckage are strewn across the gardens. Here, Belimarius’s trio of generals guard the Runewell of Lust and its anima focus while Belimarius herself completes her work inside the Eye of Desire. Among the generals, the PCs should already know Lograsi from their negotiations in the Velashu Uplands in the previous volume. Lograsi is accompanied now by two others: Nonumaliana (the jealous leader of the Knights of Malice, a sinspawn who would love nothing more than to see the runelord fall, provided she’s there to collect the spoils), and Azvoraug (the leader of Belimarius’s rune giants, to whom the runelord has promised a province in New Thassilon).

Once immaculately manicured, the winding gardens of Sorshen’s atrium are marred by evidence of the city’s destruction. Shattered chunks of stone now block off the balcony. At the center of the savaged garden stands a fountain that has completely ignored the surrounding damage. Three pitchers of water floating above the fountain continually empty into the well-like basin below without ever overflowing its rim. Despite the lack of damage to the fountain, flickers of unpleasant red energy shimmer around it.

The three pitchers floating above the fountain are a single anima focus—an artifact that maintains the link between the Universe and the Eye of Desire, and the Runewell of Lust within. A contingent of soldiers forms a tight perimeter around the anima focus near the center of the atrium, while the fountain crackles with angry, red energy behind them. Three formidable-looking generals stand in conference, watching the fountain’s waters for signs of change. One, a human woman who wears the emerald robes of a Runelord of Envy, looks impatient; she is planning for something and is eager to set this plan in motion. Another, a rune giant whose gigantic body is covered in tattoos, stands idle with his great spear to one side. The last of them is Lograsi—of the three, he looks the most at ease as he sips from a freshly poured glass of wine. The three are attended by a pair of elite shadow giants who serve the generals as bodyguards.

If the PCs arrive stealthily and none of the generals or shadow giants notice them, they can take advantage of this and launch a surprise attack instead of attempting to influence Lograsi. Proceed with “An Unsuccessful Negotiation” in this case.

Lograsi and the other generals are frustrated by how long Belimarius has spent locked away in the Runewell of Lust. They know nothing of how her efforts to harness the warshard have proceeded. They do not even know if Belimarius is alive, or if Sorshen left behind some trap that imprisoned or killed her. Though Lograsi isn’t surprised to see the party, the reception they receive depends on how they ended their previous interaction with him.

In this encounter, the PCs have a chance to interact with the generals and potentially influence them into leaving without a fight, granting them access to the runewell. This encounter uses the influence rules (GM Core 187). The generals all have reason to abandon Belimarius: Nonumaliana wants to kill the Runelord and usurp her title, and Azvoraug is no longer confident Belimarius will uphold their deal—but as long as Lograsi remains loyal to Belimarius, the other two generals won’t make any moves against her. If the PCs have a good rapport with Lograsi, however, they can convince him to walk away and surrender the Runewell of Lust, as well.

The encounter plays out over the span of 30 minutes, with each round taking 10 minutes each. The PCs thus have 3 rounds to complete this encounter and influence Lograsi before he becomes too frustrated to entertain their theatrics. If the PCs made an enemy of Lograsi the last time they met, he may only hear them out for two rounds, or he may refuse to hear anything they have to say. The other two generals hang back and watch, quietly, as this discussion plays out. Lograsi is slightly higher level than he was the last time the PCs spoke to him, but his personality remains the same.

Appearance Lograsi is a thin Azlanti man dressed in gray leather, with a neat goatee and captivating violet eyes. He cuts a quiet but tense argument with Belimarius's other generals short when the PCs arrive.

Ending the Negotiation.text:
Ending the Negotiation

The three generals remain in the gardens only to collect Belimarius’s spellbook if the PCs promised it to them. Otherwise, the generals leave without further incident, granting the PCs unrestricted access to the artifact.

Abundance Overflowing.name: Abundance Overflowing
Abundance Overflowing.text:
A1. Abundance Overflowing Severe 18

Once the generals are dealt with, the PCs can turn their attention to the fountain in the middle of the atrium.

Sparkling, clear water cascades down through an elegant three-tiered fountain. Three porcelain jugs float above the fountain, shimmering in the gentle light. They pour ever more water down into the pool, ensuring an endless flow of water to spill over the edges of each tier, forever. The pitchers crackle with magical potential realized, and an abundance of energy surges through the spring, ready to overflow.

Sorshen was the first runelord to create a runewell—a potent artifact designed to serve as a focal point for an extraplanar sanctuary, to absorb energy associated with a specific sin, and to perform other functions as well. She based this first runewell’s creation off of an even more ancient artifact called the Everdawn Pool, and once she finished it successfully, other runelords swiftly followed in her footsteps to create runewells of their own.

The runewell itself exists inside a demiplane, serving as an “eye” into which a runelord and their allies could retreat. Entry into these demiplanes was locked to the runewell’s “anchor” into the Universe—a linked artifact known as an anima focus. Each runelord’s anima focus had a unique appearance. In Sorshen’s case, her anima focus appears as three separate vases from which water eternally pours—the same three vases that float over the central pool here in her atrium. She transported it to Xin-Eurythnia soon after she woke, removing it from her previous sanctuary deep under the city of Korvosa.

An anima focus's only purpose is to maintain a link to its associated runewell demiplane, and to control the only entrance into and out from it; as such, an anima focus cannot be destroyed as long as its associated runewell exists. A PC who examines the fountain and its floating vases and succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:40|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[nature|dc:42|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic], @Check[occultism|dc:42|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic], or @Check[religion|dc:42|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check to Identify Magic realizes that the three vases are the anima focus for the Runewell of Lust, but also realizes that some force within the Eye of Desire is "holding the door shut"—this is the cause of the rippling red energy.

The three porcelain vessels float at different heights above the fountain, releasing everlasting supplies of sparkling, clean water into the (nonmagical) fountain below. The topmost pitcher depicts a fiery sun with fourteen rays; the middle pitcher is decorated with a field of pink and red lilies as well as a snake hidden among the flowers; and the bottom pitcher bears a wild, untamed lion—all classic symbols for lust and desire. These vessels are the gateway into Sorshen’s personal demiplane, and they cascade crackling arcane power down into the fountain alongside water, a clear indication that the sanctum has been breached and that the Eye of Desire is active and occupied.

Into the Eye.name: Into the Eye
Into the Eye.text:
Into the Eye

With the Runewell of Lust’s anima focus under the PCs’ control, they can freely access the Eye of Desire by taking three Interact actions to anoint themselves with water from the three pitchers in a specific sequence: first the middle pitcher bearing a field of lilies, second the bottom pitcher decorated with a roaring lion, and lastly the upper pitcher with the image of a burning sun. Once a PC takes these three actions in a single round, they are immediately transported into the Eye of Desire. If the PCs wish to coordinate their anointing, they can all do so simultaneously so they all appear in the demiplane at roughly the same time. Any PC who studied the anima focus and successfully Identified Magic understands how to activate it—if no PC is capable of this, though, the PCs can still discover this information by spending 8 hours Investigating the Blood Moon Palace.

The PCs can rest and prepare before entering the Eye of Desire. However, as time passes, Belimarius continues to work toward her ascension. If the PCs don't enter the Eye of Desire within 24 hours of reaching this point, Belimarius finishes her ritual, and the runelord of envy they'll face within will be a mythic threat. A PC can spend 10 minutes studying the red energy that surrounds the anima focus to gauge how long they have remaining before Belimarius becomes mythic by succeeding at a @Check[arcana|dc:38] or @Check[nature|dc:40], @Check[occultism|dc:40], or @Check[religion|dc:40] check.

When the PCs are ready, they can activate the anima focus and enter Sorshen’s demiplane, the Eye of Desire, where Runelord Belimarius waits.

Astelaur’s Room.name: Astelaur’s Room
Astelaur’s Room.text:
B15. Astelaur’s Room

A sixteen-foot-tall living tree grows from the ground and casts a gentle shade over the rest of this room under what appears to be an opening to a lovely summer sky above. Large shelves protrude from the walls, as though to offer elevated perches to a zoo animal, and a large, upholstered cushion has been pushed against the far wall. Toys and pillows cover the floor, including one particularly worn plush barely identifiable as a rabbit.

Hallowed Lynxes

Player characters (and perhaps players themselves) may expect to encounter a much more powerful feline creature in Sorshen’s domain—one of the notorious hallowed lynxes, powerful felines Sorshen created to serve as her pets and guardians early in her rule as Runelord of Lust. These creations skew toward cruel personalities, though, and no longer mesh well with Sorshen’s current worldview—yet she didn’t destroy those few hallowed lynxes that remained. Instead, she released them to other worlds, opting intend to keep “pets” like Astelaur who prefer her company because they like her, not because she compelled them.

A PC who asks Astelaur about hallowed lynxes gets little more than a scoffing laugh from the dweomercat, or perhaps a brief, “Obviously, her tastes have improved lately,” before he goes back to grooming himself.

The ceiling of this room is enchanted with a permanent 9th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.HBJPsonQnWcC3qdX]{Mirage} spell (DC 40 to disbelieve). Despite the presence of illusion magic, the tree is very real. Instead, the illusion illuminates the room with natural-feeling sunlight during the daytime, complete with a gentle breeze and outside smells.

Creature: This unusual room is home to Astelaur, an adult dweomercat Queen Sorshen keeps in her archives as a pet. Adult dweomercats are notoriously independent, but Astelaur enjoys Sorshen’s company, the meals that manifest in his room three times every day, and the seemingly limitless supply of minor magical items Sorshen provides for him to play with. With everything a fey cat could want, he has little reason to leave, and despite the fact that he’s free-willed and intelligent, he enjoys being kept as a “pet.” He’s relaxing on his bed when the PCs enter and addresses them in a voice that carries a feeling of cool disinterest: “I was wondering when adventurers would show up.”

Astelaur is not caged or confined to his room. He is free to prowl the palace as he pleases, though he hasn’t left the archives since the lockdown began. Belimarius didn’t breach the archives, and the cat doesn’t know what’s happened since Sorshen’s disappearance. He knows Sorshen hasn’t returned since the tremors began, that the palace was invaded, and that the palace’s lockdown defenses went into effect. Beyond that, he has little information and has been prepared to leave via translocation spell should an immediate threat present itself. Yet none ever did, and magical cats from the First World are still cats—as such, he has chosen to remain as long as possible in a place where his meals come unimpeded, waiting for Sorshen’s return or for a group of adventurers’ inevitable arrival.

As a resident of the Blood Moon Palace, Astelaur is capable of answering any questions the PCs might have about Sorshen, the palace, the archives, and Sorshen’s research prior to her disappearance. The trilingual dweomercat is fluent in Common, Fey, and Goblin, and his analyses and interpretations of recent events are astute and reliable. He is, however, still a cat, and the PCs need to find some form of tribute to offer in exchange for his time—delicious food, magical items to play with, or real good scratches. This includes any combination of alchemical foodstuffs worth a combined total of at least 15,000 gp (several deliveries of the food from the guest kitchen, area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02guestkitchen00]{B4}, work great here), an offering of magic items worth at least 30,000 gp, or scratches for 1 minute accompanied by a @Check[nature|dc:39] check to make sure they’re perfect. Once proper tribute is offered, Astelaur entertains questions until he grows bored (a duration determined by your whim); likely questions and his answers are as follows.

Where is Sorshen? “I rather think I should be the one asking you this. I’ve been here this whole time, after all, while you’ve been out there. Where is mother?”

Are you trapped here? “How silly. Why would mother trap me in my own home? I go out to visit other places sometimes, but my meals and my bunny are all here, so I don’t see why I should leave.”

How do we disable the palace’s lockdown defenses? “A mirror in mother’s office does that. The safe word is ‘crickets.’”

What are the clockwork soldiers? “They’re cooks and librarians. You didn’t fight them, did you? Mother doesn’t like it when I play with them, but she always has them repaired like new, so I don’t see why she should mind so much.”

What does Sorshen keep down here? “This is the archive wing. Mother’s office is here, as are her libraries and the art and heirloom archives. Down the hall are the guest rooms.”

May we use Sorshen’s archives?/Can we borrow some of the treasures here? “Do I look like a guard dog to you? Do what you want. If you do something mother doesn’t like, you’ll find out eventually, but I doubt she’d mind if you borrow anything here as long as you return what you borrow if she asks.”

Is it safe to rest here? “More or less. More when the place isn’t on lockdown. A few of the rooms here and there are... misbehaving... in mother’s absence, but others, like the sitting room, are always good places to rest. That room can even cure your aches and pains! I keep trying to get mother to fix my room up with that sort of thing, but she says that kind of magic doesn’t come naturally to her and that she had some old mage friend set it up for her a few years back.”

Can you come with us as we explore? “I could... but I won’t. I’m fine here, thanks!”

What was Sorshen’s last project/What has Sorshen been working on? “Mother has been greatly occupied by the last time she saw Alaznist, the old Runelord of Wrath. When she and mother woke from their slumbers, mother became trapped in a dead timeline before a group of heroes reached across time to find her. Those heroes fought Alaznist and seemed to set the timeline right, but how can one ever be certain of a nonlinear route through time? Mother fears that some past version of Alaznist, after she awoke but before her defeat, could still walk a path that crosses our futures.”

Xanderghul is back! “Oh. That’s... much worse than some past Alaznist coming back. I do hope you help mother out with that!”

In addition to answering questions and helping the PCs with their research, if one of the PCs succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:40|traits:action:make-an-impression|name:Make an Impression], @Check[diplomacy|dc:40|traits:action:make-an-impression|name:Make an Impression], or @Check[nature|dc:40|traits:action:make-an-impression|name:Make an Impression] check to make an impression on Astelaur, the dweomercat could reveal the auxiliary closets (@UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02auxiliaryclo00]{B2}) where the real Sorshen’s Scintillating Garment is hidden, as well as to a secret room (@UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02storageroom000]{B6a}) where the replica of Sorshen’s Sinuous Guisarme is stored.
