Sorshen’s Study.name: Sorshen’s Study
Sorshen’s Study.text:
B17. Sorshen’s Study

An elegant, masterfully wood-worked duskwood desk is the centerpiece of this cozy study. A chair with a high upholstered back sits behind the desk, and though it’s still stylish, the large claw marks marring its right side are barely hidden by the fox pelt draped over the chair’s left arm. Piles of books and papers cover nearly every surface of the study, migrating from the desk across the floor.

A pair of glass doors to the south lead into an adjoining sitting room that features a comfortable couch, chair, and a cork board filled with confusing notes. A mirror with an ornate gold frame hangs on the wall next to the sitting chair.

A PC who spends an hour Investigating this room and looking through the collected books, notes, and scrolls gains a good handle on various topics that have concerned Sorshen since her awakening several years ago. In particular, Sorshen’s notes concerning Alaznist’s plans, the minutia of chronomancy, and a personal account of her experience being trapped in an alternate timeline are contained on the cork board in her sitting room, in journals on her desk, and within crumpled notes scattered across the floor of her study.

The large mirror in the sitting room controls the lockdown. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[occultism|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check, or a @Check[nature|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[religion|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check to Identify Magic understands how to use this mirror, although a conversation with Astelaur can serve just as well. To bring the Blood Moon Palace out of lockdown, a PC needs only look into the mirror, succeed at a @Check[deception|dc:30|traits:action:impersonate,concentrate,exploration,manipulate,secret|name:Impersonate] check to Impersonate Sorshen's voice, and speak the her passcode, "crickets"—provided it's spoken in Thassilonian. They can learn the passcode from Astelaur (who likely forgets to note, initially, that the word must be spoken in Thassilonian). A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:50] check or @Check[thievery|dc:50] check can manipulate the mirror's arcane programming and change the passcode to something else.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.X0R9nXoLOPNFJahQ]{Scrolls} @UUID[Actor.1zcOvyOzNW1SmPM7]{Desk Drawer}
Many of the furnishings in this room, particularly the duskwood desk (which itself is worth 18,000 gp) are treasures, yet they’re far from portable and stealing them will certainly annoy Sorshen. That said, she’s less attached to many of the consumable magic items kept here and won’t begrudge the PCs using them in their efforts to stop Xanderghul, and she won’t ask for the return of any unused consumables when all is said and done. Among the scrolls the PCs can gather here are an 8th-rank scroll of banishing touch, scroll of disappearance, scroll of dominate, scroll of foresight, scroll of interplanar teleport, scroll of it is written, scroll of planar palace, scroll of part the mists to paradise, scroll of seize identity, scroll of umbral journey, and scroll of uncontrollable dance. One scroll in particular is kept in a bejeweled gold scroll tube (itself worth 4,000 gp): a scroll of summon Oliphaunt of Jandelay that could be of great use later in the chapter (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02conjuringthe00]{Here}). Other books found here contain the formulas for all of the rituals found in Player Core and Player Core 2.

One curious treasure found in a desk drawer is a mask of uncanny breath carved in the shape of a beautiful woman’s face. Sorshen kept this mask handy mostly for the bonus it grants to Occultism checks, but the PCs may find this mask to be a godsend when they explore the Prosperity Vault later in this chapter, where the air is bad to breathe.

Perhaps a greater treasure are the large number of spellbooks Sorshen keeps here. All of the arcane spells found in Player Core and Player Core 2 can be found in these books, along with the Thassilonian spells presented on page 119 of Lost Omens Rival Academies and any other spell of your choice (including most of the mythic spells found on pages 154–157 of War of Immortals). As Runelord of Lust, Sorshen’s training renders the use of spells to meddle with physical forms or invoke the void as anathema, and while these types of spells can be found in these spellbooks, they’re invariably in their own volumes and seem to be rarely, if ever, opened. While Sorshen doesn’t mind if a PC uses these books to learn spells, she won’t abide having these books taken or damaged and demands their return or replacement in such an event once the Adventure Path is over.

Reward: Grant the PCs 80 XP for lifting the lockdown.

Library Stacks.name: Library Stacks
Library Stacks.text:
B20. Library Stacks

This large, high-ceilinged chamber features dozens of shelves filled with a staggering collection of books. A few reading rooms and study desks to the west afford relaxing places to sit and read, but the bulk of this library is devoted to the storage and display of Sorshen’s private collection.

Sorshen’s literary collection includes magical textbooks, research, and spellbooks dating from ancient Thassilon to the present day. It contains history papers, collections of news articles, and accounts commissioned from adventurers describing creatures and places encountered in their travels. The archive also contains an abundant fiction section, including multiple bookcases of romance novels.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.G1vVKZCFuCP67UQK]{Library Stacks}
While there are no magical books or spell formulas kept here, this collection remains quite valuable and would be worth 40,000 gp if one could gather the books up and transport them to a buyer—a crass move sure to displease Sorshen. The books are more valuable to the PCs where they are, as a resource to draw upon while researching Jandelay and the Oliphaunt (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thewaytojand00]{Here}), and as general reference books. A PC who spends an hour referencing these books gains a +3 item bonus on checks made to Recall Knowledge using Arcana, Occultism, or any Lore connected to ancient or New Thassilon (@UUID[Item.4yarTTpX8eVk23ky]{Sorshen's Library Reference}).

The Way to Jandelay.name: The Way to Jandelay
The Way to Jandelay.text:
The Way to Jandelay

Once the PCs are comfortable with the archives and understand their layout and holdings, they’ll be able to use the materials here to begin working on researching the Oliphaunt, Jandelay, and where they should go from here. Lifting the lockdown isn’t required for them to start the process, but as long as the lockdown persists, periodic alarms, light fluctuations, and other minor inconveniences impart a –1 status penalty to all research checks (@UUID[Item.L7YMuLCHiNAdYfzh]{Archive Lockdown}). Alternatively, once the lockdown is lifted, the PCs can wind the clockwork servants found in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02guestkitchen00]{B4} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02privatearchi00]{B12}—winding all of these up grants the PCs a +2 status bonus to their research checks (@UUID[Item.lQpwm5EPDSMfP7Vi]{Clockwork Servants' Assistance} and @UUID[Item.7Q88f4BWbtTGSLrW]{Clockwork Librarians' Assistance}).

By this point, the PCs should already know that Xanderghul and Sorshen are in Jandelay, and that they need a means of reaching Jandelay to stop Xanderghul and rescue Sorshen. The information they possess about Jandelay’s nature may vary, but they know they can’t reach it via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport}, as they lack an appropriate planar key. Whether they hope to find a planar key to Jandelay among Sorshen’s collections or a ritual to summon the Oliphaunt like Belimarius had planned, their answers surely lie in Sorshen’s archives.

This section of the adventure uses the Research subsystem (GM Core 190) to track what the PCs learn. This is a 19th-level challenge, and accruing all the Research Points to rebuild Gimmel’s methods of calling on the Oliphaunt is a mythic deed.

Research Timing.name: Research Timing
Research Timing.text:
Research Timing

Regardless of the type of check the PCs make while researching, the materials the PCs are going through and the obscurity of their subject means that it takes, in effect, a day’s worth of work to attempt a single research check. Any PC who doesn’t participate in research can spend their time engaged in other downtime activities, of course, but doing so will slow the party’s progress toward their goal.

The PCs don’t have unlimited time to conduct this research, as every day they spend on this effort from this point forward until they reach Jandelay in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto]{Chapter 3} is more time for Xanderghul to gain an upper hand in his ongoing, epic struggle against Sorshen. As the PCs know from their Liralarue-sent dreams, they have approximately four weeks to reach the Heart of Jandelay and confront Xanderghul, and half that if they hope to have Sorshen help during their confrontation with Xanderghul in a significant way (they have even less time if they spent several days reaching this point of the story). Track the number of days remaining openly, so that the players can make more informed decisions about when they wish to stop pursuing research and move on to Spindlehorn.

Research Avenues.name: Research Avenues
Research Avenues.text:
Research Avenues

The PCs can choose one of the following avenues to spend their day researching the route to Jandelay. Thaumaturges can substitute Esoteric Lore and bards can substitute Bardic Lore for any other Lore check allowed in the following avenues.

Art and Relic Research (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02artworkstora00]{B18} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thassilonian00]{B21}): A PC can investigate Jandelay or the Oliphaunt.

  • Maximum RP 6
  • Research Checks @Check[art-lore|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], @Check[crafting|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], or @Check[perception|dc:44|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research].

Dream Discussions with Liralarue: Retreating into dreams can be a fruitful avenue of research.

  • Maximum RP 6
  • Research Checks @Check[diplomacy|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], @Check[occultism|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], or @Check[perception|dc:44|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research].

Library Stacks (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02librarystack00]{B20}): While some books form untidy piles on desks and chairs, others lie open.

  • Maximum RP 8
  • Research Checks @Check[library-lore|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], @Check[society|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], or @Check[perception|dc:44|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research].

Sorshen's Study (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02sorshensstud00]{B17}): A jumble of notes scattered across Sorshen's study can be arranged to build a timeline of Runelord Alaznist's activity and the alternate histories her time travel created.

  • Maximum RP 8
  • Research Checks @Check[academia-lore|dc:39|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], @Check[arcana|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research], or @Check[perception|dc:44|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research].

Recruiting Help: A PC can recruit help from knowledgeable allies like Aethusa, Ayavah, Galissodia, or Kandirvek to make these checks. The PC must work with the NPC during the research to direct their work and to take notes—this method doesn’t let a PC ignore the one-Research-check-per-day limitation. The PC can decide to let the NPC attempt the skill check themselves or to use their aid to gain a +2 circumstance bonus to their own check.

The Way to Jandelay Research 19

  • rare
  • arcane
  • mythic
  • occult

Research Checks art and relic research, dream discussions with Liralarue, library stacks, Sorshen's study

2 Research Points Gimmel, the third Runelord of Greed, conjured the Oliphaunt of Jandelay during a war between Thassilon and Azlant in –6301 ar. This conjuration into Golarion was unprecedented, for never before had the Oliphaunt been drawn to a world not facing imminent destruction. The method by which Runelord Gimmel accomplished this feat is believed to have been lost to time.

4 Research Points Jandelay is a demiplane located at the center of the Maelstrom, placing it at the metaphorical and literal center of the Great Beyond. Over the eons, Jandelay has slowly grown in size as bits and pieces of diverse realities have collected there into a patchwork menagerie—whenever an apocalyptic event destroys a city, country, planet, or plane, fragments of that place are absorbed by and preserved in Jandelay. The most legendary of this plane's inhabitants is the Oliphaunt of Jandelay. As difficult as it is to call this monster to another plane through magic (traditionally via an exceptionally rare 10th-rank mythic spell called @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Ywe64VHwcBOAWBtq]{Summon Oliphaunt of Jandelay} which, even then, only summons a brief manifestation of the creature that lasts for but a few moments), it's even more difficult to travel to Jandelay yourself. No planar keys, necessary for casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} spells, are known to currently exist for Jandelay.

6 Research Points Jandelay is maintained by strange beings called watchers, gargantuan one-eyed creatures who revere the Oliphaunt as a sacred herald of destruction and follow the beast across the planes wherever it rampages. The watchers are the ones responsible for collecting bits and pieces of the Universe's lost places, tucking them away in Jandelay to create a physical record of all that once was. (The PCs can learn more about watchers via a successful @Check[occultism|dc:49|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:49|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge).

8 Research Points Runelord Gimmel performed his ritual to conjure the Oliphaunt at a site known as Spindlehorn. Sorshen believes that this unprecedented event caused Golarion's fate to diverge into multiple timelines. In the current history of the world, the Oliphaunt drove back the armies of Azlant, rampaged across Thassilon, but ultimately returned to Jandelay. In another timeline, Alaznist pulled the Oliphaunt forward in time from –6301 ar and into modern-day Korvosa, where its rampage brought about the end of Varisia. In a third, the Oliphaunt tore across Thassilon unchecked, destroying the empire prematurely and pushing Haruka and Eurythnia into the sea.

10 Research Points Spindlehorn is famous among scholars of ancient Thassilon for its terrifying height, and for a piece of Thassilonian poetry inscribed at its base titled "The Epic of Jandelay" by modern translators. The tower was built by Runelord Gimmel in –6313 ar, supposedly so he could look the towering Oliphaunt in the eye when he conjured it. Truthfully, it was because Spindlehorn's location was the only place where such a powerful conjuration ritual could be performed at all.

12 Research Points Runelord Gimmel built Spindlehorn on the site of the Prosperity Vault, an underground arcane ritual chamber created shortly after Shalast's founding by the first Runelord of Greed, Kaladurnae. The Prosperity Vault's purpose was to ensure eternal wealth in Shalast's mines, transmuting ugly rock and mud into splendid, shimmering gold. This potent magical power served as a "seed" of sorts from which Gimmel raised Spindlehorn in a process that sealed off all entrances to the Prosperity Vault and focused its powerful magic outward to serve as a magical amplifier for the casting of world-piercing rituals.

14 Research Points When the Oliphaunt abandoned Golarion after Gimmel's conjuration ended, it left something terrible behind—an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} planted deep in the ground, as a promise of future devastation. If the Oliphaunt can leave something behind on Golarion, surely it can also bring something back during its return to Jandelay, providing a theoretical way to travel to the notoriously inaccessible plane. No one has ever recovered this apocalypse seed, if indeed it even exists, as it's most likely buried deep under Spindlehorn's roots.

16 Research Points While Golarion's Spindlehorn is a tremendous needle tower that pierces the sky, its mirror in the Netherworld is a terrible pit cutting deep into the ground. By using a planar travel spell like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport}, a traveler can enter the Netherworld, descend the pit, and then re-emerge on Golarion two-thousand feet beneath the surface inside the buried caverns of the long-sealed Prosperity Vault. It's likely here, at the point Gimmel used to trigger the growth of Spindlehorn, that the Oliphaunt's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} is located.

18 Research Points Ancient sources believe it was Lissala, the Thassilonian rune goddess, who led Gimmel to the discovery of Jandelay and his eventual success in conjuring the Oliphaunt to Golarion. Gimmel used secret runes revealed to him by the goddess to reach into Jandelay, then twisted those runes to conjure instead of merely watch. The PCs learn of these long-lost runes, which they can use alongside an object belonging to the Oliphaunt (like the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed}, for example) to replicate Gimmel's conjuration ritual. At this level of research, the PCs realize they know everything that's needed to conjure the Oliphaunt at Spindlehorn long enough to clamber onto the immense beast and ride it back to Jandelay, just as Runelord Belimarius had hoped to do before she was defeated. The PCs can leave for Spindlehorn at once, but if they take a more time to research, they'll gain additional advantages during the challenges to come.

20 Research Points Sorshen has devoted significant research to untangling what would happen if she encountered an alternate version of herself from another timeline. She's skeptical the multiverse would allow two versions of one person to exist simultaneously and worries she would be forced to kill the other version of herself, or else both would surely perish. These notes grant the PCs an advantage when they roll for initiative in the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto.JournalEntryPage.03spindlehorns00]{Spindlehorn’s Collapse} encounter, allowing them to roll twice and take the better result. This is a fortune effect.

22 Research Points When the Oliphaunt rampaged across Varisia to sunder the Azlanti army, it killed a linnorm in the Wyvern Mountains. Unable to lay its curse upon the Oliphaunt, this linnorm cursed Spindlehorn in its stead, and its unquiet spirit is said to haunt the site to this day. This information grants the PCs a +2 circumstance bonus on Will saves to resist Lythazossa's Vestige of an Ancient Curse (@UUID[Item.wPaT2AMGDP7nUilL]{Linnorm's Curse Foreknowledge}).

24 Research Points Jandelay is a timeless demiplane. The preserved apocalypses each maintain the gravity and structural integrity of the plane they were collected from, and they're sorted into chronological regions according to their date of collection. This information grants the PCs a +3 circumstance bonus to checks made to navigate Jandelay once they arrive there (@UUID[Item.Y9zAFrADez9Tzpun]{Jandelay Navigator}).

26 Research Points The PCs retrace Gimmel's ancient steps in creating their ritual, discovering the same subtle manipulations of arcane runes he did. This information grants the PCs a +2 status bonus to all skill checks made to overcome obstacles when they Conjure the Oliphaunt (@UUID[Item.qsxP0nhasgDfcNRI]{Gimmel's Arcane Insight}).

Rewards: Grant the PCs 10 XP for each new tier of Research Points they reach, for a total reward of 130 XP if they reach at least 26 Research Points.

Reaching 18 Research Points and discovering Lissala’s lost runes in 9 days or less is a Mythic deed and earns each PC 3 Mythic Points.

Spindlehorn.name: Spindlehorn
Spindlehorn.text:
Spindlehorn

Armed with a ritual to summon the Oliphaunt, the time has come for the PCs to travel to Spindlehorn, call the herald of the apocalypse, and break into Jandelay. Traveling across Varisia to Spindlehorn is a trivial task for a group of powerful heroes like the PCs. Kandirvek is happy to fly them on his back, or spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U0hL0LLaprcnAyzC]{Migration} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} allow the PCs to cross great distances in a short time. However the PCs decide to travel, they should reach Spindlehorn without incident or difficulty, but the time it takes to cover the 560 miles between Xin-Eurythnia and Spindlehorn could affect the countdown until Xanderghul’s triumph.

Allow the players to check in with their Eurythnian allies for help connecting various pieces of information or resolving any lingering questions they might have. Prompt them to finish any downtime actions they want to complete, such as retraining or learning new spells. Though the people of Xin-Eurythnia have only just started the task of rebuilding, with the refugees from Vekker’s Crossing only now beginning the long trek back home, the PCs can potentially travel to larger cities to make final purchases before continuing the adventure.

Nether Spindlehorn.text:
Nether Spindlehorn Moderate 19

Traveling through the Netherworld with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} allows the PCs to cover vast distances quickly. Normally, doing so over long distances results in emerging back into Golarion within a mile of the destination, but in this case, the pit revealed to be Nether Spindlehorn and its relatively short descent of 200 feet (which equates to traveling 2,000 feet down on Golarion) allows the PCs to emerge into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02uppertower0000]{C1} with ease once they reach the pit floor.

When the PCs arrive at the Nether Spindlehorn, read or paraphrase the following.

A dark gray sky looms oppressively, like a ceiling covering the world that feels too low. The ground, made of rough gray stone with grooves that seem to trip with every step, stretches out in every direction including north. Leafless trees grow with empty branches striving up and outward. The clear waters of the Storval Deep are gone, here, replaced with a graveyard of ash and soot and bone. On the horizon at the far side of the deep, mountains pierce the sky, and the border between the two grows indistinct, like the shimmer of a mirage. An iron gate hangs open at the mouth of a deep and terrible pit. It sways in a breeze that can’t be felt, opening and closing in perfect, slow silence. The chasm cuts deep into the ground; bottomless, or something close to it. There is no light within.

Since the PCs are only partially in the Netherworld when they cast umbral journey, they need not worry about the stranger conditions of that plane, yet as they begin their descent, they’re nevertheless confronted by one of the Netherworld’s most dangerous denizens.

Nether Spindlehorn Moderate 19

@UUID[Actor.mROrw2CpS0wdv7pO]{Elite Urveths (2)}

Creatures: Two immense, wormlike undead—elite urveths—have claimed Nether Spindlehorn as their domain, attracted by the destructive energy echoing from the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} across the planes. Sensing a nearby source of vitality, the two urveths become enraged and attack as soon as the PCs begin their descent, bursting from walls of the shaft.
Nether Spindlehorn.name: Nether Spindlehorn

The Prosperity Vault.name: The Prosperity Vault
The Prosperity Vault.text:
The Prosperity Vault

When Runelord Kaladurnae took control of the nation of Shalast, he did so for the deep and plentiful deposits of gold, quartz, and other precious minerals in the Kodar and Wyvern Mountains. As he worked his followers in those mines and hoarded the great wealth they produced, he became increasingly frustrated by the conviction that, no matter how hard he worked his people, there could be ways of plundering the riches of the deep even faster. Compelled by his growing need for more wealth, Kaladurnae created a powerful ritual to fuel his insatiable greed. He captured the lampad nymph queens of Shalast’s greatest mountains and bound them together in his Prosperity Vault, an arcane prison that transmuted rock, stone, and mud into endless veins of gold.

Almost three centuries later, when Gimmel sought to conjure the Oliphaunt to destroy Azlant’s invading armies, he did so on the site of the Prosperity Vault, stealing its power to grow Spindlehorn from its heart and transform it into an amplifier for his conjuration ritual. Since its construction in –6313 AR, Spindlehorn has endured and the Prosperity Vault beneath it has fallen into obscurity. In the centuries that followed, the lampad queens remained imprisoned within the vault, polluted by its greed, while the golden ore the Prosperity Vault was created to grow inside Shalast’s mountains instead bloomed within the vault itself.

More recently, elemental creatures became attracted to the Prosperity Vault for the ample and eternal source of gold within it. The vault’s caverns have been overrun by these creatures, the most prominent of which are powerful variant oregorgers known as goldgorgers. Transformed by their time away from the Plane of Metal and thousands of years of only eating gold, the goldgorgers are smaller and narrower than their oregorger kin on the Plane of Metal, but the tremendous arcane power of their new home has made them exceptionally dangerous. The goldgorgers nest across the vault and in burrows tunneled between the walls. If the gold did not grow forever, creating endless new supports to prop up the deteriorating ceiling, these burrows would have surely collapsed the vault.

Prosperity Vault Features.name: Prosperity Vault Features
Prosperity Vault Features.text:
Prosperity Vault Features

The Prosperity Vault contains three levels, but the uppermost two (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02uppertower0000]{C1} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02lowertower0000]{C2}) consist of single chambers, while the third is a mix of worked stone rooms, many of which shifted apart from their original positioning during the formation of Spindlehorn and the more recent caverns and tunnels burrowed by goldgorgers. Ceilings are 10 feet high in most rooms, while the connecting corridors are roughly oval in cross-section with 7-foot-high ceilings. Unless otherwise noted, the rooms are unlit.

One particularly complex element the PCs must contend with is the stagnancy of the air within the Prosperity Vault. After centuries of being sealed off from the world and inhabited only by undead and elementals, the air in the vault is of exceptionally poor quality. For every 10 minutes of breathing this stagnant air, a PC must succeed at a DC 34 Fortitude save to resist becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1}. A creature that’s already enfeebled who fails this save instead has their enfeebled condition increase by 1, to a maximum of enfeebled 6. A creature who remains in the vault for more than an hour automatically becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} by the bad air. Short-lived solutions to the lack of air (such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.W69zswpj0Trdy5rj]{Air Bubble}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1K6AYGisvo9gqdhs]{Elemental Form}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XS7Wyh5YC0NWeWyB]{Fiery Body}) won’t be very helpful in combating this complication. A PC with the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.aJUXbe9HJVvv0Mxa]{Breath Control} feat only has to make the @Check[fortitude|dc:30] save once every 4 hours, while items like a mask of uncanny breath (such as the one found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02sorshensstud00]{B17}) or bottled air can fully protect the PCs in this situation. Players are likely to come up with other creative solutions, particularly involving the use of powerful or mythic magic, and in cases like this, you should reward their creativity by allowing them a win against this inconvenience.

When the PCs return to Golarion after traversing the Netherworld, they appear in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02uppertower0000]{C1}.

Lower Tower.name: Lower Tower
Lower Tower.text:
C2. Lower Tower

This room’s walls and statues have poorly withstood the test of time. A central spiral staircase leads up through a hole in the ceiling thirty feet above, while to the south, two flights of stairs wind ever downward. A jagged oval hole has been dug into the stone floor near the western stairs.

This room is similar in decor to the chamber above it, save that it's a @Check[art-lore|dc:41|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[arcana|dc:43|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge. On a success, the PCs can piece together the story told by these mural fragments, which depict Runelord Kaladurnae as he constructed the Prosperity Vault. He used the power of captured lampad nymph queens as a source for the powerful magic he wove to manifest numerous artificial veins of gold through the roots of the Wyvern Mountains.

The spiral stairs lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02uppertower0000]{C1}, while the southern stairs both lead down another 100 feet to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02vaultthresho00]{C3}. The hole nearby drops straight down the same distance to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02goldgorgerbu00]{C4a} in the goldgorger tunnels.

Goldgorger Burrows.name: Goldgorger Burrows
Goldgorger Burrows.text:
C4. Goldgorger Burrows Moderate 19

Creatures: At one point, this area was infested by a dozen goldgorgers, but today, only four of these dangerous elementals remain active in the Prosperity Vault. Centuries of feeding on the gold generated by the Heart of Greed have made these goldgorgers almost content, and they’ve been happy to slumber in a state of semi-hibernation. The “seed veins” of gold plugging the hallways leading into the Heart of Greed aren’t palatable to the goldgorgers, but each external area where the gold blocks a tunnel is marred by scratches and gouges left behind by “tastes” the goldgorgers took. The winding burrows they’ve dug in pursuit of gold grown by these seed veins have resulted in the maze of rounded tunnels shown on the map. Other tunnels leading deeper into the surrounding mountains were destroyed when Runelord Gimmel raised Spindlehorn, but the goldgorgers remain content as they are.

C4. Goldgorger Burrows Moderate 19

@UUID[Actor.DCNGiNJrMZMu1PuQ]{Goldgorgers (4)}

At least, until they catch wind of intruders. If the PCs wish to avoid attracting their attention, they must proceed through these tunnels quietly. The four goldgorgers are currently located in the four caves marked C4a, and whenever the PCs come within 60 feet of one of these caves (or as soon as they make particularly loud noises anywhere in the Prosperity Vault), these four creatures quickly come to investigate and attack on sight. A goldgorger flees if reduced to fewer than 40 Hit Points.

Heart of Greed.name: Heart of Greed
Heart of Greed.text:
C6. Heart of Greed Severe 19

The floor and ceiling of this chamber are made of polished black marble, while the walls themselves are solid gold, smooth and shiny in a few places, but mostly jagged and rough, as if the gold had been gouged or scraped over eons. In the middle of the room, a twenty-foot-diameter rune inlaid with gold decorates the floor, while above, the ceiling rises to a thirty-foot-high dome decorated with murals of a green-robed man surrounded by riches. Finally, to the southwest, a strange four-foot-wide mass of what appears to be a distorted bulb of bone is embedded in the floor—a weird centerpiece to the treasure scattered about nearby.

The green robed man depicted in the mural above is Runelord Kaladurnae, while the “bone cyst” is what the PCs seek—the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} left eons ago by the Oliphaunt of Jandelay. The solid masses of jagged gold that clog what were once seven entrances to this chamber grew here over the eons, but unlike the veins of gold the Prosperity Vault created elsewhere, the gold here can only exist in this space, maintained by the vault’s lingering power. Bits broken off (or eaten by goldgorgers) fade away swiftly, leaving nothing in the hand (or belly) to sell (or digest). The harvested sections simply regrow in a slightly different jagged shape on the wall.

Creatures: The Prosperity Vault is haunted by two restless spirits. One manifests as a haunt that was once the raw magic power of the vault, but the other is the ghost of Lythazossa, the Blighted Breath, a cairn Linnorm who dwelt in these caverns for a time after the runelords of greed had let the Prosperity Vault go fallow. She became collateral damage when Runelord Gimmel conjured the Oliphaunt and was crushed under the behemoth’s foot, yet rather than curse the Oliphaunt with her power, the linnorm’s soul lingered here, clinging to the fragment the Oliphaunt left behind. This dangerous ghost now sees the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} as the cause of its torment but also as the only thing keeping her from “dying.” She doesn’t quite realize she’s been dead for centuries.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.bWvbAaWPwS7xzaag.PlaylistSound.bLeEF0Dl9FPflo39]{Echoes of the End}

C6. Heart of Greed Severe 19

@UUID[Actor.nbhw4vqFCrdwbpqJ]{Lythazossa} @UUID[Actor.b0eDUfEYDSUFvHpW]{Echoes of the End}

While Lythazossa remains as immense as she was in life, as a ghost, her incorporeal body moves in and out of the chamber walls with ease. When the PCs first enter, Lythazossa’s face barely protrudes from the gold wall near the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed}, and as soon as she spots the intruders, she slithers out into the room to attack, rolling Stealth for initiative. While parts of her immense ghostly shape may brush through the walls now and then, as long as the majority of the linnorm ghost is outside the walls, she avoids being slowed and gains no significant advantages. This changes if the PCs flee and she pursues; as long as she slithers through the walls to chase them down the narrow tunnels (narrow to her, at least), she’s @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} 1, although she can make up for this by simply moving through walls to try to cut off fleeing PCs. Lythazossa fights until destroyed and rejuvenates unless the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} is taken from the Prosperity Vault. Once the seed is removed, her soul finally moves on to the afterlife.

Hazard: The magic that created the Prosperity Vault’s gold was forever distorted by Runelord Gimmel’s formation of Spindlehorn. When this same wild arcane energy scraped against the Oliphaunt’s immense soul during the mythic creature’s brief passage through the area, fragments of its spiritual essence flaked off and formed a devastating haunt. Note that until this haunt is disabled, the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} cannot be moved or taken from this place.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.Dp8fcSZKsm5z7VJ4]{Hoard}
Lythazossa has been dead a long time, but ironically, no agents of the runelords of greed ever bothered to seek out her hoard—a mass of treasure is strewn about the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed}, all of which have been kept safe from goldgorgers by the ghost and haunt in this room. The additional treasures include 34,000 gp in ancient coins and jewelry, a suit of +3 major resilient high-grade elven chain, a +3 major striking greater astral greater extending grievous high-grade adamantine scythe, a supreme sturdy shield, a wand of unfathomable song, a shadowmist cape, and a zealot staff.

Back to the Surface.name: Back to the Surface
Back to the Surface.text:
Back to the Surface

Once the PCs have recovered the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed}, they’ve got all they need and can return to the surface of Golarion. While there remains no physical route back to the surface world, any teleportation effect with a range of over 2,200 feet allows for an easy return to the Spindlehorn’s base—a 5th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{Translocate} spell is best suited here, but @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.69L70wKfGDY66Mk9]{Teleport} works just as well (although the PCs might need to make a short walk along the shore of the Storval Deep to return to Spindlehorn). @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} lets the PCs climb the pit back up to the surface. If the PCs are truly stuck, then the next time they dream, @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06campaignrole02]{Liralarue} can warp reality so that they awaken on the surface, although this manipulation of reality taxes her so that she can no longer provide assistance to the party for the remainder of the chapter.

Nymph Prisons.text:
C5. Nymph Prisons Moderate 19

This cubical chamber is twenty-five feet in every direction. The walls are made of black marble, with each surface etched with dense, spiky runes—thousands of them, perhaps tens of thousands in all. The only exception is a roughly five-foot-diameter circle of bare stone in the middle of the floor.

When Runelord Gimmel raised Spindlehorn from the Prosperity Vault’s heart, much of the complex was destroyed, and centuries of goldgorger burrowing hasn’t helped matters. As a result, two of these chambers to the west have partially collapsed and are now empty, their one-time prisoners having escaped long ago.

Creatures: In each area marked as C5a, a sole occupant remains—a beautiful woman with gold veins weeping as she sits in the center of the room, within the rune-free patch on the floor. Each of these are one of the four surviving lampad queens whom Runelord Kaladurnae imprisoned millennia ago to channel the Prosperity Vault’s magic power. Their centuries of imprisonment have cause tumors and crusts of gold to grow from their bodies and have unfortunately shattered their minds.

C5. Nymph Prisons Moderate 19

@UUID[Actor.iPrq6hyW9ztjLE8J]{Imprisoned Lampads (4)} @UUID[Actor.fsuNT47o8NZogKpi]{Erzgeists (2)}

While each lampad is in her prison, she can take no actions. As such, the lampad queens aren’t significant threats here—instead, the danger comes from two vengeful undead spirits known as erzgeists. They’ve long lingered in the area, feeding off of the lampads’ torment even as they bristle for a chance to attack intruders. (The goldgorgers learned to move swiftly through these chambers as a result.)

The first time the PCs enter one of these rooms, they’re attacked by the two erzgeists, who fight until destroyed and pursue fleeing PCs relentlessly through the Prosperity Vault.

Any attempt to physically move the lampad from her spot in the middle of the room fails as long as she lives—or as long as the binding runes on the walls remain intact. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:41] or @Check[thievery|dc:44] check made as a two-action activity can disable the magic of the runes, allowing the lampad to go free. Physically destroying every rune would take hours, but this also does the trick. At your discretion, spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.McnPlLFvKtQVXNcG]{Shape Stone} or the like can speed this up quickly (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.x7SPrsRxGb2Vy2nu]{Earthquake} works as well but is a dangerous spell to cast in an underground area).

Reward: Grant the PCs 20 XP for each lampad queen they rescue. In addition, a rescued lampad queen rewards one PC with her Inspiration in the form of a small nodule of gold broken off from her body.

What Golarion Deserves.text:
What Golarion Deserves

One moment, the PCs are clinging to the Oliphaunt’s back while they hurtle through dense clouds of planetary and societal debris from countless destroyed worlds, and the next, they’re watching the Oliphaunt hurtle away like a comet, while the PCs suddenly find themselves adrift amid the fragments of worlds too minor to even deserve a place among the collected dead realities that form the Apocalypse Archive.

The PCs now stand atop a fragment of stone they recognize as an immense carved eye—perhaps a fragment from Karzoug’s crumbled face from Mhar Massif, although it seems smaller here. The eye floats amid several other fragments of stone architecture amid a swirling backdrop of churning muted colors as bits and pieces of realty are slowly eroded away, erased from existence. Floating in the air before them is a figure that has vexed and tormented them since the start of the campaign—the Ashen Man.

Their foe has watched their progress against Xanderghul, and at times intervened to make his frustrations known, but this time, the Ashen Man steps forward in person—a risk, and one perhaps he should have taken when the PCs were less powerful, yet one in his arrogance he never thought he’d have to take in the first place. By finding a way into Jandelay, they’ve forced this confrontation, and as the Ashen Man greets the PCs, there’s a cadence to his raspy voice that carries a bit of disappointment, as one might hear in the voice of a parent who has learned their child has failed the family legacy in some horrific and irreparable manner.

If the PCs immediately attack the Ashen Man, they’ll face a more-than Extreme 19 encounter, as the Ashen Man is a level 23 foe. Before they attack, the Ashen Man holds up a hand and says, “Before you resort to violence, a moment of your time? If only to extend your lives a few seconds more?” If the PCs persist, proceed with @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02fightingforg00]{Fighting for Golarion}.

This encounter adapts the Influence subsystem (GM Core 187), as the PCs debate the fate of Golarion itself with the Ashen Man: if it has a right to exist or if the time has finally come to let it go. As the conversation begins, the PCs see other entities take an interest in the discussion—two @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06ancientone0000]{Ancient Ones} and a @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06watcher0000000]{Watcher} from Jandelay alike lurk nearby, quietly observing what the PCs have to say.

Each round of the debate consumes 10 minutes in the game, during which, each PC can attempt to Discover or Influence the Ashen Man to earn Influence Points. At the start of each round, the Ashen Man poses a question as to the nature of Golarion’s right to exist. This should focus the discussion’s topic for that round, give PCs a special check they can make to Discover, and introduce a skill the PCs can use to Influence that they can automatically pursue without having to Discover it in the first place.

Topics for the four rounds of debate are listed after the Influence stat block. The “Additional Influence” entry for each of these rounds’ topics should be made apparent to the PCs as the round begins without the need for a Discovery check to learn about them. Once the PCs reach the end of the fourth round, what happens next depends on how many @UUID[Item.izggxVEKvCz9L4JB]{Influence Points} they’ve accumulated.

Ashen Man Influence 23

  • Large
  • Aberration
  • Mythic
  • Time

Supernatural agent of entropy

Perception +40

Will +40; mythic resilience (War of Immortals 168)

Discovery @Check[dimension-of-time-lore|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[occultism|dc:42|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[perception|dc:45|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover]

Influence Skills @Check[diplomacy|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to address a topic with empathy and respect), @Check[deception|dc:42|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to address a topic manipulatively or with trickery), @Check[intimidation|dc:45|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to address a topic with huge emotions and threats)

Influence 4 The ancient ones accompanying the Ashen Man are convinced to depart, entirely removing the first combat encounter. The PCs each earn 1 Mythic Point.

Influence 6 The watcher accompanying the Ashen Man is convinced to depart, entirely removing the second combat encounter. The PCs each earn 1 Mythic Point.

Influence 8 The Ashen Man's resolve is shaken. He begins his fight against the PCs @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}. The PCs each earn 1 Mythic Point.

Influence 10 The Ashen Man fully concedes to Golarion's right to exist. He does not fight the PCs; skip Fighting for Golarion entirely and go on to @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02theashenmans00]{The Ashen Man’s Fate}.

Resistances Though the Ashen Man believes Golarion's destruction is inevitable, he has little patience for the subject of destiny. He is quick to dismiss pleas involving it as irrelevant rather than hearing them out. PCs who engage with or evoke the idea of a predestined future suffer a –2 circumstance penalty on checks to Influence the Ashen Man during that check.

Weaknesses The Ashen Man believes that entropy and destruction are the natural consequence of time's progression and the purpose of the multiverse, but he is also receptive toward nihilistic philosophies. These positions are incompatible: if there is no purpose, the purpose cannot be destruction. A PC who gently unravels this cognitive dissonance or who frames their arguments around nihilistic beliefs such as the absence of a single, universal meaning of life, receives a +2 circumstance bonus to Influence the Ashen Man with any Charisma-based check.

Penalty If the party doesn't reach 10 influence points at the end of 4 rounds, the Ashen Man grows tired of their theatrics—proceed with Fighting for Golarion.

Round 1 Topic—Inevitability

Additional Influence @Check[lore|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (any), @Check[performance|dc:42|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

The Ashen Man argues the end is inevitable; when you know you will one day die, what is the purpose of living at all? The PCs can refute this by presenting their own reasons for living, such as their passions, love for their families, or their faith, using any Lore skills they possess, or they can use Performance to present the Ashen Man with a captivating art piece that makes their desired point.

Round 2 Topic—Predestination

Additional Influence @Check[society|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[perception|dc:42|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

The Ashen Man argues the end is predestined; the Oliphaunt was called to Golarion by the Thassilonians and then again by the PCs. Their world is owed to Jandelay and what is owed must be paid. The PCs can argue against giving up on your community even when the odds seem overwhelming with a Society check, or they can perceive a logical error in the Ashen Man's claim with a Perception check and use this to refute him.

Round 3 Topic—One of Many Ends

Additional Influence @Check[athletics|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[medicine|dc:42|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

A great meteorite crashes into the ground, hurling the PCs into the unknown depths of the mindscape. As the world ends around them, the PCs show the Ashen Man firsthand they possess the tenacity to survive, no matter the circumstances, either by using Athletics to prove their physical tenacity or Medicine to show how they would care for those less fortunate.

Round 4 Topic—Nihilism

Additional Influence @Check[religion|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[occultism|dc:42|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

The Ashen Man argues all life is meaningless; the PCs live and fight for nothing, they and their deeds will all be forgotten, and nothing of lasting consequence will ever be born of their choices. Without divine power, mortals can never change the nature of the multiverse. The PCs can refute the Ashen Man's premise that the gods wield unlimited power over mortals with a Religion check, or they can make an Occultism check to argue that the multiverse's nature doesn't need to change for Golarion to have a place within it.

Fighting for Golarion.name: Fighting for Golarion
Fighting for Golarion.text:
Fighting for Golarion

At the end of the fourth round, if the PCs haven’t reached 10 Influence Points with the Ashen Man, he impatiently waves aside any further attempts to continue the discussion, saying, “The time for words is over. It has been for years. You will now become the first victims of your world’s end.”

Fighting for Golarion Severe to Extreme 19

@UUID[Actor.4SNNhLwBL1IaEeEE]{Ancient Ones (2)} @UUID[Actor.ksQawDyffQxDRuS4]{Watcher} @UUID[Actor.MqmvAuR03VzqZBXu]{The Ashen Man}

This fight potentially has three back-to-back combats. The first fight pits them against two ancient ones (a Severe 19 encounter). In the second fight, they face a single watcher (also a Severe 19 encounter). The final fight is against the Ashen Man himself, an Extreme 19 encounter. The PCs have no time to rest or recover between fights. Noncombatants whose battle hasn’t yet started remain at the edges of the area, watching—if they’re targeted at any time by the PCs, that foe joins the current battle early, which can swiftly push things even beyond extreme for the PCs. If you’re feeling generous, award XP after each fight, and if the PCs earn enough to level up, allow them to do so (although this won’t allow them to regain expended resources or Hit Points), but in the end these three back to back fights aren’t the best resolution.

If the PCs earned at least 4 Influence points, the ancient ones do not attack and instead leave the area. Likewise, if they earned at least 6 Influence points, the PCs won’t have to fight the watcher.

Unless the PCs earned 10 Influence points, they must at least fight the Ashen Man. In this case, he fights to the death, not believing even until the last that the PCs have a chance of killing him.

Advocating for Golarion.name: Advocating for Golarion
Advocating for Golarion.text:
Advocating for Golarion

Once combat begins, there’s still a chance, however small, for the PCs to earn some last-minute Influence points. Though the Ashen Man has lost interest in debating the PCs, they can continue to present their case to him and accumulate Influence Points by using the following Advocate for Golarion activity. Each time the PCs reach a new Influence threshold, the encounter is adjusted according to the threshold reached (10 Influence Points: the ancient ones surrender and leave the combat; 14 Influence Points: the watcher surrenders and leaves the combat; 18 Influence Points: the Ashen Man surrenders).

Advocate for Golarion 2

  • Auditory
  • Concentrate
  • Emotion
  • Linguistic
  • Mental

You aren't finished, and the Ashen Man will hear everything you've got to say. Attempt a Diplomacy check against the Ashen Man's Will DC.

Critical Success Add 2 Influence points to the total you reached in the Ashen Man influence encounter. Compare this new total against that influence encounter's influence thresholds—if this results in a creature leaving the battle that's currently in play, they do so—using their best option to retreat from battle. The next combat begins immediately.

Success As critical success, but add only 1 Influence point.

Critical Failure The Ashen Man has lost interest in you, and you can no longer Advocate for Golarion.

The Ashen Man’s Fate.name: The Ashen Man’s Fate
The Ashen Man’s Fate.text:
The Ashen Man’s Fate

The Ashen Man’s defeat should be presented as a big deal, with the PCs getting a choice to grant him mercy and let him escape or to finish him off. Those choices will have implications on @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto]{Chapter 3}—if they let him escape, he becomes a resource they can call upon to aid them in their final fight against Xanderghul, now convinced that their world should be allowed to exist. If they instead decide to finish him off, they can perhaps rest easier at night knowing one of the greatest threats to face Golarion has been defeated.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.nKbyt1aBkmkWYQ49]{Fragments of Power}
Regardless of the Ashen Man’s fate, Jandelay itself takes note of the PCs’ power, and fragments of potent magic the Apocalypse Archive had drawn from ancient, long-forgotten worlds are drawn to the PCs like the proverbial moths to flames. These fragments of power arch toward each PC from that patchwork worlds looming in the distance, bathing each character in mythic power that settles into a suit of armor or a weapon worn or carried by that PC. Each PC has a choice at this point—they can immediately apply a mythic armor potency rune to a suit of armor or a mythic weapon potency to a weapon. (They cannot choose mythic resilient or mythic striking runes at this time, but that option will come soon enough in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto]{Chapter 3}).

Rewards: At the end of this encounter, whether the PCs succeeded in talking down the Ashen Man or beat him in battle, grant each PC 3 Mythic Points for this legendary deed. In addition, grant the PCs experience points for both ancient ones, the watcher, and the Ashen Man as if they’d defeated them all in combat, even if they talked some or all of them down—this should be more than enough to propel the PCs into 20th level.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.rcnMG9SHg5flRm21]{Ride The Oliphaunt}

In any event, once this has all resolved, and perhaps just as the PCs are trying to decide on how best they might continue the remaining potentially millions of miles onward to the patchwork world of Jandelay, reality ripples and changes again, revealing that all of this was a mindscape created by the Ashen Man. While time seemed to progress normally for the PCs, in truth, their trip through the Great Beyond all took place in the space between two seconds. They still stand atop the Oliphaunt of Jandelay, and their destination lies only a few moments ahead of them.

Call to Oblivion.name: Call to Oblivion
Call to Oblivion.text:
Chapter 2: Call to Oblivion

Rebuilding Xin-Eurythnia

While the PCs can leave the restoration of Xin-Eurythnia entirely to NPCs like Ayavah and Galissodia, they may also wish to lend their considerable power to the effort while researching the Oliphaunt in the Blood Moon Palace. Because the PCs are widely recognized as Xin-Eurythnia’s saviors, they can easily quash petty power struggles and keep the work on track by organizing repairs or naming an interim leader. They may even wish to help with the reconstruction of the city personally. More advice on how the PCs can help rebuild the city is covered in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22104beyond]{Beyond the Campaign}.

As news of Belimarius’s defeat spreads, the last of the rune giants withdraw with General Azvoraug, and the remaining soldiers follow General Lograsi and General Nonumaliana back to Xin-Edasseril. The PCs have succeeded at liberating the ruins of Xin-Eurythnia, and while there’s still much work ahead before the city is livable again, the heroes’ most pressing concern is stopping Xanderghul and the Ashen Man.

By this time, the PCs should know that Xanderghul and Sorshen are on Jandelay. They’ve likely heard the Oliphaunt’s name and may even have learned Belimarius’s plan to reach Jandelay by summoning the Oliphaunt and riding it through the planes. Though the PCs are powerful heroes and undoubtably have access to spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport}, without a planar key tuned to the demiplane, Jandelay remains inaccessible by teleportation. If the PCs don’t consider riding the Oliphaunt themselves (perhaps because Belimarius escaped with her notes), some of their allies (like Ayavah or Galissodia) are familiar enough with Sorshen’s resources to suggest that the PCs visit the archives in one of the lower wings of the Blood Moon Palace. There, they can research methods of traveling to Jandelay so they can finally confront Xanderghul and perhaps rescue Sorshen. If they drag their feet or appear to be unsure of what to do next, a dream from @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06campaignrole02]{Liralarue} can also point them in the same direction.

Blood Moon Palace.name: Blood Moon Palace
Blood Moon Palace.text:
Blood Moon Palace

The PCs have already explored some of the Blood Moon Palace, but the structure is sprawling in size and still dangerous. Between lingering holdouts of Belimarius’s forces, opportunistic looters, and dangerous wards and guardians left in place by Sorshen, anyone who plans to enter the fortress should approach with caution.

The notes and maps they recovered from Belimarius’s spellbook are more than enough to guide the PCs to a remote section of the palace’s archive wing, but either Galissodia or Ayavah can also direct the PCs to this part of the palace. If spoken to, they warn the PCs that there are likely powerful defenses and guardians still in place who, in Sorshen’s unexpected absence, might not be cooperative. The PCs didn’t encounter many defenses in their pursuit of Belimarius, as the Runelord of Envy had disarmed these herself to reach the runewell in the atrium, but the traps and protections surrounding the archives on the lower levels remain intact.

Archive Wing Features.name: Archive Wing Features
Archive Wing Features.text:
Archive Wing Features

Looting the Archives

Many valuable objects can be found in the archives, yet most belong to Queen Sorshen, and the PCs would do well to remember that. The majority of the magic items they come across in areas B1–@UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thassilonian00]{B21} are tools Sorshen won’t begrudge them borrowing for the duration of this adventure (as Astelaur in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02astelaursroo00]{B15} can explain), but the PCs shouldn’t expect to keep or sell these items. The archive’s non-magical treasure isn’t considered part of the PCs’ expected wealth gain for this adventure, but the magic items are, since the PCs can freely make use of them for the remainder of the campaign.

If the PCs abscond with any of Sorshen’s treasure or refuse to return borrowed magic items, she’ll use spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.CeSh8QcVnqP5OlLj]{Pinpoint} to track them down. She’s aware that any violence she pursues for the sake of regaining her property could be misinterpreted by anyone who doesn’t believe her claims of renouncing her tyrannical past, but her patience only goes so far. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[diplomacy|dc:50] check can mollify her anger in such a case and persuade her to accept the loss as “payment” for the services the PCs rendered by defeating Xanderghul.

Galissodia and Ayavah are both familiar with the Blood Moon Palace and can give the PCs directions to reach the archive wing on the lower levels. Use the map on the inside back cover as a reference for encounters in this area. This small section of chambers is nestled underground, but the rooms themselves are cozy and comfortable, well lit by numerous @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.mRz8Jmk4Q06SsZpC]{Everlight Crystals} and ventilated with magically powered air circulation and temperature controls. The walls are masonry, and the doors are made of reinforced wood—Sorshen knew that anyone with the power to reach this far into her domain likely wouldn’t be impeded by mundane walls and doors. As such, these bear quite little in the way of physical protections or locks unless otherwise noted. Sorshen relied mostly on her presence and reputation to protect her archives, as well as on the hazards and guardians she put in place herself.

After descending one last flight of stairs on the eastern side of the Blood Moon Palace, the PCs reach the archive wing, where Sorshen keeps her office, perfume laboratory, libraries, and a vault of Thassilonian objects, in addition to a suite of rarely-used guest accommodations. Unfortunately for the PCs, the chambers here don’t seem particularly welcoming while the archives are on lockdown—all lights darken and all hazards and guardians are activated, as detailed in the following encounters.

Note that while these areas are presented in the standard format for encounter play, there are very few actual dangers facing the PCs. Keep in mind that the players don’t know this—they should feel a sense of danger and awe as they explore these rooms for the first time. Still, once the PCs defeat the guardians in the main hall and deal with the dangerous hazard in the perfumery lab (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02palacecorrid00]{B1} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02perfumelabor00]{B11}, respectively), there’s not a lot of action (or XP) to be had in the archive wing. Consequently, if the PCs are wary of the prospect of looting the place (see the “Looting the Archives” sidebar on this page), players might grow frustrated or impatient with this section. If that seems to be the case, feel free to switch to exploration mode, share the map of the archives, and tell the players that the PCs spend several more hours exploring. Summarize the rooms so play can progress into researching their next steps (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thewaytojand00]{Here}).

Warning Dreams.name: Warning Dreams
Warning Dreams.text:
Warning Dreams

As soon as the PCs begin this chapter, they’re on a timer. The epic clash between Xanderghul and Sorshen, which has been unfolding at the heart of Jandelay since the Doomsday Door below Xin-Eurythnia opened during the first adventure of this campaign, is coming to a close, and if the PCs don’t intervene soon, Xanderghul will prevail.

The primary method by which the PCs learn about this countdown is through their dreams. Each time they sleep, they have an opportunity to visit @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06campaignrole02]{Liralarue} in the Dreamlands, as detailed in her NPC entry. Yet even on nights they don’t visit her, they experience visions and warnings sent to them through dreams. With each new day that passes, the number of uncertain futures Liralarue can glimpse dwindles, giving her the ability to more precisely predict when Xanderghul might triumph and unleash the apocalyptic power of Jandelay upon Golarion. In these dreams, she makes sure the PCs know that what they’ve accomplished so far (particularly stopping the Risen of the Trinity Star from opening more Doomsday Door in the previous adventure) has slowed his progress significantly, but time still runs short.

The first time the PCs sleep during this chapter, Liralarue warns them that she can sense the clash between Xanderghul and Sorshen is coming to a head, but that if they can make it into Jandelay within four weeks’ time, they still have a chance to stop the Runelord of Pride from enacting his apocalyptic plans. While she has no direct insight into what these plans entail, the worst-case scenario is that Xanderghul succeeds and destroys Golarion. Unfortunately, if the PCs take longer than a month to reach him, the best-case scenario is still utter devastation across the Saga Lands and much of Avistan. If the PCs can intervene within two weeks, however, Liralarue believes Sorshen herself will be able to provide more assistance during the final confrontation.

The primary thing that will consume the party’s time from this point forward are downtime activities, which includes researching a way they can reach Jandelay in the first place!

Palace Corridors.name: Palace Corridors
Palace Corridors.text:
B1. Palace Corridors Severe 19

This twenty-foot-wide, fifteen-foot-high hallway winds away from a flight of stairs and is lit only by a dim, blue-green glow that flickers from several alcoves in which statues of a beautiful woman stand. Metal-reinforced doors stand in the walls between these alcoves.

The alcoves in the walls are normally blocked off by permanent @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Walls of Force}, but when the palace’s lockdown defenses activated, these walls vanished, releasing the dangerous energies exuded by the statues of Sorshen into the hallway. These statues are made of stone but are all plated in layers of a toxic skymetal known as abysium—and a few of them are also host to even greater dangers (see “Creatures” below).

In all, there are 18 abysium-plated stone statues stored in alcoves along this hall. Each statue is an exquisite work of art, glowing softly with a wonderful blue-green luminescence. When the walls of force over these alcoves are active, the statues are harmless, but now that the palace defenses have been activated, all creatures who begin their turns in this hallway become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} if they start their turn adjacent to a statue). If the lockdown is disabled, the walls of force reappear, and the statues become harmless art pieces once more. A PC can override the lockdown for a single alcove's wall of force with a successful @Check[thievery|dc:41] check or @Check[arcana|dc:44] check made as a two-action activity, causing it to reappear.

B1. Palace Corridors Severe 19

@UUID[Actor.lvZ0NyLt9QVg9G09]{Abysium Sentinels (4)}

Creatures: Toxic statues are the least of the PCs' worries here, though, as four of the statues (the two closest to both sets of stairs) are actually headless carvings of humanoid bodies with abysium Thassilonian sentinels perched atop their necks. Because Sorshen is currently on a different plane, each sentinel’s attempts to mentally warn her of intruders are unsuccessful. They animate and attack either as soon as a PC attempts to damage any of the statues, as soon as anyone opens a doorway in the hall, or if the intruders remain in the hall for longer than 1 minute. When the sentinels attack, they activate at once, with those out of sight of the PCs quickly flying to join the fight from their perches. While the Blood Moon Palace remains on alert, the sentinels fight to the death to defend it from intruders and chase the PCs out of the archives if necessary. If lockdown procedures are disabled, however, the sentinels attempt to return to their statue perches before the walls of force go back into effect. If they can’t, they simply hunker down next to their alcoves and wait for the walls to be removed so they can climb back onto their headless homes.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.uEXHDS6W7rGbkgBa]{Abysium Statues}
If the PCs handle the statues with care, they can be used to craft abysium weapons and armor. Each statue contains 300 gp worth of abysium, enough for a PC with master proficiency in Crafting to create standard-grade abysium weapons, armors, and shields (Pathfinder Lost Omens Grand Bazaar 96). A PC with legendary proficiency in Crafting could use the statues to create high-grade abysium weapons, armor, and shields.

Once Xanderghul is defeated, however, a PC who harvested any of this abysium must succeed at a @Check[diplomacy|dc:55] check to avoid earning Sorshen's annoyance. While she understands that the PCs required access to her archives and isn't bothered by the damage dealt to her construct guardians, she expected to be able to repair them upon her return and is displeased to have lost such rare and precious crafting materials.

Auxiliary Closets.name: Auxiliary Closets
Auxiliary Closets.text:
B2. Auxiliary Closets

These auxiliary closets are a pair of rooms filled with shoes and gowns that didn’t fit in Queen Sorshen’s personal closet in the upper levels of the Blood Moon Palace. The shoe closet’s (area B2a) back wall is filled from the floor to the ceiling with all manner of shoe and boot, and there’s an ottoman in the center of the room for guests to use while changing footwear. The primary closet (area B2b) features walls of clothing on delicate golden hangers and folded into elegant drawers as well as display cabinets filled with varied styles of jewelry. Two mannequins with an uncanny resemblance to Queen Sorshen are outfitted in splendid gowns, and six tall mirrors are arranged in such a way that a person standing in their midst can view themselves from all angles.

Sorshen is determined to stay on the good side of Golarion’s many powerful heroes and avoid the fate of the other runelords, but she sometimes worries that a hero she might invite to parties in her home could arrive with mud-caked armor and dirty hair. The auxiliary closets attend to this fear and are where she maintains a collection of painstakingly selected dress clothes she deemed appropriate for these hypothetical adventurers. Queen Sorshen is, at all times, prepared to restyle a guest at a moment’s notice.

The items in the auxiliary closet are made available to the queen’s guests and friends—even for events outside the Blood Moon Palace. Any time a powerful hero needs to look sharp, Sorshen is determined to present the helpful solutions of a generous friend who’s no longer an evil, selfish tyrant.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.AO3uGIFES2rkf3Yj]{Closets} @UUID[Actor.kiAzfsdeY0b506cY]{Closet Hidden Panel}
Rows upon rows of fine, high-fashion garments (Player Core 287) and shoes line Sorshen’s closets, ranging from evening gowns to suits. The 50 plainest outfits are worth 55 gp each, but some exemplary gowns are worth considerably more. Seven gowns, two overcoats, and one matching shorts and blouse set are greater art objects, featuring delicate needle lace, gold-threaded embroidery, and amethyst stoning. These garments are worth 1,000 gp each. Two gowns are major art objects; the first is a slim-fitted, floor-length evening gown featuring noqual fastenings, a corseted bodice with sheer emerald-stoned side panels, a high slit, and a 50-foot train; the second is a structured leather ball gown made from dragon scales, with a high neck collar, adamantium gorget, and black fur stole. Each is worth 3,500 gp.

In addition, one of the mannequins wears an illusory facsimile of Sorshen's Scintillating Garment, a powerful artifact. A PC who realizes the garment is illusory and succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:50] check finds a hidden panel in the closet, revealing the real Scintillating Garment. While Sorshen is elated if the PCs arrive in Jandelay wearing anything found in the auxiliary closets, including her Scintillating Garment, she does expect them to return her belongings when all is said and done.

Guest Rooms.name: Guest Rooms
Guest Rooms.text:
B3. Guest Rooms

The following text applies to all four guest rooms.

This guest room contains a four-poster bed adorned with silk bedspreads, a writing desk, velvet-cushioned bench at the foot of the bed, and layers of plush fur-and-wool rugs over the cool tile floor. The room is lit by a crystal chandelier.

When the PCs arrive, the four guest rooms are unlocked but can be locked from the inside. If locked, a successful DC @Check[thievery|dc:30] is required to open them from the outside.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.bV9uErHEtwXxxbtm]{Crystal Chandelier} Each room’s crystal chandelier is fitted with two dozen everlight crystals and is worth 1,000 gp apiece.

Guest Kitchen.name: Guest Kitchen
Guest Kitchen.text:
B4. Guest Kitchen

This kitchen is equipped with an open-fire stove and ample counter and table space to work on. Food and drink are stored in a wide array of cupboards and crates.

The cupboards here are magically enchanted to preserve any foodstuffs placed within them—some can even keep food chilled. The secret door to area B4a can be discovered with a successful @Check[perception|dc:35] check.

Creatures: Though Sorshen’s guests are more than welcome to use this kitchen themselves, the kitchen is staffed by clockwork servants who cook, clean, and care for the archive wing of the palace. The two clockwork housekeepers and the single clockwork chef are special variants of clockwork soldiers whose programming enables them to prepare meals, though they remain as capable in combat as the typical clockwork soldier. These servants have not been wound since the morning of the Unveiling Ceremony and currently rest, inoperable, in their hidden back room (area B4a) while the lockdown is in effect

If the PCs discover the clockworks and wind them, they return to their duties immediately. The cooking and housekeeping services of the clockworks can help the PCs focus on their research once the lockdown is lifted, granting them a +1 status bonus to research checks made in the archives (@UUID[Item.lQpwm5EPDSMfP7Vi]{Clockwork Servants' Assistance}).

@UUID[Actor.ysev2V0mf9LP3DDV]{Clockwork Servants (3)} Creature 6

  • Uncommon
  • Medium
  • Clockwork
  • Construct
  • Mindless

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.FyrsCx6Ong7IMMCR]{Kitchen}
A ten-minute Search of this room turns up a few potent alchemical foodstuffs, including six flasks of wyrmhide fury cocktails, ten greater poison fizzes, and eight greater silver crescents.

Storage Room.text:
B6. Storage Room

The door to this plain storage room is locked but can be opened by a PC who succeeds at four @Check[thievery|dc:35|traits:manipulate,skill,action:pick-a-lock|name:Pick a Lock] checks to Pick the Lock or a @Check[athletics|dc:40|traits:attack,skill,action:force-open|name:Force Open] check to Force it Open.

This storage room is plain but amply stocked with cleaning supplies, spare bed linens, materials for spot repairs, and crates of shelf-stable foods like rice and lentils.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.c93plNMG2Q3UpygX]{Storage Room} @UUID[Actor.Uiqx6MR9BIbOkdh1]{Secret Entrance}
If the PCs spend 15 minutes Searching this room, they can gather 1,000 gp worth of raw materials that can be used to craft alchemical items in Sorshen’s laboratory. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:40|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check made during the Search (or who Seeks in the right area) uncovers the secret door to area B6a. Within, what appears to be Sorshen’s Sinuous Guisarme is displayed behind a permanent 10th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force}. If the PCs can remove the wall or otherwise bypass it, they may be disappointed to discover the guisarme isn’t the real thing, but it’s nevertheless a powerful facsimile Sorshen had created to loan out to her allies—she’s delighted to see any PC using this +3 major striking keen shifting spell reservoir guisarme when she finally meets them again. As with the actual Sinuous Guisarme, this weapon’s unusual double-bladed design grants it the twin weapon trait.
Storage Room.name: Storage Room

Toy Storage.name: Toy Storage
Toy Storage.text:
B9. Toy Storage

This chamber is filled with shelves and crates containing a wide range of strange toys, trinkets, and sparkling decorations.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.Lqy6EhlWM5NavoFO]{Toy Storage} @UUID[Actor.2dhZY7yDOSmt3ybP]{Toy Storage Hidden Loot}
The minor items stored here are a collection Sorshen maintains for her pet dweomercat, Astelaur. If the PCs raid his toy room, they suffer a –2 penalty to checks to gain information and other assistance from the dweomercat until they hand over the toys. Most of the items here are minor trinkets—in all, they constitute 6 Bulk of various toys worth a total of 2,000 gp, but a PC who Searches the area for 10 minutes notices a few items of greater value, including an exquisite high-grade alloy orb, a major ruby capacitor, and a greater snarling badger. If the PCs befriend Astelaur, he’ll allow them to keep these more valuable consumables.

Meeting Room.name: Meeting Room
Meeting Room.text:
B10. Meeting Room

The table and couches in this small room are provided to offer guests a place to eat and rest. Though simple, the furniture is stylish and high quality.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.ckroJ91lNg7LwqvI]{Meeting Room}
Sorshen used this room to meet with important guests. A PC who spends 10 minutes Searching this room discovers something of note—a wand of manifestation etched with a mysterious sigil. This item, left behind by none other than Old Mage Jatembe on a recent secret visit to discuss potential Thassilonian curriculums at the Magaambya, is one of the few items found in the archives that Sorshen won't demand back. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:30] check or @Check[society|dc:35] check recognizes that the sigil on the wand is Old Mage Jatembe's personal rune. If the PCs discover who the wand belonged to and return it to him, Jatembe thanks them for their honesty but tells them the wand is theirs, adding with a mercurial wink that he left it there for them in their time of need.

Perfume Laboratory.name: Perfume Laboratory
Perfume Laboratory.text:
B11. Perfume Laboratory Severe 19

A faint but cloying mist that carries an unpleasant, musky scent fills this large alchemical laboratory, which appears to be focused on distilling perfumes and oils. Three free-standing workbenches sit in the middle of the room, while to the east, the entire wall is taken up by a single long workbench covered with strange machinery and glass containers of differently colored bubbling liquids and churning smoke.

Much has changed in the thousands of years between Sorshen’s rule over Eurythnia and her emergence into the modern world.
