The apocalypse of Earthfall wrought significant shifts over Inner Sea flora, and plants once used to create Sorshen’s favored scents are now long extinct. Her desire to replicate these lost scents inspired her new hobby as an amateur perfumer, and she uses this laboratory to experiment with alchemy and perfumes alike.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.bWvbAaWPwS7xzaag.PlaylistSound.KzovAO8DSpRDWeCP]{Malfunctioning Perfumery}

B11. Perfume Laboratory Severe 19

@UUID[Actor.2XdbwKcwCVSJh6lV]{Malfunctioning Perfumery (Freestanding)} @UUID[Actor.XrsiXY5zSNyYHWcB]{Malfunctioning Perfumery (Eastern)}

Hazard: Sorshen was in the process of distilling several rare and unusual essential oils at the time of the Unveiling Ceremony. When she did not return to the lab to finish, unintended problems began emerging. As soon as the PCs open the door to the perfume laboratory, the malfunctioning perfumery hazard activates.

The dangers of the abandoned perfumery are represented by a single complex hazard that represents the malfunctioning of the three freestanding workbenches and the larger workbench to the east. By disabling or destroying the smaller workbenches, the overall danger of the hazard can be lessened, but the hazard as a whole threatens those in the room until it's fully dealt with.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.XniEVS71SH6SIikF]{Smaller Workbenches} @UUID[Actor.Ovno3oggU415MiGX]{Large Eastern Workbench} @UUID[Actor.1G4m2ykAfGXI4cCy]{Perfume Laboratory}
After this chamber’s hazard is disabled, the PCs can recover up to five batches of alchemical wonders from the room‚ two from the large eastern workbench and one each from the three smaller workbenches. If a workbench was destroyed in this encounter, its associated treasure(s) is lost.

Between the three smaller workbenches are three major dread ampoules, a true elixir of life, and three major bottled catharses. The larger eastern workbench has two elixirs of rejuvenation and a greater alchemical chart.

Finally, if all three workbenches survive intact, the PCs can use the laboratory themselves. They receive a +3 item bonus to Crafting checks to create alchemical items while working in Sorshen’s laboratory (@UUID[Item.JwWBjQP5FWy4WFcQ]{Sorshen's Laboratory}).

A total of 20,000 gp in raw materials for crafting alchemical items is kept here—materials that can be claimed even if all of the workbenches were destroyed.

Reward: Dealing with the malfunctioning machinery here is a mythic deed; doing so grants 3 Mythic Points to each PC.

Private Archive Corridors.name: Private Archive Corridors
Private Archive Corridors.text:
B12. Private Archive Corridors

The sparse corridors of Sorshen’s private archive circle around an atrium at the center of the room. Thanks to the atrium’s glass windows, the room’s beautiful landscaping can be seen and enjoyed even while passing through the halls.

Under normal circumstances, clockwork librarians care for the archives, but they haven’t been wound in some time. Four hidden closets (area B12a) line the corridors, each containing an inoperable clockwork librarian. If the PCs find and wind the clockworks back up, the constructs return to their duties once the lockdown is lifted, granting the PCs a +1 status bonus to research checks made in the archives (@UUID[Item.7Q88f4BWbtTGSLrW]{Clockwork Librarians' Assistance}).

If the PCs activate the clockwork cooks (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02guestkitchen00]{B4a}) and these clockwork librarians, this becomes a +2 status bonus on research checks.

Prayer Room.name: Prayer Room
Prayer Room.text:
B16. Prayer Room

A large obsidian-and-porphyry statue of a beautiful winged woman with three tails stands directly in front of a small window through which a night sky, full moon, and the skyline of Xin-Eurythnia can be seen as if viewed from a high tower in the Blood Moon Palace. Moonlight reaches through the window and graces a pair of discreet prisms held in the statue’s raised hands, casting a gentle, pastel rainbow across the ceiling.

This small prayer room honors @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.jL1qiVOZBKXETtVD]{Nocticula}, the Redeemer Queen, and is used by Queen Sorshen as a private altar. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:30] check discerns that the floor cushions in the room see regular use, but that the altar itself is rarely approached, suggesting Sorshen may use the room for contemplation more than prayer. The window beyond the statue is a 10th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Ucf8eynbZMfUucjE]{Illusory Scene}, as is the rainbow pattern on the ceiling.

Treasure: @UUID[Item.J0MtVv3YpXTdoysD]{Sanctuary's Blessing}
A PC who worships @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.jL1qiVOZBKXETtVD]{Nocticula} or one of the deities the Redeemer Queen has good relations with (such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.AlL9GtlTldbqNoVm]{Calistria}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.0BH54ZVR8NcrGlMu]{Findeladlara}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.gxwmzxUWBOhdgFSN]{Shelyn}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.aTYy1WHwAZiuei4h]{Tsukiyo}) finds comfort here and instinctively understands that if they spend an hour in prayer or meditation, the room can grant them the ability to cast a 9th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.SUKaxVZW2TlM8lu0]{Cleanse Affliction} once in the following 24 hours as an innate divine spell.

Artwork Storage.name: Artwork Storage
Artwork Storage.text:
B18. Artwork Storage

This vault contains an amazing collection of artwork, with a particular focus on ceramics, paintings, and statuettes, most of which are kept in labeled containers or wrapped in silk as they sit atop annotated shelves.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.kxwAirAvn0dRnJWB]{Artwork Storage}
A PC who spends 2 hours Searching this room can get a good idea of the amount of artwork kept here—in all, the collection is worth a staggering 60,000 gp. Of course, selling any of this artwork off is sure to annoy Sorshen! This collection is perhaps more valuable to the PCs as a place to spend time researching the Oliphaunt and Jandelay (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thewaytojand00]{Here}).

Inner Atrium.name: Inner Atrium
Inner Atrium.text:
B19. Inner Atrium

The inner atrium is a lush, humid greenhouse located at the center of the archives. Its glass walls accommodate an uninterrupted view of the archive corridors. The bottom level has a manicured lawn of soft clover and is illuminated by magical sunlight. A shimmering pool of water occupies the center of the lower atrium, and rich, upholstered chairs flank the pool, offering comfortable places to relax.

Treasure: The shimmering pool of water is a scrying pool—it’s immobile but has all of the abilities of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.ByRyBRjNBcK5rwQ9]{Peridot Crystal Ball}.

Thassilonian Relic Storage.name: Thassilonian Relic Storage
Thassilonian Relic Storage.text:
B21. Thassilonian Relic Storage

A large range of antiques and relics are stored in this room. The most interesting pieces are displayed behind glass, like a small, personal museum exhibit, while other items are sorted and stored across a multitude of drawers.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.Uu6OohTnRBpgWgHJ]{Relic Storage}
A wide range of ancient Thassilonian objects are kept here. Many of these have little value to anyone other than Sorshen, an archaeologist, or a Thassilonian scholar, but in all, the objects here are worth approximately 30,000 gp. As with the art in the nearby storeroom, these resources are perhaps more useful as objects to research.

Arriving at Spindlehorn.text:
Arriving at Spindlehorn

Like other great Thassilonian ruins such as Magnimar’s Irespan, Riddleport’s Cyphergate, Korvosa’s central ziggurat (known as the Grand Mastaba), or the towering Lady’s Light at the southeast corner of the Mushfens, Spindlehorn has long inspired and terrified Varisia’s people. Unlike those sites mentioned above, though, Spindlehorn’s remote location between the shores of the Storval Deep and the rugged Wyvern Mountains has kept it from ever becoming an oft-visited adventuring site. The structure itself contradicts the laws of architecture and physics, appearing as a two-thousand-foot-tall column of stone around which a single spiraling staircase winds up to a precarious ten-foot diameter platform that affords one of the most stunning (and terrifying) views of the Storval Plateau. That Spindlehorn’s astoundingly slender length has endured thousands of years of storms, earthquakes, and even Earthfall itself speaks to its potency.

Yet before the PCs can begin to duplicate Runelord Gimmel’s ritual to conjure the Oliphaunt of Jandelay, they must first recover the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} they now know lies as deep underground as the tower rises, in a hermetically sealed chamber known as the Prosperity Vault. Of all the ways they could use to enter the vault, the one suggested in their research is the simplest: by traveling to the Netherworld at this location, they can find an incredible inversion of Spindlehorn—a two-thousand-foot-deep pit into which a ten-foot-wide spiraling ramp winds ever deeper.

The easiest way the PCs can travel to the Netherworld and descend into Nether Spindlehorn’s pit is via casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} at the site (potentially using the scroll found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02sorshensstud00]{B17}; if no PC can cast this spell, one of their allies who can cast arcane or occult magic, such as Aethusa, can step in to help). Afterward, they can traverse the ramp down into the pit’s depths before returning to Golarion by ending the spell, appearing in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02uppertower0000]{C1} of the Prosperity Vault. If your players come up with a different method to reach the chamber below, such as by transforming into burrowing creatures or somehow figuring out a way to teleport directly into the area, that should work as well—in this case, you can either create a Moderate encounter similar to the one presented below to challenge them, or simply award them 80 XP for their ingenuity and proceed with the Prosperity Vault encounters.
Arriving at Spindlehorn.name: Arriving at Spindlehorn

Ambush of the Runelords.name: Ambush of the Runelords
Ambush of the Runelords.text:
Ambush of the Runelords Severe 19

While the party delivered a devastating blow to the Risen of the Trinity Star when they stormed the Crypt of Runes in the previous adventure, not all of Xanderghul’s risen runelords were present in the crypt. Some of them accompanied him on his initial journey to open the Doomsday Door below Xin-Eurythnia and were destroyed in the process, but the three remaining risen runelords were left behind. These risen were among the most recent of Xanderghul’s creations—not only the most powerful of them, but led by the only runelord who comes close to surpassing his hatred of his long-term rival Sorshen: Runelord Alaznist, the one who most recently murdered him in her bid to rise from Hollow Mountain.

Risen runelord Alaznist is in turn served by two slightly less-powerful risen runelords: Aethusa II (the sixth Runelord of Greed) and Jurah (the fourth Runelord of Envy). When word came of the fall of the Crypt of Runes and the PCs’ success in opposing the Risen of the Trinity Star’s efforts to open the Doomsday Door, these three went to ground to bide their time. By scrying upon allies of the PCs and using other methods to surreptitiously track their progress, they kept tabs on the PCs’ every action, hoping their attempt to reach Xanderghul would fail. They were unable to pursue the PCs into the Blood Moon Palace for fear of being discovered, but when the PCs left for Spindlehorn, they knew it was time to strike. Alaznist used umbral journey to follow them through the Netherworld, and now she and her two companions are ready to ambush the PCs at some point in the Prosperity Vault.

Where to carry out this encounter is up to you. You may have the risen runelords track the PCs through the Prosperity Vault, striking when they’re tired from another battle or while they rest. Conversely, they might race down the stairs soon after the PCs enter area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02lowertower0000]{C2} (this is an excellent place to stage the attack, as it’s a large room with no other combats set there), moving in a panic and hoping to stop them before they get much further. They could even launch an attack against them just before they begin the ritual to conjure the Oliphaunt atop Spindlehorn. However it plays out, allow the PCs to attempt @Check[perception|dc:42] checks before the ambush begins. If any PC succeeds, they know that something or someone is stalking them—give the party a moment to prepare if they wish, allowing them to potentially lay a trap for the ambushers.

Ambush of the Runelords Severe 19

@UUID[Actor.eAahBKrenBT6bZiB]{Risen Runelord Alaznist} @UUID[Actor.G0s3kKkrAdnedBAy]{Risen Runelord Aethusa II} @UUID[Actor.HfKEy6QUytBE8O1x]{Risen Runelord Jurah}

Alaznist hangs back to blast the PCs with magic from afar while Aethusa II and Jurah move forward to engage (also with magic) at closer range. If they’re able to prepare for the ambush because no PC succeeded at their Perception checks, the risen runelords each have one round to cast preparatory spells before the attack begins (Alaznist casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly}, Aethusa II casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.m2xFMNyQiUKQDRaj]{Energy Aegis}, and Jurah casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wfleiawxsfhpRRwf]{Disappearance}). Once combat begins, the three risen runelords fight until destroyed.

Reward: With the defeat of these final risen runelords, the PCs have finished off all of the risen runelords Xanderghul created. Grant each PC 3 Mythic Points for this legendary deed.

Upper Tower.name: Upper Tower
Upper Tower.text:
C1. Upper Tower Moderate 19

Decrepit mosaics cover the walls, while black marble statues of men with wolf skulls for heads stand along the perimeter of the room. All but the four southernmost statues are shattered. What may have once been a grand entryway has caved in, likely a consequence of becoming buried thousands of feet below ground. Only a set of spiraled stairs remain at the room’s center, leading farther down. The air smells stale and is uncomfortable to breathe.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[art-lore|dc:39|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[arcana|dc:41|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes that the mosaics are a rendition of Runelord Kaladurnae's life and achievements. In them, he is shown conquering fortune dragons, sponsoring arcane scholarships, and standing triumphant over the Cinderlands.

The spiral stairs lead 100 feet down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02lowertower0000]{C2}.

C1. Upper Tower Moderate 19

@UUID[Actor.IehTXzFNFEPQ9kFk]{Adamantine Sentinels (8)}

Creatures: Kaladurnae armed the entrance to his Prosperity Vault with a fleet of adamantine sentinels, each perched on the neck of one of a dozen decapitated marble statues. These sentinels faithfully guarded Kaladurnae’s arcane vault for thousands of years until the arrival of the goldgorgers. Though the sentinels rose to stop them, four were consumed by the voracious elementals. Those that remain do so only because the goldgorgers got full and moved on. The remaining eight sentinels have returned to perch atop their statues; they fight until destroyed but will not pursue intruders down into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02lowertower0000]{C2}.

Vault Threshold.name: Vault Threshold
Vault Threshold.text:
C3. Vault Threshold

A line of four black stone statues of a handsome man with gold hands and gold eyes stand along the southern wall of this long room. Each statue stands in a different pose—one welcoming, one stern, one observant, and one triumphant. A pair of burrowed oval tunnels open into the room to the north and east, while a worked stone tunnel in the center of the north wall ends at what looks like an immense plug of solid gold that blocks further passage north.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[society|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge identifies the man depicted in the statues as Kaladurnae. The gold blocking the tunnel is no illusion or falsehood—it's real gold generated by the Heart of Greed (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02heartofgreed00]{C6}), now completely "overgrown" to fully plug the original seven hallways that granted access to the chamber.

If the PCs make a lot of noise here (such as by trying to mine the gold or shouting), the goldgorgers who infest the surrounding burrows come to investigate (see area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02goldgorgerbu00]{C4}).

Conjuring the Oliphaunt.name: Conjuring the Oliphaunt
Conjuring the Oliphaunt.text:
Conjuring the Oliphaunt

Spindlehorn is 2,000 feet tall, and a climb up the steps that wind around its base takes nearly an hour, assuming the PCs are ascending carefully. At your discretion, a PC who attempts to race up the stairs can make the journey in 30 minutes but must succeed at four separate @Check[acrobatics|dc:40] or @Check[athletics|dc:40] checks to avoid a slip or a tumble (with each successive check being made at an increasing altitude of 500 feet). Flight and even teleportation are swifter and safer options. In the end, for a high level mythic party, reaching the top of Spindlehorn shouldn’t be a big deal... even if they have to call on Kandirvek to fly them up to the top!

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.sIZDiWhTJPXp2RPT]{Spindlehorn} @UUID[Playlist.bWvbAaWPwS7xzaag.PlaylistSound.0blKBh7xEmZ1R5L8]{Conjuring The Oliphaunt}

At its peak, Spindlehorn’s stairs end at a ten-foot diameter platform—room for four Medium or smaller PCs to stand without immediate fear of falling. No railing protects against such a fall, and the view of the Wyvern Mountains and the Storval Deep is as breathtaking as it is nerve-wracking. The weather should be clear and calm—a blessing, as in high winds the tower’s slightly gentle sway is more noticeable (although never enough to threaten collapse!) Flying is certainly a wise choice for the PCs at this point!

Armed with the ritual’s details they uncovered in Sorshen’s archive and a fragment of the Oliphaunt itself in the form of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed}, the party can begin the process of conjuring the Oliphaunt at once. To do so, the PCs must perform a special ritual, detailed below—you can assume all the PCs know this ritual already if they achieved at least 18 Research Points when researching @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02thewaytojand00]{The Way to Jandelay}.

This ritual plays out differently than more common rituals, and rather than being a single set of checks made by a primary caster and secondary casters, the entire party takes part, resolving the ritual’s success using the chase rules (GM Core 192) to overcome three obstacles. The PCs earn Ritual Points each time they succeed at a check to overcome one of the following obstacles. As soon as their Ritual Point total equals or exceeds the threshold value, they prevail and immediately begin the next step of the ritual. Ten minutes pass each round, during which a PC engaged in attempting to overcome the current obstacle can take no other action. If the PCs haven’t completed the ritual by the end of 30 minutes, the ritual comes to a sudden end, and the magic closes down with a catastrophic explosion. Each PC who took part in the ritual takes @Damage[15d10[force]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:42|basic] save), with those who critically fail being knocked off the top of Spindlehorn if they weren’t flying, after which the PCs must wait a day for Spindlehorn to recover its energies so they may try again.

Scene Notes Sound Effect

@UUID[Playlist.8w8BYQ8qA7s7m3h1.PlaylistSound.7VCwjN4MrdgHxnzF]{Catastrophic Explosion}

In some cases, a PC can perform a required action (such as by casting a specific spell) to automatically earn a Ritual Point, but if they roll a check to overcome, they earn points as follows:

Critical Success The PCs gain 2 Ritual Points.

Success The PCs gain 1 Ritual Point.

Critical Failure The PCs lose 1 Ritual Point, and the PC who made the check suffers the specific effect for that round’s critical failure.

Open the Portal

Ritual Points 2

Overcome @Check[arcana|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite], @Check[occultism|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite], or @Check[religion|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to manipulate planar energies, @Check[athletics|dc:42|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to help hold the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JsRaJz8Lo1FE1R0P]{Apocalypse Seed} steady at the center of the ritual's focus, or @Check[reflex|dc:45|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to keep your footing. A PC may also cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Ywe64VHwcBOAWBtq]{Summon Oliphaunt of Jandelay} to automatically earn 1 Ritual Point instead of attempting a check, using the magic of the spell to bolster the ritual.

The ritual begins as the PCs call the Oliphaunt to return. Tremors begin to shake the ground, sounding almost like the approach of immense footsteps. Waves ripple across the surface of the Storval Deep while small landslides tumble down slopes of the nearby Wyvern Mountains. Spindlehorn vibrates and shakes with each footfall but does not collapse. When this step is overcome, an immense swirling portal rips open in reality, affording a harrowing glimpse into a churning vortex in which fragments of countless destroyed worlds churn.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[20d8[spirit]] damage (@Check[will|dc:40|basic] save) as fragments of their soul are torn free by the magic.

Beckon the Oliphaunt

Ritual Points 3

Overcome @Check[deception|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite], @Check[diplomacy|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite], or @Check[intimidation|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to trick, lure, or dare the Oliphaunt to emerge through the portal, @Check[performance|dc:42|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to capture the Oliphaunt's attention, or @Check[will|dc:45|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to keep from being overwhelmed by the Oliphaunt's presence. A PC may also cast a spell (of at least 8th rank) or use a feat (of at least 15th level) to aid in attracting the Oliphaunt's attention—the GM should determine if the spell or feat could be used in such a way (some examples would include the bard feat @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.8C9qo5LL9J0UTNGc]{Courageous Onslaught}, the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.mZttsiWl1ql5NvrH]{Scare to Death} Intimidation skill feat, or the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fkDeKktdmbeplYRY]{Overwhelming Presence} spell).

The Oliphaunt begins manifesting into Golarion. It stands before Spindlehorn, before the PCs, looking into them as it once looked into Gimmel. The beast's eyes pierce the soul. It roars with terrible promise, and the ground cracks beneath its feet. With its tusks, the beast tears the Universe open, creating a path home from naught. It prepares to return to Jandelay, the power of the ritual inadequate for it to manifest fully in the world.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[20d8[sonic]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:40|basic] save) as their failure results in a blast of sound directed solely at them from the Oliphaunt.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.rcnMG9SHg5flRm21]{Ride The Oliphaunt}

Ride the Oliphaunt

Ritual Points 3

Overcome @Check[nature|dc:40|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to effortlessly ride the Oliphaunt, @Check[acrobatics|dc:42|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to balance on the Oliphaunt, or @Check[perception|dc:45|traits:olliphaunt-rite] to determine the safest way to clamber onto the immense beast. A PC may also cast a spell (of at least 8th rank) or use a feat (of at least 15th level) to aid in being able to clamber onto the creature and remain there securely (some examples would include the rogue feat @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.fLrwddS607eRFfHA]{Implausible Infiltration}, the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.TVFfTP9fHRidwBlW]{Cloud Jump} Athletics skill feat to leap onto the creature, or the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pswdik31kuHEvdno]{Metamorphosis} spell to assume the form of a clinging creature)

The Oliphaunt treads a path it alone was meant to walk, and the Great Beyond believes it walks alone. Whether by clinging atop its back like a speck of inconsequential cosmic dust or by fooling the multiverse into believing you, too, are the Oliphaunt of Jandelay, you're granted access into one of the multiverse's backstage corridors. Falling from the beast's back now, in this place between places, would annihilate your soul.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[20d8[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic] save) from a glancing blow from the Oliphaunt as it turns to retreat back to Jandelay.

Rewards: Conjuring the Oliphaunt is a mythic deed. Once the PCs complete the ritual, restore 3 Mythic Points to each PC. In addition, they earn 80 XP each.

Stuck Between Places.name: Stuck Between Places
Stuck Between Places.text:
Stuck Between Places

As the PCs clamber aboard the Oliphaunt, it begins its return to Jandelay, traversing the Great Beyond in a vertiginous journey into the silvery eternity of the Astral Plane. To the PCs, they see their world suddenly pull away as if they were catapulted into the depths of space for a few moments before spending what feels paradoxically like a few seconds and forever in the endless void of the Astral Plane. Then, the silvery nothingness surrounding them blooms into a swirling riot of color as the fragmented worlds they glimpsed through the portal manifest all around them. Allow the PCs to attempt a @Check[arcana|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], @Check[occultism|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], or @Check[religion|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge to realize they’ve arrived at the outskirts of Jandelay... a moment before things go completely awry.

Race to the End.name: Race to the End
Race to the End.text:
Chapter 3: Race to the End

A few moments after the PCs defeat the Ashen Man, they return from his mindscape to their perilous position atop the Oliphaunt, riding the beast into Jandelay.

The Oliphaunt hurtles into the Apocalypse Archive, stampeding across the plane, blazing a trail of destruction through a patchwork of countless ended worlds. Eventually, if the PCs don’t jump from the Oliphaunt’s back themselves, the beast shakes them loose, and they drift gently down into one of the grassy fields that separate the apocalypse capsules. Unlike the many ending worlds the PCs could see while riding the Oliphaunt, the field is peaceful and quiet, empty save for the PCs and a huge alabaster white spire. Likewise, regardless of how much time passes between the PCs stepping (or being thrown) off of the Oliphaunt, they all arrive here simultaneously.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.Kr3qMEyrlQ3wyyit]{Jandelay Fields}

Somewhere in Jandelay, Xanderghul and Sorshen are locked in tumultuous battle, and the PCs must reach them before Xanderghul is victorious, sacrificing the Saga Lands to the Apocalypse Archive and completing his ascension.

Entering an Apocalypse.name: Entering an Apocalypse
Entering an Apocalypse.text:
Entering an Apocalypse

At the end of each hour spent Navigating Jandelay, if the party has accrued at least 4 Apocalypse Points, they lose all those points, earn 1 Mythic Point each, and move on to the next apocalypse closer to Xanderghul (proceeding through the following several encounters in the order presented). If they have 3 or fewer Apocalypse Points, then each PC experiences a traumatic vision in which they see Golarion come to an end, with a focus on what they love most about their world being front and center—each PC takes @Damage[42[mental]] damage and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:42] save with the following results, after which they can attempt to Navigate Jandelay again while carrying over the Apocalypse Points they earned in the previous attempts.

Critical Success The PC takes no damage.

Success The PC takes half damage.

Failure The PC takes full damage and increases their @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed} condition value by 1.

Critical Failure The PC takes double damage and increases their @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed} condition value by 2.

Androffa’s End.name: Androffa’s End
Androffa’s End.text:
Androffa’s End

In the Age of Creation when mortality and divinity alike were new, Rovagug roamed the Universe consuming and destroying planets. Countless worlds were added to Jandelay’s archive before life could even begin upon them until finally the gods crafted a prison to contain the Rough Beast, luring him to Golarion to become trapped there, drawing him away from other worlds like Earth or Androffa. The latter was a faraway world in a faraway galaxy, and though the Rough Beast’s rampage was stopped before he reached Androffa, it would not be kept from the Apocalypse Archives forever.

The humans of Androffa grew quickly, guided through their earliest ages by ancient gods known collectively as the Shoal. But, as their power and capabilities continued to ascend, they eventually turned away from their divine benefactors. The Androffans entered a golden age of incredible technologies, and gloried in themselves and in their own creations, rather than in their creators. As they launched one of the greatest of these creations, the immense starship Divinity, which brought their culture to countless other worlds and could even travel between galaxies using revolutionary wormhole-creating engines, the Shoal grew frustrated, bitter, and petulant.

Androffa’s apocalypse took place some time after Divinity left their solar system but before the ship crashed on Golarion in a region that would one day become known as Numeria. When it came, it was swift and—to all but a few prophets and doomsayers—unexpected. The Shoal descended from the heavens and rose from the depths to show the Androffans the power of the gods. The megacities covering Androffa’s surface and hovering in low orbit went cold, plunged into a sudden, eternal winter, and the vast majority of life on the planet was destroyed. The Shoal left only enough alive to ensure that the survivors could, in theory, learn from their hubris and potentially rebuild from the frozen ruins, and they named this a mercy before they departed. For a time, the Shoal watched over the ruined world before they too lost interest and moved on. Today, Androffa has rebuilt into a new world, one far different than what came before—but when things ended with the Shoal’s devastation, a portion of Androffa was stolen away to join Jandelay.

Read or paraphrase the following as the PCs arrive in this apocalypse.

Strange, flat streets of dark gray stone painted with yellow and white stripes are dusted by a thin blanket of frost that sparkles where it catches the sun. Everything is bright, cold, and unnaturally straight. Glowing symbols float in the air next to buildings made of stone, metal, and glass, accompanied by pictures of shoes and shivering bowls of noodles. A distant scream pierces the barren light of day followed by the silence of death. Faces come into focus in the shadowed corners of stairwells and doorways, huddled people hiding from something that has them terrified to their core. Partially obscured by the sun’s bright rays, pearlescent figures seem to descend from the sky but never deign to touch the ground. The same cannot be said of the beings swathed in shadow and smoke who climb up from rifts in the earth. Ropes of rainbow and black chains flail in a tempest, linking all these looming entities, and they speak as one in a shrill sonic wave that sounds like no language, yet can still be understood.

“For your hubris. For what was owed but never paid. For your disrespect.”

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[architecture-lore|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], @Check[society|dc:42|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], or @Check[crafting|dc:45|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes similarities in architecture, construction techniques, and materials between this strange city and the technological ruins in Numeria. A critical success on any of these checks confirms that the PCs stand in an Androffan city from the distant past—the same place that the Divinity, the ship that crashed in Numeria hailed from so long ago.

These strange figures are the gods of Androffa, and a moment later, a devastating combination of freezing winds, huge tremors, and waves of monstrous invaders sweep over the world. Ice crystals form in the streets, and a thick layer of frost accretes along buildings, causing metal and glass to shatter. The ground heaves as monstrous fiends erupt from it and begin chasing down and consuming the fleeing populace. The rare few creatures who survive this apocalypse will do purely through chance.

The PCs are caught in this combination of freezing winds, collapses, and fiendish incursions, and enduring the apocalypse takes place in two stages. The first of these is resolved using the run away chase subsystem (GM Core 192); the PCs have 6 rounds to complete the chase before the fiendish monsters unleashed upon this reality catch up to them. Each round of the chase represents the passage of 5 minutes in game—if the PCs don’t finish all six obstacles in 30 minutes, their pursuers catch up and attack (see Facing the Fiends).

Bitter Winds of Annihilation Obstacle 20

Chase Points 4

Overcome @Check[survival|dc:40] to prepare for the extreme temperatures, @Check[nature|dc:42] to prepare for the extreme temperatures, @Check[fortitude|dc:45] to simply endure the cold

The Shoal have blotted out the sun's warmth from Androffa. The temperature drops to terrible, inhospitable levels that almost no one could survive unprepared.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[cold]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Neon Collapse Obstacle 20

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[reflex|dc:40] to dodge the falling rubble, @Check[athletics|dc:42] to catch falling fragments or knock them aside, @Check[perception|dc:45] to anticipate a sign breaking before it happens

While racing through the streets, several of Androffa's outlandish glowing signs flicker and spark before smashing to the ground, threatening to crush anyone caught beneath them.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Rime and Oil Obstacle 20

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[acrobatics|dc:40] to balance on the slick ground, @Check[stealth|dc:42] to find a place to hide while cautiously weaving through the streets, @Check[crafting|dc:45] to swiftly jury-rig protection from the flames

The flat Androffan roads have grown slick with ice and spilled oil leaking from nearby vehicles. The Shoal descend from the sky like twinkling stars or up from the ground like volcanic eruptions and will burn anyone who dares to fly up between the buildings immediately.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[fire]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Lamentations of the Doomed Obstacle 20

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[intimidation|dc:40] to scare the desperate masses away, @Check[medicine|dc:42] to quickly (if only for a few moments) ease their pain, @Check[will|dc:45] to steel your nerves against the pleading faces

Huddled Androffans hide in the small corners of stairs and roofs, hoping to outlast the Shoal's anger. Their desperate eyes beg for help, for someone to save them, but they all died nine thousand years ago. Nothing can get these people off Androffa alive.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Between the Broken Shards Obstacle 20

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[thievery|dc:40] to quickly clear the glass from the area before it becomes dangerous, @Check[crafting|dc:42] to quickly clear the glass from the area before it becomes dangerous, @Check[acrobatics|dc:45] to weave between the broken shards

The winds pick up, and the temperatures drop. Shelter can be found in the Androffa's metal buildings, but the winds outside whip shards of glass from hundreds of windows into a razor-edged storm.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[slashing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Rouse the Strange Machine Obstacle 20

Chase Points 4

Overcome @Check[engineering-lore|dc:40] to revive the strange machine in the bitter cold, @Check[thievery|dc:42] to revive the strange machine in the bitter cold, @Check[crafting|dc:45] to warm the machine enough to bring it back online

The PCs reach a strange machine—part tank, part flying vehicle—whose pressurized interior will protect against the cold and hide them from the fiends, but the intense, freezing cold has sapped the power from it. If the machine can be revived, it can offer a warm harbor to wait out the end of the world, even as the supernatural proximity of so many fiends rips and tears at the party's souls.

Critical Failure The PC takes @Damage[10d6[spirit]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic:true] save).

Adjusting Xanderghul.name: Adjusting Xanderghul
Adjusting Xanderghul.text:
Adjusting Xanderghul

Xanderghul is a 25th-level mythic foe. If all five favors are in play, Xanderghul is reduced in power to something more akin to a Severe 20 encounter.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.campaign-effects.Item.G8YANJEFkHebehZh]{Favor of a Past Benefactor}: Runelord Liralarue uses her knowledge of rune magic to suppress Xanderghul’s spells. Reduce Xanderghul’s arcane spellcasting DC to 46 and his spell attack modifier to +38. He loses his Sovereign of the False ability entirely.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.campaign-effects.Item.HTPJ0ciyeaIgrPzQ]{Favor of a Present Foe}: While they don’t appear in person, the favor of a present foe ripples through time and space to undermine Xanderghul’s defenses by filling his mind with convictions of betrayal and the failure of his supporters. Reduce all of Xanderghul’s skill checks, saving throws, and Perception modifiers by 4.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.campaign-effects.Item.rjQyiAqxvVzYUpqV]{Favor of a Future Ally}: Mythic support from a likely future siphons into the Heart of Jandelay, eroding Xanderghul’s power. He immediately loses 1 Mythic Point. Reduce his AC to 49, his bec de corbin Strike modifier to +40, his waking dreams Strike modifier to +42, and the save DCs of all his non-spell abilities by 4.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.campaign-effects.Item.WWevYlEmHFDBiOLe]{Favor of the Oliphaunt}: The Oliphaunt comes to the PCs in the Heart of Jandelay and brings havoc and ruin to their enemy, trampling and trumpeting Xanderghul as combat begins. This reduces his maximum (and thus his starting) Hit Points to 450 for the rest of the campaign.

@UUID[Item.UVrs4kum7iqydx1a]{Favor of the Divine}: A divinity’s favor doesn’t directly impact Xanderghul but does bolster the PCs defenses. At the start of each round, each PC regains 1 Mythic Point (to the normal maximum of 3). The PCs gain a +2 status bonus to saving throws against any effects created by Xanderghul and a +2 status bonus to their AC against his attacks. The PCs also become quickened for the duration of the fight and can use the extra action any way they want.

Running the Combat.text:
Running the Combat

Once Xanderghul has been adjusted, you’re ready to roll initiative and begin the fight. Xanderghul is a powerful runelord and mythic spellcaster, and his most powerful options are his spells. He has many illusion spells to deceive the PCs and can transform the battlefield by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx]{Freeze Time} to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2BV2yYPfVJ5zirZt]{Mountain Resilience} and illusion spells while the PCs are frozen and unable to see or react to his spellcasting. For the first few rounds of combat, he plays with the PCs, opting for tactics that tease and torment, such as by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.i35dpZFI7jZcRoBo]{Illusory Disguise} to take advantage of Anything You Can Do or Shuffle the Deck, or by using @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.73rToy0v5Ra9NvL6]{Duplicate Foe} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.f8SBoXiXQjlCKqly]{Illusory Creature} to create versions of the PCs to fight against them. Once he’s brought below 250 Hit Points, though, he changes tactics, focusing instead on trying to take down the PCs as efficiently as possible and growing more and more defensive. If Sorshen is providing aid, he might spend some of his actions trying to disable or destroy her, but for the most part he’ll focus on the PCs, knowing that they’re the true threat (remember that any attempt to use Arcana to disable Sorshen is a two-action activity, something Xanderghul is unlikely to want to devote time to in this fight, since even if he’s able to critically succeed on these checks, it’ll take him at least 2 rounds to accomplish). He has no real option to retreat at this point and fights to the death.
Running the Combat.name: Running the Combat

Sorshen’s Aid.text:
Sorshen’s Aid

Unless Xanderghul seizes the advantage, Sorshen can provide aid during this fight—yet she is much reduced in power and struggles herself to resist Jandelay’s pull toward entropy. Had the PCs started the fight only a short time later than they did, she would have perished. Rather than function as an NPC with full stats in this fight, Sorshen’s influence manifests as a haunt-like hazard that works against Runelord Xanderghul. If the PCs can defeat him, Sorshen will be able to regain her body and agency, but for now, even as she fights alongside them against her oldest rival, her actions are limited. She manifests as a transparent version of herself at the center of the map; she can’t move but does her best to provide what aid she can by using her routine against Xanderghul or to aid the PCs as you see fit. If Xanderghul destroys her during this fight, she remains dead if he wins the battle, but if the PCs prevail, she’s able to manifest back in her true body at the end of combat as detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto.JournalEntryPage.03concludingth00]{Concluding the Adventure}.

Sorshen’s Scintillating Garment: If a PC wears this item, Sorshen is delighted and bolstered—her routine has 4 actions instead of 3.

Sorshen’s Sinuous Guisarme: @UUID[Actor.1ftiltkhZlgOkr9O]{Sorshen's Aid}
If a PC wields the replica of this item, Sorshen empowers it by transforming it into the actual @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.yYVbgyLGfhRJaNEY]{Sinuous Guisarme}.

@UUID[Actor.m0bN38pzxBnNnf7P]{Queen Sorshen's Aid} Hazard 22

  • Unique
  • Arcane
  • Complex
  • Haunt
  • Mythic
Sorshen’s Aid.name: Sorshen’s Aid

Unrealized Potential.text:
Unrealized Potential

In addition to the PCs’ options, they can also use the Offering of Destiny action during the fight against Xanderghul, spending the XP they’ve earned beyond level 20 to sap away the Runelord’s strength.

Offering of Destiny 1

  • Mythic

Cost 300 XP; Frequency once per round

You forge a bargain to sacrifice your own unrealized power to sap Xanderghul's strength, forestalling his divine apotheosis. Xanderghul takes a –1 penalty to his spell DCs and spell attack bonus, to a maximum of a –4 penalty, until the end of his next turn. If four PCs use this offering in a round to increase the penalty to its maximum of –4, Xanderghul also loses 1 Mythic Point.

If you prefer to level your players up by milestone instead of awarding XP in your game, your players likely haven't recorded an amount of XP they've earned past 20th level. In this case, each PC can use Offering of Destiny twice in their fight against Xanderghul.
Unrealized Potential.name: Unrealized Potential

Concluding the Adventure.name: Concluding the Adventure
Concluding the Adventure.text:
Concluding the Adventure

Everything comes down to this final confrontation against Xanderghul. If the PCs die in Jandelay, Xanderghul’s apotheosis is complete. He sacrifices the Saga Lands, attains divinity, and leaves Golarion for a new world elsewhere among the stars where he can be its undisputed and unquestioned master. If the PCs escape Jandelay without defeating Xanderghul, the Saga Lands are still doomed unless they can regroup and return to Jandelay to challenge him a second time—but this time, he’ll be ready for them; Sorshen is dead, and he automatically starts combat with his advantage.

If the PCs are successful, they will likely take some time to confirm Xanderghul has truly been killed and is not feigning death with another illusion, but the fact that the watchers disperse into Jandelay should be ample evidence that this particular threat to Golarion has been resolved. If your players continue to doubt they’ve finally succeeded in defeating the most powerful runelord, allow them Perception checks and, regardless of result, confirm to them that he is dead.

Sorshen returns to her physical form at the end of the battle (albeit @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 5} if Xanderghul destroyed the haunt she manifested as during the battle) and thanks the PCs profusely, inviting them to stay with her in the Blood Moon Palace again while they recover from their trials. Banquets and balls are held in their honor across the Saga Lands and into Absalom. The reconstruction of Xin-Eurythnia can also begin in earnest, and the Eurythnians are more than happy to accept any help the PCs might offer.

With Belimarius defeated, Sorshen becomes the sole ruler of New Thassilon. General Nonumaliana returned to Edasseril and claimed the title of Runelord of Envy, but she has yet to secure her hold over Belimarius’ armies and territories. If one of the PCs is interested in leadership, Sorshen offers to mentor them in statecraft and elevate them to rule New Thassilon alongside her. If that PC proved their strength and leadership to the Eurythnians in the evacuation and battle to retake Xin-Eurythnia, Sorshen may instead offer her Blood Moon Palace and leadership of Xin-Eurythnia to rule over themselves as sole monarch (or whatever title or political structure that PC might prefer). In this case, Xanderghul’s return has left Sorshen more concerned than ever that Alaznist’s past self might still be lurking somewhere in the future, and she intends to find a way into the Dimension of Time to stop her no matter when she might be hiding. PCs who want to continue their adventures are welcome to join her, though she can’t say where or when this new quest might take them.

Navigating Jandelay.name: Navigating Jandelay
Navigating Jandelay.text:
Navigating Jandelay

Adventuring in Jandelay

Jandelay is a timeless plane (although the effects of poisons, diseases, and non-natural healing work normally) with normal gravity and metamorphic planar traits (GM Core 172). The PCs are unable to enact lasting change on the archived apocalypses they encounter, but their actions and spells affect the creatures they fight in each apocalypse fragment for as long as those battles last. When the PCs leave a fragment, that apocalypse begins again anew, and any creatures or hazards within revert to their original state.

Tracking XP

Although by this point the PCs should be 20th level, you should still hand out XP as normal as they overcome hazards and combats. They won’t be leveling up, of course, but in the final confrontation against Xanderghul, PCs can expend part of their own mythic power in the form of spending XP to aid in the battle by making an Offering of Destiny (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto.JournalEntryPage.03unrealizedpo00]{Unrealized Potential}).

The captured apocalypses contained within Jandelay are meticulously ordered and maintained by the Watchers, who keep them arranged in chronological rows. If the PCs knew which apocalypse to find Xanderghul in, they would merely need to navigate to the row of captured worlds that corresponds with the date the Watchers recorded that apocalypse to find him. Unfortunately, without knowing Xanderghul’s location, Jandelay’s careful organization doesn’t help the PCs to quickly move between the clusters of final days.

Fortunately for the PCs, they’re not just any heroes—they’re mythic heroes. The sparks of power burning within them enable travel through Jandelay using their wills and imaginations, providing them a way to potentially reach Xanderghul simply by hopping between a few different destructions, rather than potentially spending several lifetimes wandering aimlessly. The PCs realize they can navigate Jandelay in this manner after spending only a few moments exploring the idyllic green pasture they’ve landed in, as they watch how the distant ruined worlds that surround them on all horizons seem to bend and flex toward them whenever they direct their attention to them.

Navigating Jandelay is a mythic deed that uses the following Victory Point-based activity to measure the PCs’ ability to contort reality and negotiate with the metaphysical space. Each time they press Jandelay to bring them to Xanderghul, each PC attempts a skill check to influence the plane to earn Apocalypse Points—either to proceed to the next realm, or to endure their own private devastations before being forced to try again. Once the PCs arrive at an apocalypse, they must prove their dominance over that realm’s cataclysm before they can Navigate Jandelay again, each time moving closer and closer to the plane’s heart, where Xanderghul awaits.

Navigating Jandelay

  • Exploration
  • Mythic

To compel Jandelay to transport you closer to Xanderghul, you must exert your powerful destiny and mastery of reality over the plane. An attempt to navigate Jandelay takes 1 hour, during which each PC can attempt one of the following DC 42 skill checks to force the plane to move them closer to Xanderghul: @Check[arcana|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate], @Check[nature|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate], @Check[occultism|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate], or @Check[religion|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate] (to use your power over magic to manipulate reality); @Check[deception|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate], @Check[diplomacy|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate], or @Check[intimidation|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate] (to compel Jandelay to obey through the strength of your personality); @Check[athletics|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate] (to physically force the plane to obey); or @Check[survival|dc:42|traits:jandelay-navigate] (to use your powers of exploration to simply know the right path forward). Alternatively, a PC can simply spend the hour allowing Jandelay into their minds so they can become one with this reality and then adjust it to their whims by instead attempting a @Check[will|dc:45|traits:jandelay-navigate] save. Successes have the following results.

Critical Success The party accrues 2 Apocalypse Points.

Success The party accrues 1 Apocalypse Point.

Critical Failure The party loses 1 Apocalypse Point. If they have no points to lose, this attempt to Navigate Jandelay ends immediately, even if other PCs haven't tried a check, and the party suffers visions of Golarion's devastation before they can attempt to Navigate Jandelay again.

Facing the Fiends.name: Facing the Fiends
Facing the Fiends.text:
Facing the Fiends Moderate 20

Facing the Fiends Moderate 20

@UUID[Actor.ngMoWJMKlWRbqM2z]{Astradaemons (6)} @UUID[Actor.Yhnb8Xd0Na9YBht6]{Lesser Deaths (2)}

Creatures: If the PCs run out of time, they're attacked by six astradaemons and a pair of lesser deaths whose bones glow red and whose skulls sport diabolic horns. This encounter plays out on the map Androffa’s End.

Surviving the Freeze.name: Surviving the Freeze
Surviving the Freeze.text:
Surviving the Freeze

If the PCs successfully Rouse the Strange Machine before they run out of their 6 rounds, they have a safe, warm place to hide and witness the extinction of nearly all life on Androffa. Once the apocalypse is complete, they return to the verdant fields of Jandelay and begin another influence round. If instead they face the pursuing fiends, they can make their way to the Strange Machine to seek shelter therein automatically once combat is over.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.Euaeg1m4RxJ0ZEYn]{Strange Machine}

The time that passes as they watch Androffa freeze, crumble, and be consumed happens in an instant, during which the PCs cannot do much but observe—to them, it seems as if an entire month passes in seconds. When the apocalypse is finally over, the PCs can attempt to move on from Androffa to the next apocalypse by Navigating Jandelay.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.0rDokO5tOuON1QjH]{Dead Androffan}
While the PCs wait out the apocalypse, they discover an unexpected treasure: a piece of magical technology known as an empath’s implant. This device sits atop the head of a dead Androffan whom the PCs find inside the strange machine. Appearing as a colorful visor with a long, thin cable that extends from the rim that burrows directly into the wearer’s brain when worn, this device, known in Androffa as an “empath’s visor,” is a technological wonder that essentially duplicates all the powers of a laurel of the empath, save that as a technological item its effects cannot be affected by things that counteract magic. The device is powered by the wearer’s own biometric energies, which causes the wearer to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} for 1 hour whenever the item is invested.

Reward: Grant the PCs 80 XP and 1 Mythic Point each if they complete the chase before the combat triggers.

The Destruction of Iz.name: The Destruction of Iz
The Destruction of Iz.text:
The Destruction of Iz Severe 20

Entire worlds need not be annihilated for the watchers of Jandelay to take note. When a devastating enough catastrophe occurs, they might gather portions of that realm to seed a world’s eventual doom. Golarion first came to their notice during Earthfall, but the second apocalypse the PCs find themselves visiting is from a much more recent event. When a mortal witch named Areelu Vorlesh opened the Worldwound, a legion of demons invaded Golarion. The city of Iz was the first to fall, and it was utterly destroyed. Jandelay’s watchers captured the opening of the Worldwound and preserved Iz’s destruction in this world fragment. Here, demons stalk ruined streets, setting the city on ablaze and slaughtering the citizens of Iz.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[perception|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes this ruined region as coming from the Worldwound, while a critical success confirms these to be the fallen streets of Iz upon Areelu Vorlesh's initial opening of the devastating rift.

The Destruction of Iz Severe 20

@UUID[Actor.tMbe49p69ToOUcpB]{Areelu Vorlesh} @UUID[Actor.F1rBF5EXbGUj0bAJ]{Vrolikai} @UUID[Actor.xzaUsEP6pcHJSqnF]{Shemhazians (4)}

Creatures: The PCs can't change Iz's fate, but if they hope to progress closer to Xanderghul, they need to fight their way through a horde of demons to survive its destruction. The architect of the Worldwound herself, Areelu Vorlesh—or at least, a memory of her—is preserved here amid the devastation she caused. She is eager to fight the PCs from the moment she sees them, assuming they’re yet another group of doomed heroes hoping to defend their homes. As she attacks, she is joined by a vrolikai and four shemhazian demons. They fight to the death, only to reform on to the next apocalypse.

Once the PCs have defeated Areelu Vorlesh and her demon attendants, they can make their way through the remainder of Iz’s destruction while helplessly watching the Sarkorian city burn and fall into the growing rift below all around them. The PCs will face no further dangers worth their time here and are free to Navigate Jandelay once more.

The Fall of Bakrakhan.name: The Fall of Bakrakhan
The Fall of Bakrakhan.text:
The Fall of Bakrakhan Moderate 20

In this apocalyptic world fragment, the PCs emerge into the Thassilonian city of Xin-Bakrakhan, the capital of Runelord Alaznist’s domain in the shadow of Hollow Mountain, just as Earthfall fills the sky with fire. The event is already visible in the sky when the PCs appear alongside dozens of others on the city streets, as people gawk up in the heavens, growing increasingly panicked as the stars themselves appear to descend. The watchers were here, even after the gods of Azlant intervened to block what would have been a planet-destroying event. The resulting devastation of countless falling stars crashing into Golarion would still be enough to trigger the fall of Azlant, Thassilon, and many other societies and would trigger the Age of Darkness. As terrified people rush through city streets, several streaking meteors in the sky above scar the heavens, but one in particular—a red star in the sky—seems stationary as it only grows brighter.

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.3j1sBoKQxIPG8fa0.PlaylistSound.hgG6EEj4AA3zAh2h]{The Fall of Bakrakhan} @UUID[Playlist.bWvbAaWPwS7xzaag.PlaylistSound.AIQp17h11BSEy2Il]{Megatsunami}

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[society|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[perception|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes the city they stand in as Xin-Bakrakhan but notes that the city is not in ruins and realizes they've arrived right before Earthfall, some ten thousand years in the past. A critical success notes that the ominous red star is one that would plunge into the heartland of Bakrakhan—an impact that would cause most of Alaznist's empire to be transformed into what today is known as the Varisian Gulf. The PCs are in no danger of perishing in fire from a direct strike, but the floods of a megatsunami are imminent.

The Fall of Bakrakhan Moderate 20

@UUID[Actor.Yjaqlr9yiK1TSH10]{Earthfall}

Hazard: Because the PCs know of this recorded apocalyptic event, they know danger and destruction are coming. As Earthfall strikes, smaller fragments of the larger meteor that strikes in the Bakrakhan heartlands southeast of Xin-Bakrakhan slam into the city itself, creating localized explosions and devastation—but these aren’t the cause of the city’s destruction.

Use the city map of Xin-Bakrakhan to set the stage for this encounter. The PCs appear near Fury Gate at the lowest elevation point in the city, the area most in danger of being directly affected by the coming megatsunami. As the disaster continues, those waters sweep inward—and the falling meteors affect the entire region, regardless of location. The PCs first appear in the lower elevation section of the East Furies.

Apocalyptic hazards are a special form of hazard introduced in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22105theend.JournalEntryPage.05apocalyptich00]{The End of Worlds}. This hazard combines the elements of a megatsunami with a meteor shower, pushing encounter threat level even higher. Make sure you’re familiar with how apocalyptic hazards work before this encounter begins.

The PCs can each attempt a check to Anticipate this hazardous apocalypse; if any PC succeeds, then each PC can attempt to Prepare for the hazard before its routine begins.

If the PCs survive this event’s first five minutes, the devastation to Xin-Bakrakhan continues to unfold around them, but they'll have reached a place of relative safety from the devastation that they can begin Navigating Jandelay while the city burns and drowns.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.VQxxaUzZjYAwJywY]{Bejeweled Chest}
On any round during which a PC isn't in danger of either being struck by a meteor or hit by the tsunami, that PC can attempt a @Check[perception|dc:42] check. The first time during this encounter a PC succeeds at this check, they notice a bejeweled chest of darkwood that's been swept up by the water and has become caught against a ruined building's facade. The PC can choose to secure the chest, but doing so exposes them to the tsunami's waters during the next minute. If the chest is claimed, it's too badly damaged to be worth much and falls apart soon after it's recovered, but the viper rapier within can be salvaged.

Spindlehorn’s Collapse.name: Spindlehorn’s Collapse
Spindlehorn’s Collapse.text:
Spindlehorn's Collapse Moderate 20

When a world comes to Jandelay’s attention, it sometimes reaches across alternate timelines to draw in apocalypses that might have been—these endings that could have happened but didn’t never last for very long before they’re inevitably absorbed by Jandelay and remade into something new, but the PCs’ journey through the strange realm happens to coincide with one such recent, if temporary, addition—a world in which the PCs themselves brought about the end of the world through their own errors.

This fragment contains an apocalypse recorded from an alternate timeline, where the PCs weren’t up to the task of conjuring the Oliphaunt to ride it into Jandelay. In this timeline, the PCs’ mythic destinies failed them, and rather than drawing the Oliphaunt for a brief moment, they instead tore open the boundaries between worlds and allowed the Oliphaunt to rampage unchecked and uncontested through the Saga Lands.

As the PCs draw near to this apocalypse, they have the sudden strange sensation of reliving the moment they conjured the Oliphaunt at the end of the previous chapter, but this time their ritual fails, and as the Oliphaunt manifests into the world, it casually shoulders aside Spindlehorn, causing the megalithic tower to collapse to the ground, taking the PCs with it. The Oliphaunt then thunders off to the southwest, intent on laying waste, and a moment later the PCs find themselves standing on the ground near the collapsed pinnacle of Spindlehorn, watching as their own bodies from this alternate reality swiftly decay amid the rubble.

Creatures: The alternate-timeline PCs don't stay dead, however. As soon as the PCs regain control of their actions, the broken versions of themselves rise up, groaning and shrieking from the agony of their bodies, minds, and souls decaying and falling into ruin. At the same time, reality itself begins to crumble away as Jandelay consumes this temporary apocalypse, eager to reabsorb it.

The defeated versions of the PCs instinctively recognize those they’re based on as rivals and focus their attacks on their doubles—they don’t have the PCs’ abilities or mythic powers, as they’re merely tormented undead “what-if” versions, yet they’re still quite powerful. By defeating these undead versions of themselves, the PCs complete their final steps through Jandelay, but at the end of each round of combat, the decay of reality around them as this alternate timeline is reabsorbed inflicts a swiftly growing penalty.

Spindlehorn's Collapse Moderate 20

@UUID[Actor.xI4LGKFv2Eeu6QlE]{Tormented Heroes (4)}

At the end of the first round of combat, each PC takes @Damage[6d6[untyped]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:35|basic:true] save); this damage ends once all four tormented heroes are slain. The tormented versions of each PC do not take this damage. If the PCs can defeat their undead doppelgangers before they are themselves killed (either by a tormented PC or the ambient decay of reality), they prove themselves worthy of existence—proceed with @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22103raceto.JournalEntryPage.03theheartspre00]{The Heart’s Precipice}.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.ShbFJM5fouslCeIM]{Reclaimed Destinies}
Because the PCs just defeated alternate universe copies of themselves, even though those copies carried no gear, the surge of reclaimed destinies infuses their belongings nevertheless. As at the end of Chapter 2 (See @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22102callto.JournalEntryPage.02theashenmans00]{Here}), each PC can immediately apply a mythic rune to a suit of armor or weapon they own, but this time they can choose from among mythic armor potency, mythic weapon potency, mythic resilient, or mythic striking as their rune to apply.

Rewards: Navigating Jandelay to the plane’s heart is a mythic deed, and once the PCs complete this last encounter, they each earn 3 Mythic Points.

The Heart’s Precipice.name: The Heart’s Precipice
The Heart’s Precipice.text:
The Heart's Precipice Extreme 20

As the PCs complete the fourth and final apocalypse, they emerge on the precipice of the Heart of Jandelay, a distorted bubble of ruin created from the personal apocalypse of Xanderghul’s sundered ambitions. The Runelord of Pride struggled to accept the numerous defeats he’s suffered, most recently his assassination by Alaznist and then a second, even more humiliating defeat at the hands of heroes who struck him down as he was recovering from that assassination in his own Temple of the Peacock Spirit. Even as his soul was hurled into the Eclipse of Abaddon, Xanderghul clung to the idea that his greatness was too profound and plans too careful to have been so simply foiled, and the fact that a god’s death triggered his resurrection only bolsters these convictions.

Using the divine power of his nascent ascension and drawing upon the potent magic stored in his greatest treasures, Xanderghul carved out this externalized receptacle of collapsed schemes deep within Jandelay. Instead of a memory fragment of a destroyed world, Xanderghul’s creation is a fortified bubble of distorted time, where he meant to hide and complete his apotheosis away from reality’s meddling. Sorshen pierced this bubble when she entered Jandelay through a Doomsday Door, disrupting his plans—and then when the PCs prevented the remaining Doomsday Door from being opened by his faithful Risen of the Trinity Star, they further narrowed Xanderghul’s options. Now, his only way forward is to defeat Sorshen and then draw from her items and soul the extra boost of mythic power he needs, yet Sorshen is nearly his equal.

From the precipice, the PCs can see both runelords within this bubble of collapsed time, where Sorshen has been fighting Xanderghul for both all of time and for only a moment, simultaneously. The two appear frozen to those outside this bubble, but within, their battle has raged since nearly the start of Revenge of the Runelords. Meanwhile, the Oliphaunt has joyfully returned to its eternal task of devastating ruined worlds as quickly as Jandelay restores them, so the memories of those lost to those apocalypses experience the fall of their societies forever. Nothing that ends is ever forgotten in Jandelay.

At the center of Jandelay, shards of a dozen broken worlds crown a crystal sphere of suspended time. Blurred images of Xanderghul and Sorshen duel within the sphere, vacillating forward and back through the timeline of an immutable battle. Trapped in a timeless hole at the center of a timeless plane, victory and loss are unattainable; they can only play their roles in the eternal war they’ve waged against each other across the ages. The sphere is surrounded by slabs of jagged broken stone that float in a churning violet void, while further out, landscapes cobbled together from hundreds of different dead worlds stand watch as the Oliphaunt of Jandelay trumpets and tramples through the ruins, only for the structures and features to rebuild in the creature’s wake.

This region of Jandelay has strange gravity instead of normal gravity, meaning all bodies of mass are centers of gravity with roughly the same force. A creature can stand on any solid object that's as large as or larger than them. A PC who's incapable of flight and steps off the edge of any of the solid ground here falls—they can Grab an Edge with a successful @Check[reflex|dc:40|traits:manipulate,action:grab-an-edge|name:Grab an Edge] save. If they fail, they fall for what seems like an eternity, only to land prone a moment later on the ground next to where they fell, taking @Damage[20d6[mental]] damage from the experience (@Check[will|dc:40|basic:true] save). The PCs appear on the largest shard of solidity, but they're not alone. Use the Heart's Precipice map for this encounter.

Creatures: Before the PCs have an opportunity to investigate the sphere of frozen time, a pair of towering spider-like entities—watchers—crawl up from below the floating rocks and block their approach. The watchers communicate with the PCs telepathically, demanding they depart from Jandelay, return to whatever plane they call home, and wait for the proper time to join the Apocalypse Archive. They don’t know how the PCs reached Jandelay, nor do they truly know if the Oliphaunt brought them to the watchers or to Xanderghul, but the archives aren’t meant to have visitors, and the PCs cannot be hosted.

The watchers do know the PCs have been trampling through their realm and surviving every apocalypse they encounter along their way. They note in this conversation that the mysterious entity they refer to only as “The First Watcher” has noticed them, and though these two watchers do not say so directly, their statements imply that garnering the First Watcher’s attention is negative.

Unlike the PCs, these watchers seem unconcerned by Xanderghul’s presence and do not view him as a threat to Jandelay’s integrity. Whether they accept Xanderghul because he intends to deliver them the Saga Lands or simply because he hasn’t entered their collection of archived worlds, the watchers do not say.

The Heart's Precipice Extreme 20

@UUID[Actor.xaRNAJbvnKWMMoKZ]{Watchers (2)}

The PCs have a chance here to each plead their case to the watchers by attempting a @Check[diplomacy|dc:42] check to explain themselves, a @Check[intimidation|dc:45] check to convince the watchers they deserve to be here in Jandelay, or a @Check[deception|dc:53] check to trick the watchers. These checks earn Victory Points, and the party can attempt up to four in all (although no one PC can attempt the same skill check more than once). If the PCs earn at least 3 Victory Points, one of the watchers is convinced and recedes back to simply observe, while if the PCs earn at least 5 Victory Points, both watchers step back. Watchers who don’t step back will attack as soon as the PCs make it apparent they intend to meddle with Xanderghul and Sorshen, resulting in an Extreme 20 encounter (if they both fight) or merely a Moderate 20 encounter (if only one remains in their way). A watcher fights until it’s reduced to 150 HP or less, at which point it goes Out of Phase and remains so for the rest of the adventure.

Reward: Grant the PCs XP for any watchers they convince to step aside as if they’d defeated them in combat. If they convinced both watchers to step aside, grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary deed (2 Mythic Points if they managed to succeed at a Deception check to trick one of the most observant of all creatures in the Great Beyond).

Time Everlasting.name: Time Everlasting
Time Everlasting.text:
Time Everlasting

More watchers arrive as the PCs’ confrontation with the two above plays out, but they don’t approach the PCs or the sphere. For now, they merely observe from a distance in growing numbers while Out of Phase, ready to bear witness to Xanderghul’s ascension or his defeat. The only thing remaining between the PCs and Xanderghul now is the crystalline sphere of distorted time. Because time is frozen within the sphere, the PCs can use this opportunity within the safety they’ve carved out at the Heart of Jandelay to rest and prepare for their final confrontation against the Runelord of Pride. The PCs can take as long as they want for these preparations as long as they don’t leave the area—any attempt to do so causes the watchers to bristle, automatically warning the PCs that if they do leave, they’ll need to potentially face more opposition from these powerful creatures.

But as long as the PCs remain, the watchers don’t interrupt the PCs’ preparations, no matter how long they take. As they watch, they telepathically sing an eerie hymn that honors the Oliphaunt’s role in the Great Beyond as the destroyer who clears the way. A PC with legendary proficiency in Performance can learn the song by ear and perform with the watchers, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to all checks to break the temporal distortion (@UUID[Item.fu8trCmPIzLFSkeA]{Watcher's Hymn}).

When the PCs are prepared, they can turn their attention to the task of breaching the bubble of frozen time. As high-level mythic characters, they have many resources at their disposal, and they can call on powerful allies, foes they’ve shown mercy to, and benefactors both mortal and divine for aid in piercing the crystalline barrier. They’ll automatically learn the following after taking 10 minutes to Investigate the sphere:

  • With enough work, it’s possible to break through the sphere and force Xanderghul and Sorshen into the PCs’ timeframe through the application of various skill checks, but once this process begins, it’s very likely that Xanderghul will take note and choose to remove the protection at his convenience a few rounds later, timing it to his advantage rather than the PCs’ advantage. In other words, once they begin to work on the distortion, they’ll need to work quickly to accomplish as much as possible and can’t turn back.
  • Sorshen appears to be on the defensive, but if the PCs can force the distortion to end before Xanderghul chooses to do so, she may be able to provide aid during the following conflict.
  • Finally, the PCs notice faint images of allies and enemies who have played a role in the campaign flickering and flashing across the surface of the immense sphere, almost as if the entire bubble was functioning like an immense crystal ball. By focusing further, a PC can draw upon the good will of these individuals—earning favors from past, present, and future allies and enemies to reduce Xanderghul’s power.

Breaking the Temporal Distortion.text:

Once they begin, they have 4 rounds before Xanderghul decides to end the distortion himself, which gives him an advantage by preventing Sorshen from taking part in the following clash and also limiting the number of favors the PCs can rely upon.
