The Heart of Jandelay.name: The Heart of Jandelay
The Heart of Jandelay.text:
The Heart of Jandelay Extreme 20

As shards of ended worlds drive into Xanderghul’s crystalline sphere, piercing the barrier and shattering it open, waves of distorted time shutter across the planes; Sorshen and Xanderghul rejoin linear time, coalescing into singular points across their eternal battle.

In this climactic battle at the center of Jandelay, the PCs face off against Xanderghul, Runelord of Pride. Xanderghul is an exceptionally dangerous foe and has mythic power, like the PCs. Even for 20th-level heroes, Xanderghul presents a beyond Extreme threat encounter. Fortunately, the PCs need not fight Xanderghul alone. Sorshen rushed to Jandelay immediately when she saw her first glimpse of Xanderghul through the Circle of Open Hands, and she has fought tirelessly to hold Xanderghul back since. Now, she fights alongside the PCs to stop Xanderghul once and for all.

In addition to Sorshen, any favors the PCs called upon can influence the battle as well, using their power to distract and weaken Xanderghul further. Before beginning this final battle, it’s best to call for a brief break—give the players a chance to talk over strategy while you take some time to prepare and adjust Xanderghul’s stats, applying the modifiers associated with the allies the PCs successfully called to Jandelay in the previous section.

The Heart of Jandelay Extreme 20

@UUID[Actor.wzKrjdfyv2Y5F9vC]{Runelord Xanderghul}

Use the Heart of Jandelay map for this final battle, maintaining the PCs’ positions on the crown of rubble as it pierces through the barrier. Like the Heart’s Precipice, this area of Jandelay has strange gravity, allowing creatures to stand on any solid object that's as large as or larger than themself.

Xanderghul’s Advantage.name: Xanderghul’s Advantage
Xanderghul’s Advantage.text:
Xanderghul’s Advantage

If the PCs weren’t able to bring down the temporal distortion before the end of round 4, Xanderghul does so himself at the start of round 5. In this event, he’s able to keep Sorshen shunted in the distortion so that she can provide no aid in this combat. If the PCs managed to gain any favors from across time and space, one of them is randomly lost. Xanderghul rolls for initiative with Arcana as a result of starting combat by undoing the magical distortion to his advantage.

Beyond the Campaign.name: Beyond the Campaign
Beyond the Campaign.text:
Beyond the Campaign

With Revenge of the Runelords, Paizo has finally published what we hope serves as an epic conclusion to the runelord threat that began at the very start of the Pathfinder Adventure Paths, but we need you, the GM, to help us carry the story over the finish line for your group—especially if you’ve played other runelord-themed Adventure Paths. Use this adventure as an opportunity to include callbacks to your table’s favorite moments in Rise of the Runelords, Shattered Star, Return of the Runelords, or even tangentially related adventures like Rusthenge or Seven Dooms for Sandpoint. Done right, this adventure not only pays off a mythic storyline, but several stories that have been playing out for nearly two decades!

But the story doesn’t have to end with Xanderghul’s long-delayed (and hopefully final!) defeat. Even as the PCs in this campaign reach the height of mortal power, new stories can emerge out of the events in Revenge of the Runelords for new heroes to tackle. Presented on the following pages are some suggestions for what might lie in store for future adventures in the Saga Lands.

Rebuilding Xin-Eurythnia.name: Rebuilding Xin-Eurythnia
Rebuilding Xin-Eurythnia.text:
Rebuilding Xin-Eurythnia

The city of Xin-Eurythnia suffered greatly during the events of Revenge of the Runelords, but it wasn’t destroyed, and as its citizens return, they bring with them their great skill and powerful magic. Whether the PCs of this very Adventure Path remain to help with the rebuilding effort, or new PCs arrive to provide what aid they can, there’s plenty to keep people busy, including the constant need for new supplies (and protection for those who gather said supplies), repelling of Darklands denizens who have claimed portions of the city, and making safe buildings whose magical protections have gone awry. The face of Karzoug no longer looms from the peak of Mhar Massif, and the Pinnacles of Avarice are devastated, but powerful foes and dangerous hazards set loose by the damage could potentially cause problems as well.

The Circle of Open Hands.name: The Circle of Open Hands
The Circle of Open Hands.text:
The Circle of Open Hands

Xanderghul’s interference disrupted the Unveiling Ceremony at the start of this campaign, preventing the Circle of Open Hands from linking with its sister portal in Absalom, yet the ruined portal can be salvaged from the sinkhole into which it plummeted. That sinkhole must be repaired as well, and makes for a great place to dispose of rubble cleared from the city streets. Wise (and powerful) PCs might push for the destruction of the Doomsday Door down below (see the previous adventure for details on this artifact), but simply filling in the sinkhole with rubble (augmented, perhaps, via magic like shape stone or wall of stone) should be enough to prevent it from becoming a problem again.

Once the sinkhole is repaired, Sorshen herself can provide the bulk of the work in repairing the Circle of Open Hands. Its final, successful activation can serve as a satisfying coda to your Revenge of the Runelords campaign, and the new link established with Absalom will make the process of rebuilding the rest of Xin-Eurythnia all the easier.

Sorshen’s Role.name: Sorshen’s Role
Sorshen’s Role.text:
Sorshen’s Role

As the last of the old runelords, Sorshen is ready to give up many of those old traditions and embrace the new world she finds herself in—assuming she survives or returns from Jandelay at all! While she’s willing to continue to serve as queen of New Thassilon, she’s also open to feedback from the PCs, and it won’t take much convincing from these mythic heroes for her to turn over control of the city and nation to people of the modern era. How the city goes about choosing their new leaders is up to you and your players to determine, of course, but if she ends up stepping aside, Sorshen is most likely to move on from Golarion. Her fear that Runelord Alaznist may have engineered some last-minute escape plan through the Dimension of Time continues to gnaw at her, and in this development, by the end of the year, Sorshen herself is no longer found on Golarion—where she may have gone and what she might discover is left for you to decide.

That said, the baseline assumption going forward is that Sorshen remains queen of New Thassilon and continues to do her best to usher in a more cooperative role for the nation in the Golarion of today. But even if she perished in Jandelay, one significant legacy of her time on Golarion remains: the Runewell of Lust. What’s to become of this potent, dangerous artifact may fall to future heroes, or it could even become the source of a new threat to the region.

Rules for the Runewell of Lust are presented @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22106advent.JournalEntryPage.06artifactsoft00]{Here}, but feel free to adjust them as you desire for any new plots or adventures.

Rise of a New Threat.name: Rise of a New Threat
Rise of a New Threat.text:
Rise of a New Threat

The runelords are far from the only ancient threat that lurks within the Saga Lands, nor is the Trinity Star the only warshard of Gorum to crash down into this region of the Inner Sea. As mentioned on page 92 of War of Immortals, another warshard struck a small, rocky island found in the center of Lake Skotha in the western reaches of the Storval Plateau. This isle has long served as the tomb for a powerful force that was ancient and lost even before the foundation of Thassilon, and as its occupant, Chorak, awakens from his long imprisonment within, the giants of the Storval Plateau rush to serve or deny his growing power.

Chorak is an ancient, immense warlord known as a gigas, one of the supernatural progenitors of giantkind. As the warshard’s influence continues to erode the wards that constrain him and he flexes and strains against his bonds, a new danger could well storm forth from the very heart of the Saga Lands—but this time, not a wielder of devastating arcane magic like the runelords. Part supernatural giant, part undead, part fiend, Chorak was a warlord and commander of armies who sought to enforce his will through strength and brutality. While capable of wielding powerful primal magic, he was first and foremost a creature of martial supremacy—and as such, a very different threat than the runelords Varisia has been forced to contend with over the past few decades!

Chorak, among all the potential threats and future campaign seeds presented here, is a mythic danger, and those who would stand against him would do well to seek their own mythic callings and destinies.

Return of the Risen Runelords.name: Return of the Risen Runelords
Return of the Risen Runelords.text:
Return of the Risen Runelords

In this Adventure Path, the PCs face a large number of risen runelords of various levels of power, all creations of Runelord Xanderghul through the use of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fr1AGcQo7WuvLvUi]{Raise Runelord} ritual. There were dozens of prior runelords for Xanderghul to raise using this ritual, and while the PCs fought several of those, others were never encountered during the course of this campaign. And while only one particular risen runelord can exist at any one time, once one of them is destroyed, a replacement can be created by anyone who knows the ritual.

The PCs learn about the existence of the raise runelord ritual at the end of the first adventure in this campaign, but that resource isn’t complete enough for a PC (or an NPC, for that matter) to learn the ritual—but that doesn’t mean Xanderghul didn’t hide a more complete version of his notes somewhere else. Alternatively, a brilliant spellcaster could theoretically, in time, use those notes to rebuild the ritual themselves—after all, knowledge, once discovered, has a tenacious way of being rediscovered over the ages. One of these spellcasters could even be a risen runelord who managed to survive the events of this Adventure Path, and who tracked down Xanderghul’s surviving notes in hopes of either creating their own army of risen runelord agents, or in an attempt to reverse engineer the potent magic to find a way to break free of the limitations imposed on a risen runelord.

All this is to say that in future campaigns, there’s nothing keeping you from having additional risen runelords show up to vex and torment future PCs. Rumors that a runelord who’s particularly hated by your players has come back to life could be fueled by the actions of one of these newly risen runelords. Or perhaps, like Xanderghul did, a different villain has discovered this method and has been creating new runelords to serve them.

Even rumors that the ritual remains out there could be enough to spur a quest—a race against the clock to recover the ritual’s notes before a new foe can take advantage of the magic for their own nefarious ends. Now that he’s dead, Runelord Xanderghul himself could even become the newest menace brought back via this ritual!

What if Xanderghul Wins?.name: What if Xanderghul Wins?
What if Xanderghul Wins?.text:
What if Xanderghul Wins?

If the PCs failed to prevent the opening of the Doomsday Doors at the end of this campaign’s second adventure, they’ll likely never make it into this final adventure. The devastation caused by Xanderghul’s unimpeded revenge in this case is extensive, initially localized to the Saga Lands (which are completely destroyed by the effects of the various apocalypses unleashed by opened Doomsday Doors) but does not stay there. Left unchecked, these apocalypses spread outward like contagion, swiftly engulfing neighboring nations and, in time, transform all of Golarion into an offering to Jandelay. The Apocalypse Archive gathers fragments of the world and adds it to its collection, and Golarion becomes a dead world. In time, life and new societies may rise here, but such would be a development far beyond the scope of the current campaign and, indeed, its failed heroes.

If the PCs did close the Doomsday Doors yet still fail to defeat Xanderghul, the resulting offering to Jandelay is less extensive. The Saga Lands are still devastated as the Oliphaunt returns to trample and ruin the region, and legions of watchers gather up fragments of what remains. The resulting addition to Jandelay is much smaller and, in time, might fade entirely, yet this part of the Inner Sea will remain in ruins for many years, perhaps even centuries, to come.

Both of these apocalyptic ends could seed unusual new campaigns, though. You could start a new game set in a ruined version of your favorite part of Golarion, or simply somewhere from the Saga Lands, and present it as a post-apocalyptic setting. Such stories work best when those who take part are familiar with the ruins in question, after all. This is why many of the more successful excursions into the genre take place on Earth. In this case, you can pick and choose ruined elements of Golarion for the PCs to encounter, and as they explore, they may slowly come to discover that they’re not on a ruined Golarion at all, but instead trapped within Jandelay. Whether or not the PCs can eventually convince the First Watcher of Jandelay to do something it has never done—return a ruined world to prosperity—could make for the plot of a truly mythic campaign.

As for Xanderghul? If he wins, he becomes a god of arrogance, illusions, monuments, and revenge, but he will not be worshipped on a dead world like Golarion. Instead, his cult grows to power elsewhere, and what those who live in that distant world come to believe about him are their stories to tell. Those who lived and died on Golarion shall never know, and in this, Xanderghul will, at long last, have his revenge.

Exploring Old Xin-Edasseril.name: Exploring Old Xin-Edasseril
Exploring Old Xin-Edasseril.text:
Exploring Old Xin-Edasseril

Now that Runelord Belimarius has been defeated, control of western New Thassilon reverts to Queen Sorshen. There’s a lot of work to be done, such as repairing damage to international relations—particularly with the Land of the Linnorm Kings and smaller local societies such as the Noland raiders, Velashu Horselords, elves of the Mierani Forest, or settlers of the Kindred Coast (featured in the standalone adventure Rusthenge). This political work could appeal to certain groups, and a series of adventures could take place anywhere within New Thassilon’s western half or along its northern or southern borders where PCs are asked to serve as couriers, diplomats, or to perform restoration work similar to what’s needed in Xin-Eurythnia.

One significant location of legendary allure remains, and with Runelord Belimarius gone, previous restrictions on its exploration are no longer enforced. This is, of course, the ruins of the original capital of the nation of Edasseril, located amid the rugged mountains, forested valleys, and deep tarns of central Chakikoth Isle. The Kindred Coast along this island’s southern shores makes for an excellent base of operations for any group who wishes to mount expeditions into the ruins of the first city of Envy before the nation’s capital was relocated to its current site in –5402.

The dangers that await discovery in Old Xin-Edasseril are certainly potent, with whispers of linnorms, structures capable of clambering out of the ground to change locations, a wide range of failed attempts to build upon the success of the sinspawn, and rumors of a feuding tripartite society of bickering, isolated stone giants, lamias, and the fey who rule over the tarn depths likely just scratch the surface of what high-level dangers await within the heart of Chakikoth Isle.

Cataclysmic Planar Rift.name: Cataclysmic Planar Rift
Cataclysmic Planar Rift.text:
Cataclysmic Planar Rift

This apocalypse represents the effects of numerous planar rifts forming and exploding in a region, with the risk of the planar fabric being compromised enough to tear a city-sized (if not larger) hole in reality. These rifts are likely to eject inhabitants of the other plane into the Universe, as well as serve as gateways for furious defenders to pour through to punish anyone they think might be responsible for the problem. Any additional encounters that result from these incursions should award XP as normal for encounters of their difficulty. While the rifts are likely to all lead to the same plane, particularly far-reaching disruptions might create gateways to multiple planes at once, with each rift spewing forth its own defenders. These groups would each have their own aims and agendas, clashing, collaborating, or causing chaos wherever they go.

Colossus Rampage.name: Colossus Rampage
Colossus Rampage.text:
Colossus Rampage

Monsters of titanic proportions awaken and stampede across the land, crushing everything in their wake. These might be a group of battling kaiju, an army of titanic constructs, or another onslaught of oversized creatures. Supervolcanic Eruption.name: Supervolcanic Eruption
Supervolcanic Eruption.text:
Supervolcanic Eruption

Volcanic eruptions are dramatic events in which magma erupts from a planet’s mantle onto its surface. They’re often preceded by earthquakes and the opening of fissures in the ground that vent toxic gases. These initial signs can occur months or even years in advance, making it difficult to predict the eruption’s timing. While the intensity, features, and progression of eruptions vary, this hazard represents the most dangerous variety of eruption, one that can swiftly overtake cities with rapid tides of superheated gas and rock and spew out enough ash to affect the climate for years. When these sorts of eruptions are also supervolcanos, eruptions with the highest degree of explosive force, they cause unparalleled transformation to the landscape and alter climate on a planetary scale.

If you’re looking for something more supernatural, it’s a relatively simple change to adjust the energy damage caused by a supervolcano’s pyroclastic flow to something else—for example, a cloud of ghosts erupting from a long-lost city might inflict mental, spirit, or void damage instead of the fire or electricity damage a normal pyroclastic flow brings. Just be sure to give the new event a suitable description that matches the new type of damage!

The End of Worlds.name: The End of Worlds
The End of Worlds.text:
The End of Worlds

Apocalypses are events that destroy regions and shatter worlds. They’re times of unparalleled destruction that force whoever survives to pick up the pieces and reckon with a dangerous, uncertain aftermath. This article focuses on presenting mechanics to represent the devastation of apocalypses through the framework of apocalyptic hazards meant to challenge the highest-level heroes—those who could, in theory, make the difference between the end of all things and survival for another day.

Remember that beyond the specific immediate effects on PCs from the cataclysms detailed below, apocalyptic events cause significant disruption to the local region, such as environmental devastation and widespread social unrest. While PCs should earn XP as normal for enduring and surviving these in the same way they’d earn XP for any hazard, additional challenges and combats associated with the apocalypse should also be presented as additional encounters. Fully preventing an apocalypse or helping a world recover from a near miss should be the focus of an entire adventure.

Apocalyptic Hazards.name: Apocalyptic Hazards
Apocalyptic Hazards.text:
Apocalyptic Hazards

Apocalyptic hazards are particularly dangerous events. While the PCs are unlikely to be able to stop all of the ramifications of an apocalyptic hazard, they can take actions to improve the outcome for themselves and others.

All PCs who endure an apocalyptic hazard gain XP as if they had overcome a complex hazard (Pathfinder GM Core 57), as long as they survive it—an apocalypse can’t be “disabled” or otherwise ended in the same way smaller-scale hazards can be.

Apocalyptic hazard stat blocks use the following format. These hazards affect larger regions—entire cities, coastlines, or even nations. When they occur, you should determine the size and scope of the area affected; any PCs in that area will be swept up by the hazard’s routine if they don’t anticipate and prepare!

Apocalyptic Hazard NameHazard [Level]

  • Traits

Anticipate This lists the required skill checks and DCs for a character in the affected zone to realize the apocalyptic hazard will begin within the next hour. Any character who meets the proficiency rank listed in parentheses can automatically attempt this check to predict the upcoming event. Success on the check allows the character to warn the rest of the party in time for everyone to attempt to prepare. A critical success allows additional preparation time, granting each PC a +2 circumstance bonus to their checks to prepare and possibly opening up the chance for even better outcomes.

If the PCs learn about the imminent hazard's timing through other means during the course of the adventure, they receive the results of a success or a critical success based upon how far in advance they make this discovery.

Prepare If a PC successfully anticipates the hazard, the party can prepare for the disaster—both readying themselves to meet the hazard and helping to secure the safety of others in the immediate area. Each PC can attempt one of the skill checks listed in this section. If at least half the party succeeds at these checks, the party is prepared to meet the disaster. Otherwise (or if the PCs fail to anticipate the disaster entirely), they're unprepared for the hazard when it hits.

Routine This section describes what the hazard does, how long it lasts, and what the PCs can do to deal with it. The duration of the event is listed in parentheses. A duration with a "+" listed indicates the event can continue; once its duration ends, attempt a flat check with the listed DC. On a success, the event's duration continues, repeating its routine for the same period of time. Continue attempting the flat check at the end of each interval until you roll a failure and the event ends.

Some hazards don't have a specified frequency at which any given creature would be exposed to their damaging effects, since they represent situations like asteroid showers or interplanar explosions where the density of the danger varies. Even in the most extreme situations, a given creature shouldn't be at risk of taking damage from the hazard more than once per minute. During a hazard, each PC should be given a full minute (10 rounds) to take action, either to escape the next minute's effects, to aid others, and so on.

Action If the event takes any actions during its routine, they're detailed here.

Escalation Some apocalyptic hazards can escalate to a higher level, in which case adjustments to the baseline hazard for those higher-level versions are given here. The hazard level of the escalation is listed in parentheses.

Ancient One.name: Ancient One
Ancient One.text:
Ancient One

How Old is Time?

Lying in parallel with the Great Beyond with a presence felt on nearly every plane, from the Inner Sphere to the Outer Rifts, the Dimension of Time holds too many secrets for a reality so seemingly omnipresent. Can a world truly be said to begin before time is there to start? Scholars say @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma} is the oldest being in the Great Beyond, a survivor of some previous multiverse’s collapse, but does the Lady of Graves predate time, or did she bring the Dimension of Time with her so history could begin everything anew?

In the Dimension of Time, creatures clad in tattered robes float between encapsulated bubbles of still, captured moments, untethered to any other place, unspeaking and unseeing. The few mortals to meet these enigmatic, faceless creatures have never known them to identify by any name other than the ancient ones, seemingly holding no identity (or no identity they wish to share) beyond their relationship with time.

The ancients profess to have always existed in the Dimension of Time, and for time to have always existed in the Great Beyond. Most reside in Stethelos, the storied city at the center of time, though they’re also found wandering the Void, crossing the strangest corners of the Maelstrom where it lies between other planes, and occasionally, venturing into dark corners of the Universe. They serve at the will of Tawil at’Umr, the All in One and the One in All, an avatar of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.SUaGdvQXxSAQAw03]{Yog-Sothoth} lurking deep within time as Stethelos’s caretaker. Though the ancient ones resemble their master in stature and attire, and though none would describe Tawil at’Umr as anything other than ancient in origin, most scholars consider “ancient one” a classification of its own separate from that of Great Old One, and Tawil at’Umr is definitively counted among the Great Old Ones by all who know it.

Where @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.SUaGdvQXxSAQAw03]{Yog-Sothoth} is an embodiment of all space and time, an entity who concerns himself with guarding cosmic secrets, the ancient ones are philosophers and mystics seeking ever more enlightenment. They search, have searched, and will search across time indefinitely and, having found entropy and disorder, conclude this to be the Great Beyond’s ultimate purpose. When a new creature dawns, it’s pristine and whole—perfectly ordered—for but a single moment before it can be eroded by Pharasma’s poison, accumulating decay, change, and chaos, until finally it reaches its ending, when time leaves a twilight creature broken and gone. Law and chaos, the ancient ones believe, aren’t opposing or even separate forces, but a single expression of reality viewed from two angles, different from each other only in time.

Into the Dimension of Time

The Dimension of Time is one of the most difficult and complex realms in the Great Beyond to travel to, with restrictions on its access limiting all but the most powerful of planar travelers from visiting it. At the GM's discretion, though, items looted from an ancient one, or even just fragments torn from their robes, could function as the planar key needed to allow a PC to use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} to access the Dimension of Time.

Runic Warmaw.name: Runic Warmaw
Runic Warmaw.text:
Runic Warmaw

Rune giants have specialized talents and magical abilities to command other giants, yet giants are far from the only creatures they favor when it comes to guardians. The first runic warmaws were created by Runelord Alaznist in –5780, not long after she perfected the fleshwarping techniques she learned from the qlippoth lord Yamasoth, in response to her rune giants’ repeated requests for some form of powerful guardian they could deploy against her enemies on the field of battle. In the following years, as with sinspawn and other fleshwarp creations, other runelords capitalized upon these methods to create runic warmaws as well.

A runic warmaw looks somewhat like an immense, elephant-sized hound, yet with horselike heads that have large, toothy jaws well suited to rending flesh. Strange patterns of shifting red runes appear on their black-furred bodies—runes containing latent sources of magic that rune giants can use to access some of a runic warmaw’s magical powers.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.rELMTgvh9e5GHVDL]{Runic Warmaw} Creature 16

Specialized Warmaws

The runic warmaw presented here has been specially bred by rune giants to foster magical powers that serve well in combat, but others with a focus on different types of magical tactics, such as research, defense, or travel, exist. These warmaws have differently themed innate spells—replace the three combat-associated spells listed in the stat block as appropriate for the warmaw's theme you desire for the encounter you're building.

The Ashen Man.name: The Ashen Man
The Ashen Man.text:
The Ashen Man Watcher of the End Times

The Ashen Man meditates on entropy. All life ends, a truth he knows well, but as he’s watched demiplanes collapse, planets go cold, and Jandelay flourish, he’s become increasingly impatient for Golarion to meet the same fate—a fate like all other worlds, a story with both beginning and end. Yet time and again, Golarion has somehow managed to avoid its final reckoning. The Ashen Man watched as Aroden died, along with prophecy itself, and Golarion’s destiny was sundered. If destiny would no longer play out this world’s conclusion, then the Ashen Man would fulfill this duty himself.

The Ashen Man has grown frustrated with Golarion’s heroes, who always seem to save their world from certain annihilation, but he has a habit of meddling in the affairs of heroes as well. Many powerful adventurers have encountered the Ashen Man over the ages, typically challenged to answer his signature questions on the nature of life and death rather than face him in combat.

Campaign Role

The Ashen Man plays a secondary antagonist in this campaign, behind Runelord Xanderghul. Like Xanderghul, he’s been foreshadowed in several prior Adventure Paths and standalone adventures. When the PCs finally confront him, do your best to give the battle the gravitas such a long-anticipated confrontation deserves!

Belimarius.name: Belimarius
Belimarius.text:
Belimarius Runelord of Envy

Belimarius began her career in the convoluted and contentious bureaucracy of Edasseril as a lowly politician, but she swiftly rose through the ranks through luck, tenacity, and a willingness to employ slander, blackmail, and even assassination. All of these factors culminated in her being accepted by Runelord Phirandi as an apprentice—a choice Phirandi would come to regret as Belimarius systematically poisoned and murdered his other apprentices and allies. When only he remained, Belimarius confronted and overwhelmed her former mentor, imprisoning him within a transparent coffin of force so he could do nothing but watch as she took over as the nation’s Runelord of Envy.

Runelord Belimarius emerged into the modern age only a few years ago after being trapped in a time-locked prison, yet since then, she’s more than made a name for herself as one of the Saga Lands’ most tyrannical and petty rulers. Her desire to be the sole commander of all New Thassilon is but a stepping stone, in her mind, to what she sees as her rightful place as ruler of the entire planet. In many megalomaniacal minds, such desires could be written off as deluded fantasies, but Belimarius potentially has the power to make her dreams a reality—although traditionally, she always seems to fall just short of realizing her goals, leaving her perpetually envious of those who she perceives to possess what she alone deserves.

A more detailed look at Belimarius’s personality and history can be found on pages 34–35 of Pathfinder Lost Omens Legends.

Campaign Role

Runelord Belimarius seeks something that’s been denied to her for over 10,000 years—mythic power. If the PCs don’t confront her soon enough in Sorshen’s Eye of Desire during this adventure, she’ll finally gain this power, yet it’s only a fragment of what she might wield, given time. If she survives her encounter with the PCs, Belimarius retreats to her palace in the city of Xin-Edasseril to the west, and in time, she might develop into a truly mythic threat of her own... yet it’s far more likely that her encounter with the heroes in this adventure will be the moment her luck finally runs out.

While this adventure assumes Belimarius makes her last stand in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22101crisis]{Chapter 1}, it’s possible she escapes. If she does, see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22104beyond]{Beyond the Campaign} for what might come next for the most tenacious of the seven runelords!

Liralarue.name: Liralarue
Liralarue.text:
Liralarue Dream Phantom and Self-styled Eighth Runelord

In the days of ancient Thassilon, Liralarue was apprenticed to Karzoug, the last Runelord of Greed. Today, she’s perhaps best known not for how she served Karzoug, but how she turned away from him—if, that is, she’s known of at all.

By all accounts a wizard of middling talent, Liralarue rose to prominence more for her cunning than skill with magic, eventually becoming Karzoug’s spymaster during the later years of his reign. In that role, Liralarue constructed a secret intelligence-gathering complex on the borders of the neighboring nation of Bakrakhan, in a place modern residents of the Lost Coast call “the Pit.” The results of Liralarue’s operation were exceptional, and over time, she expanded the Pit to house chambers hidden from her former mentor and devoted to her own interests, including the summoning of fiends and other extraplanar beings, clockwork technology, cloning, and fleshwarping techniques.

In a move unheard of among the wizards of her day, Liralarue abandoned the traditions of magic she’d learned as Karzoug’s apprentice, shifting her focus to the neglected study of divination, and it was here that she came into her own. She created the Ghost Stone, a powerful divinatory device through which she saw a vision of the devastation wreaked by Earthfall. Spurred by this ill omen, she began to delve into Thassilon’s deep history, eventually arriving at the belief that if King Xin had placed more faith in divinations and prognosticative magic, he might have foreseen his death at the hands of his treacherous runelords.

Soon, Liralarue determined that Thassilon needed an eighth school of magic—one focused on omens and building on the sin of vainglory. She worked to reverse engineer the Pit as an enormous runewell, a device the runelords had created to siphon power from the souls of mortals. Had Liralarue succeeded, the feat could’ve allowed her to save Thassilon from destruction, forever cementing her place as the nation’s Eighth Runelord. As Earthfall neared, however, Liralarue came to suspect her power would be insufficient for such a daunting task. In her final days on Golarion, she was struck by the bitter realization that her efforts to foresee the future had only distracted her from developing her other magical talents, which ironically would’ve helped her avert the doom she’d come to dread.

With no nation of her own to leave behind, Liralarue chose to avoid Earthfall simply by traveling to the Dreamlands. For thousands of years, she drifted half-conscious through that dreamscape and was only stirred back to awareness by the metaphysical events that accompanied the advent of the Age of Lost Omens. Once more, Liralarue took an interest in Golarion, but to her surprise, she realized that the intervening centuries had transformed her into something made from dream, neither undead nor fully alive. Furthermore, although she could see all possible futures laid before her, she’d become detached from fate itself, incapable of manipulating the Universe except through the minds of sleeping mortals. If she wanted to play a role in Golarion’s future once again, she would have to find a group of heroes to become her proxies, her agents, and indeed, her allies.

Campaign Role

With Gorum’s death and Xanderghul’s subsequent return to Golarion, Liralarue decided the time was ripe for her revenge against the runelords who prevented her from achieving the glory she always felt she deserved. Toward this end, she empowered the PCs as her agents by awakening them to their mythic destinies at the beginning of the campaign. Doing so put her in direct conflict with the Ashen Man, who imprisoned Liralarue on Leng to prevent her from lending the characters further aid.

That is, until the PCs traveled to her prison and freed her. Though Liralarue can’t exist outside the Dreamlands, after the PCs rescue her at the end of “Crypt of Runes,” she shares with them everything she knows about Xanderghul’s return, the runelord’s bid to destroy Golarion, and his connection to the Ashen Man, essentially kicking off this final adventure.

Liralarue remains a potent ally to the PCs through this entire Adventure Path. Once she’s rescued from her oubliette in Leng, she settles into a dreamscape of her own creation that duplicates an area in Golarion that the party holds dear—be it a shared hometown, favorite tavern, or anywhere else. Any time the PCs sleep, they can extend their dreams into this dreamscape to speak with Liralarue, during which time she can aid in the following ways (in addition to specific aid she can provide during the adventure itself, as detailed in the appropriate encounter’s text).

Answer Questions: Liralarue can answer questions as best she can by Recalling Knowledge with her skills.

Loan Naginata: @UUID[Actor.QaDx2xxfNNcabt3o]{Liralarue's Naginata}
Liralarue can loan a PC the use of her naginata during a dream. When the PC wakes, the +3 major striking greater astral greater extending vorpal naginata is in their hands and remains with them until the next time they fall asleep or the weapon is destroyed, whichever comes first. After that, the weapon returns whole to Liralarue, and she can’t loan it out again for 1 week. Note that since this naginata isn’t a permanent item, its runes cannot be transferred.

Teach Spells: Liralarue can teach spellcasters any of her spells, provided the spell she’s teaching is on her list of prepared spells and is on the learning PC’s spell list. To do this, the PC must Learn a Spell as normal, but need not pay the price to do so. Time spent learning the spell must be spent asleep in the waking world, and this time doesn’t count toward getting a full night’s rest.

Verdorite, Erzgeist.name: Verdorite, Erzgeist
Verdorite, Erzgeist.text:
Verdorite, Erzgeist

Verdorites don’t rise from the unquiet spirits of humanoids, or even from the souls of sapient creatures at all. Instead, these vengeful undead manifest when disaster befalls the natural world. When enough life is lost, be it plant or animal life, those anguished souls can accrete into a singularity of sorts—a verdorite.

While many verdorites rose in the aftermath of Earthfall, one type of these brutal spirits was already well-established in the heartland of the nation of Shalast—the erzgeist. First spawned in response to the devastation wreaked on the underground environments of the central Storval Plateau by Runelord Kaladurnae’s greed, these creatures persist today in various parts of north-central Varisia—particularly in the region surrounding Spindlehorn.

Erzgeists look like large bats, but they’re ghostly and semitransparent. Instead of fur, their bodies show growths of crystals and jagged shards of rock shot through with gold ore—all of it shimmering and phantasmal. Their eyes are glittering rubies, the membrane in their wings is like pale gold smoke, and their teeth and fangs are made of gold—all reflections of one man’s environment-destroying greed.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.revenge-of-the-runelords-bestiary.Actor.j4hKLFhLQrvC96EN]{Erzgeist} Creature 19

  • Spirit

An Erzgeist's Anger

Erzgeists often latch onto specific examples of mortal cruelty against the natural world—but in particular, cruelty against fey. While they aren't and never were from the First World, they're drawn to the pains of tormented fey—not to seek their release, but to lie in wait for others who might be drawn to the same torments. Even those who seek to free the tormented fey find themselves targets of erzgeists' anger.

Watcher.name: Watcher
Watcher.text:
Watcher

Creation and Destruction

The watchers share Jandelay's fields with the Oliphaunt, herald of the apocalypse, a gargantuan beast that visits worlds on the eve of their annihilation to wreak havoc and destruction. Few scholars can agree if the watchers reach a doomed world first, creating beacons that call the Oliphaunt, or if the Oliphaunt instinctively knows when a world is on the brink of calamity and the watchers follow it as their apocalyptic guide.

Watchers lurk in the shadows of the Universe, witnessing as history unfolds around them across space and time. They come to worlds on the brink of destruction, recording these worlds’ fates and cataloguing apocalyptic events for eternal enshrinement in their massive archives of Jandelay. Watchers usually perform this work unseen, slipping into the background of a plane so they can set their strange beacons undisturbed and secretly place creatures into stasis for transport back to their archives.

Though they concern themselves with calamities and apocalyptic events, the watchers have no desire to see a world end before its time. They’re attracted to the actions of mortal heroes who defy fate and work to avert disasters, and they only rarely intervene to preserve an appointed apocalypse from being stalled by these heroes, often content to witness and record the curious heroics.

When faced with unusual news or threats to Jandelay, watchers congregate into small councils to discuss and consider. These councils typically number no more than five watchers, with one watcher designated as the council’s observer, recording and remembering the meetings. Watcher councils are patient and deliberate, slow to reach any decisions, but once they reach a conclusion, there’s always a unanimous consensus.

Watchers have six long, slick insectile legs and stand approximately 30 feet tall. Small, prehensile filaments hide within their talons, which allow the watchers to achieve an astonishing degree of manual precision.

Many watchers hold an almost religious reverence for the cycle of preservation and destruction that emerges between themselves and the Oliphaunt of Jandelay. This dualistic belief in that which is eternal and that which is lost is commonly interpreted as a faith that deifies both the Oliphaunt and a mysterious First Watcher as demigods of Jandelay. The watchers are often seen alongside the Oliphaunt when it rampages across the Universe, and whether they truly see it as a god, a colleague, or merely a necessary planar phenomenon, the truth of their relationship might simply defy mortal categorization and understanding.

Fending Off the Watchers

The Beacons of Jandelay, towers of energy erected by watchers to mark worlds on the eve of their apocalypse, are a terrifying sight for those who recognize their significance. Though the watchers are commonly understood as mere observers and recorders, some scholars theorize the watchers call the Oliphaunt from Jandelay themselves only after erecting their beacons and preparing to record the ensuing calamity. By repelling the watchers and destroying their beacons (which have AC 48, Hardness 40, and 380 HP) or countering the beacons with an effect like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic}, these scholars believe doomed worlds can be snatched from the jaws of ruin.

Xanderghul Runelord of Pride

Although Runelord Xanderghul has always been the most powerful of the wizards of Thassilon (with the possible exception of Sorshen at the height of her power), and while he ruled his nation of Cyrusian from the very start of Thassilon’s history to the very end during Earthfall, it was never enough for the Runelord of Pride. Always he looked to the accomplishments of his peers and enemies—not with jealousy (for that was the remit of lesser runelords) but with frustration that they would dare approach his power. The fact that Runelord Karzoug was the first to rise from slumber in the modern era, and that Runelord Alaznist got the drop on him a few years later and actually managed to assassinate him only for both to fail in their plans, mattered little to Xanderghul. He only knew they’d bested him in ways that demanded vengeance.

Now it all comes down to this final clash—Runelord Xanderghul has been an arcane bogeyman for the world of Golarion for eons, and in this final conflict, the PCs decide what his ultimate fate will be. He’s cheated death so many times before and come back from fates that would’ve ended lesser creatures, if not erase them entirely from history, but this final attempt to become a god has left him with no retreat options. If he dies this time, the PCs can rest knowing this is one runelord who won't return.

Campaign Role

In preparing to ascend to divinity, Xanderghul has sacrificed much, including the bulk of his magical items. Casting them aside as tools only a lesser mortal would need to prevail is all part of his pursuit of perfection. Many of the benefits these items once provided are now intrinsic qualities of the runelord himself. The one exception is Xanderghul’s flawless hammer—while the weapon no longer functions fully as it once did (its intellect being among the many things Xanderghul consumed during his preparation for his new role as a god), it still serves as a +4 mythic striking greater astral greater extending quickstrike shockwave bec de corbin that retains its potent power even should Xanderghul be slain.
